And the 3,000-room Parisian Macau, Las Vegas Sands' (LVS) nearly $3 billion project, set sail on Sept. 13. Last year, Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) opened its $3.2 billion Hollywood-themed Studio City…

Stocks opened higher Tuesday amid positive overseas trade and a heavy schedule of earnings news.The Nasdaq opened 0.2% higher while the S&P 500 and the Dow industrials inched up 0.1%.The Nasdaq slumped 2.3% in October, its first down month since June. The S&P 500 dipped 1.9% -- its third straight slip. The Dow also dipped for a third time, down 0.9%.A heavy contingent of stocks were in premarket motion Tuesday, stirred by earnings news. Drugmaker Pfizer (PFE) was down 1% at the open, after a third-quarter earnings miss.Integrated oil and gas firm BP (BP) slipped 2% after beating analysts targets, then lowering its 2016 capital spending guidance. Royal Dutch Shell (RDSA) pumped 4% higher after earnings soared past expectations.Archer Daniels Midland (AMD) rolled up a 2.5% gain. The agribusiness heavyweight delivered mixed third-quarter results, but reported exceptionally strong export demand and offered a positive outlook. Shares ended Monday in a three-month cup base with a 45.59 buy point.Diesel engine maker Cummins (CMI) dropped 2%. Adjusted third-quarter earnings dropped less than forecast by consensus estimates, but revenue dropped 9% -- more than expected. Weak demand in heavy duty truck engines was a drag on results. Cummins has been fighting to clear a flat base buy point of 127.74 since early October.Coach (COH) opened 3% higher after reporting third-quarter earnings that met, and revenue that missed analyst expectations. But same-store-sales at U.S. brick-and-mortar stores rose a better-than-expected 4% and international sales jumped 7%.Casino stocks advanced after Chinese officials reported gaming revenue in the gambling district of Macau rose 8.8% in October, a third straight increase. Wynn Resorts (WYNN) rose 4% as MGM International (MGM) and Las Vegas Sands (LVS) rose 2% apiece.Ford (F) announced Monday it would report its October sales later this week due to a fire at its Dearborn, Mich., headquarters. Other automakers are expected to report Tuesday. The Federal Open Market Committee today begins its two-day meeting, with a policy announcement due Wednesday afternoon. Today's  economic calendar kicks in at 9:45 a.m. ET, when researcher Markit reports its manufacturing purchasing managers index for October. The Institute for Supply Management follows with its October PMI at 10 a.m. ET. October construction spending numbers are due from the Commerce Department, also at 10 a.m. ET.Oil prices were steady after Monday's 4% dive. West Texas Intermediate edged above $47 a barrel. Gold climbed 1% to above $1,288 an ounce. The dollar was mixed: up vs. the yen and down against the euro. Bonds slipped, lifting the 10-year yield 4 basis points to 1.86%.Positive manufacturing data boosted China's markets while the Bank of Japan's decision to hold monetary policy unchanged tamped Tokyo's Nikkei 225 to a 0.1% gain.  Europe's markets slipped into mixed action in afternoon trade, with the CAC 40 in Paris down 0.2% and Frankfurt's DAX off 0.2%, and London's FTSE 100 showing a 0.1% gain.RELATED:Cummins Q3 Declines Expected, But Markets Could Be Bottoming

Macau gaming revenue rose a better-than-expected 7.4% in September, the second straight year-over-year gain after a 26-month decline, helped by two massive casino openings in the world's No. 1 gambling destination.Las Vegas Sands (LVS) opened the Parisian Macao last month, while Wynn Resorts (WYNN) opened Wynn Palace in August. The casino resorts offer more entertainment and nongaming tourism, with the Parisian including a mock Eiffel tower.Analysts had predicted a Macau gaming revenue of flat to up 5% last month. The new casinos' novelty — and credit extended to high rollers — likely boosted September. There's some concern that growth going forward will be limited.But back at home, are any Macau-heavy casino stocks are worth mulling a wager on? Let's take a look at Las Vegas Sands, Wynn Resorts, MGM Resorts (MGM) and Hong Kong-based Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL).Las Vegas Sands broke out of a cup-with-handle base with a 51.33 buy point on Aug. 9. A few weeks later, it fell just below the pivot. Then on Sept. 1, when Macau reported August gaming revenue had turned up, Sands stock surged 7%. The next day, Sands stock moved past the 5% buy zone. Shares peaked at a 17-month high of 58.65 on Sept. 16. Since then shares have consolidated, closing at 57.54 on Friday. Shares rose 2.3% to 58.87 at the close on the stock market today, but there's no sound entry point for now.Las Vegas Sands' profit and revenue have been falling for several quarters, though top-line declines have been shrinking for the past five quarters.IBD'S TAKE: In the current market environments, investors should be careful about making new purchases. Stocks tend to move with the market, so every day keep up with the major indexes and leading stocks with The Big Picture, open to nonsubscribers through Oct. 9.Wynn Resorts cleared a 105.79 buy point on Sept. 14, and rose the following day. But two sessions later, Wynn shares fell below the pivot and then continued sliding. On Friday, shares fell more than 3% to 97.42, closing below the 50-day moving average for the first time since Sept. 7. Wynn rose 1.9% to finshed the trading session at 99.28 Monday.Wynn revenue rose 2% in Q2, the first yearly gain since Q2 2014. Earnings per share rose 53% and 45% in the last two quarters, but analysts see EPS declines in Q3 and Q4.MGM Resorts is the least Macau-centric of the big three casino operators. MGM is the top casino operator on the Las Vegas Strip.MGM tried to break out on Sept. 8, but closed just below the 25.39 buy point. MGM moved above the pivot point on Sept. 15 and Sept. 22, but soon faded below 25.39 again. Finally last week shares moved above the entry area and appear to hold. Shares closed at 26.03 on Friday.MGM shares climbed 0.6% to 26.19 at the close Monday, still in buy range.MGM revenue declines have gradually gotten smaller. Q2 EPS rose 76%. Analysts expect a 17% drop in Q3, but then forecast several quarters of strong growth.Melco Crown Entertainment's U.S. shares have been forming a handle in a cup base with a 16.32 buy point. On Thursday, Melco Crown tried to break out, but reversed with the general market. Shares closed Friday at 16.11.Shares rose as high as 16.70 Monday morning, breaking past the entry point again in heavy volume. But the stock retreated and ended the day up 0.9% at 16.26.Melco profit was flat in Q2 after eight straight EPS declines. Analysts expect a 17 % rise for Q3 and 450% in Q4. Revenue rose 17% in Q2 after a 5% gain in Q1 and a 6% fall in Q4 2015.RELATED:MGM, Wynn Resorts Undercut Buy Points As Casino Stocks Fall

Stocks opened slightly lower Monday, as the dollar slipped and the New York Fed reported a slowdown in regional business activity.The Dow industrials fell 0.1% at the open, with Walt Disney (DIS) down 0.5% and Coca-Cola (KO) up a fraction. The S&P 500 also was down 0.1% and the Nasdaq eased 0.2%.Bank of America (BAC) climbed 0.5% after reporting stronger-than-expected third-quarter results. Bank of America wrapped up Friday's session just below a 16.34 buy point in a flat base.Trucking fleet operator JB Hunt Transportation Services (JBHT) dropped 2.5%. The Lowell, Ark.-based outfit said an unexpected rise in costs dragged its third-quarter earnings below analysts targets.Oil refiner Alon Energy (ALJ) jumped less than 1%. Alon confirmed it had received a takeover offer from Delek U.S. Holdings (DK) to acquire the company for 0.44 shares of Delek stock for each outstanding share of Alon. A statement from Alon said it is reviewing the offer. Delek shares fell 1%.Hasbro (HAS) sprung 6% as a 28% earnings leap and a 14% gain in revenue topped consensus projections. Toymaking peer Mattel (MAT) caught some of Hasbro's tailwinds, rising 2% at the open.Casino stocks were under pressure, but narrowed their early losses with Melco Crown (MPEL) down 1% and Wynn Resorts (WYNN) slipping 1.5% at the open. Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and MGM Resorts International (MGM) dipped less than 2% each. News reports said 18 employees of Australia's Crown Resorts -- part owner of Melco Crown -- had been detained by Chinese authorities in Macau late last week.News outlets including Reuters and CNBC said Chinese authorities said the group were being held due to "suspected involvement in gambling crimes." Traffic to Macau has slowed under a program by Chinese officials to root out illegal activities in the special administrative region.The New York Federal Reserve's Empire State Manufacturing Survey slumped to a minus 6.8 reading for October. Declines in new orders eased and shipments were effectively flat for the month, the report noted, as prices firmed. Roughly 27% of respondents said business conditions had improved, 33% reported activity declined.The Federal Reserve's industrial production and capacity numbers for September are due out at 9:15 a.m. ET.Oil prices improved early Monday, with West Texas Intermediate crude gaining ground above $50 a barrel. Gold traded steady at $1,255 an ounce. The dollar slipped vs. the euro and the yen. Bonds edged up, trimming the 10-year Treasury yield by 2 basis points to 1.78%.Overseas markets traded moderately lower, with benchmark indexes in Japan and China ending down less than 1%. In Europe, the CAC 40 in Paris and Frankfurt's DAX were each down less than 0.4% in afternoon trade. London's FTSE 100 was off 0.7%.

Many casino stocks slipped on Monday after strengthening for much of the month, with Wynn Resorts (WYNN) among those crossing below buy points intraday.Wynn Resorts fell 4.25% to 103.96 in above-average volume, under a 105.79 buy point of a three-month-old consolidation. Gambling revenue in the area increased in August for the first time in more than two years. Eldorado sank 2.9% to 13.84 and continues to grind through a flat base begun in July.The deal, Eldorado CEO Gary Carano said in a statement, was part of a bigger plan to "expand our regional gaming platform through accretive acquisitions." The transaction is expected to close in the second quarter of next year.RELATED:Tech Data Buys Avnet Unit, Eldorado Acquires Isle Of Capri, Infoblox OKs BuyoutWynn Resorts Falls As Macau Restricts Tables At New CasinoTime To Bet On Casino Stocks As Macau Nears Turnaround?

Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and Wynn Resorts (WYNN) hit new 52-week highs Wednesday afternoon amid continued momentum in global gaming mecca Macau, but the most intriguing big casino stock may be MGM Resorts (MGM).Macau reported two weeks ago that gambling revenue grew 1.1% to $2.4 billion in August, the first increase for China's only legal gambling district since May 2014. Here's a look at how casino stocks are faring.Las Vegas Sands shares rose 3.2% to 58.31, hitting their best levels since April 2015. The stock has been on a strong uptrend since blasting out of a cup-with-handle base at a 51.33 buy point on Sept. 1, after the Macau gaming industry figures came out.Las Vegas Sands has reported several quarters of falling earnings and revenue, but the declines have gotten smaller as Macau stabilized. Analysts expect earnings to grow 10% in 2017, which would be the first annual increase since 2014.Argus bumped up its rating of the casino and resort company to a buy from hold on Wednesday.Las Vegas Sands opened its French-themed Parisian Macao casino report on Sept. 13, expanding its Macau footprint.Wynn Resorts rose 3.4% to 107.25, nudging above a consolidation to hit a 14-month high intraday in heavy volume.Wynn Resorts boasted solid earnings per share gains in the last two quarters, though analysts expect slim declines in the next two quarters. Revenue growth has returned, barely.Wynn opened a new multibillion-dollar Wynn Palace in Macau last month.Annual profit should climb 11% this year and accelerate to 27% in 2017.IBD'S TAKE: Some stocks are clearing buy points amid Wednesday's solid gains. But the market rally is under pressure. New buys are risky in the current market environment. For more guidance on the market direction, read the Stock Market Today or take a free trial to read The Big Picture.MGM Resorts is the least Macau-centric of the big three casinos, though it's certainly benefiting from improving demand there. MGM earnings shot up 76% in the second quarter. EPS is forecast to fall in Q3 but then skyrocket in Q4.MGM shares climbed 1.45% to 25.22, an area that's been a resistance level recently.In a strong market uptrend, MGM would be at or near a proper buy point. But with the rally under pressure, despite Wednesday's solid gains, investors should be cautious about taking action. You may want to keep this stock on a watchlist.Among other casino stocks, Hong Kong-based Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) is trying to build the right side of a base. Gaming equipment maker International Game Technology (IGT) is well extended from a late July breakout.RELATED:Macau Gambling Revenues Revive, Lift Las Vegas Sands, Wynn, MGM

Macau gaming revenue rose last month for the first time in over two years sending shares of Las Vegas Sands (LVS), MGM Resorts (MGM) and other casino stocks up Thursday.Gambling revenue grew 1.1% to $2.4 billion in China's only legal gambling district in August, the first increase since May 2014, when revenues fell on slowing economic growth in China. Analysts' Macau gaming forecasts had ranged from a drop of 3% to an increase of 1%.Meanwhile, a strong Chinese manufacturing report is good news for China's economy -- and perhaps Macau's casinos.Las Vegas Sands shares jumped 7.2 to 53.81% in heavy volume on the stock market today, hitting their best levels since late April and back above a 51.33 buy point. Sands recently cleared that entry level from a cup-with-handle base, but had pulled back in recent sessions. Wynn Resorts (WYNN) shares climbed 4.3% to 93.17. Wynn is in a base but still below its 50-day moving average. MGM, less reliant on Macau than Sands or Wynn, advanced 3.2% to 24.65, closing in on a buy point of 25.10 after finding support at the 50-day at the end of August.Still, the Leisure-Gaming and Equipment group is ranked 129 out of IBD's 197 industries. Big winners tends to come from leading groups.IBD'S TAKE: The increase in gambling is good news for casinos but recent moves by Macau's government could hamper growth. Wynn just opened its newest multibillion-dollar casino, the Wynn Palace in the trendy Cotai Strip, on Aug. 22 and Las Vegas Sands will open its French-themed Parisian Macao, on Sept. 13.Shares of Hong Kong based Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) climbed 7.4% to 13.94, but are still in a long downturn.RELATED:Las Vegas Sands, Ciena, Ollie's Hit Buy Points

Las Vegas Sands (LVS) led four notable stocks breaking out of bullish consolidations, clearing proper buy points Thursday despite a sluggish overall market.Las Vegas Sands shares climbed 7.7% to 53.81 on the stock market today, jumping back above its 51.33 buy point. The stock had cleared that buy point from a cup-with-handle base, but had pulled back in recent trading sessions.Meanwhile, MGM Resorts (MGM) finished trading up 3.2% to 24.65, close to its buy point of 25.10, rising 3.4% intraday to 24.70.Casino stocks were up overall Thursday as Macau gambling revenue grew 1.1% to $2.4 billion in August, the first increase for China's gambling district since May 2014.Ciena (CIEN) shares soared 8% to 23.17, retaking a 21.97 buy point from a cup base after the fiber-optic company reported better-than-expected fiscal third-quarter earnings Thursday. But sales were under analyst views. Fiber-optic stocks have soared amid strong demand from telecom and internet giants in the U.S. and China.IBD'S TAKE:  Ciena is part of the Telecom-Fiber Optics group, ranked No. 1 out of 197 industries. Check out this week's Industry Snapshot on what's driving the fiber optic boom. Ollie's Bargain Outlet (OLLI) shares leapt 8.8% to 27.66, back above a 26.65 buy point and its 50-day moving average on Thursday. RBC Capital raised its price target on the closeout retailer to 32 from 30 after Ollie's late Wednesday topped analyst estimates for Q2 and raised its guidance.The memory chip technology firm rose 4.2% to 14.40, moving just above a 14.27 buy point and hitting a 14-month high of 14.42 intraday. Roth Capital started coverage of Rambus (RMBS) with a buy rating an price target of 16.

The major market indexes were mixed heading into the last half hour of Thursday's session, as automakers and discount retailers fell, but casinos soared.The Nasdaq held a fractional gain, while the S&P 500 fell 0.2% and the Dow Jones industrial average lost 0.1%. Shares of the Hong Kong-based casino operator are still below their 200-day line and 28% off a 52-week high.Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and MGM Resorts (MGM) gained 4.5% and 3.4%, respectively, in above-average volume. Wynn has been working on a shallow consolidation since mid-June, while MGM is nearing a 25.10 buy point of a cup with handle.RELATED:Truck Sales Hit Brakes As Ford, General Motors Aug. The data center gear maker reported better-than-expected earnings and revenue in July, but some analysts remained concerned over the growth of its new products.Shares closed up 0.9% at 117.94.RELATED:F5 Networks Earnings, Sales Edge Views, But Credit Suisse DowngradesLastly, Exane BNP Paribas downgraded the drugmaker to neutral from outperform.Shares added 1.1% to 33.11.

After enduring Macau's worst slump ever, casinos in the world's top casino gambling destination -- including Las Vegas Sands (LVS), Wynn Resorts (WYNN), MGM Resorts (MGM) and Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) -- could collectively break even in August for the first time in more than two years.Las Vegas Sands stock is already in a buy zone, while Wynn Resorts and MGM are near proper buy zones.Wells Fargo analyst Cameron McKnight said in a report Monday that, based on checks on casinos there through Aug. 14, he estimates total Macau gaming revenue for August will be flat to down 2% on a year-over-year basis. That's better than the consensus of analysts who cover Macau casinos and have called for a 3%-4% drop. By comparison Macau revenue fell 48.6% in February 2015 vs. a year earlier, amid crackdowns on money laundering and smoking. If the upper end of McKnight's forecast is correct, it would be the first month since May 2014 that Macau's gambling revenue hasn't shrunk on a year-over-year basis. Casino stocks have rallied in recent months, as analysts and company executives also forecast the recession in Macau could be nearing an end.Las Vegas Sands CEO Sheldon Adelson said last month that he sees "signs of stabilization" in Macau.McKnight is keeping cautious, however. "We remain on the sidelines on the Macau gaming names as estimates and valuations adjust to a 'new normal' of (1) a weak Chinese economy, and (2) a recovery that is likely to be flatter than prior rebounds, contributing to more muted revenue growth in Macau."McKnight has market perform (neutral) ratings on Sands, Melco Crown and Wynn. He has an outperform (buy) rating on MGM Resorts, which is huge in Las Vegas and less exposed to Macau than its peers.IBD'S TAKE: Wynn Resorts and Las Vegas Sands are near buy points, and a new report suggests August could be the best month for Macau in years. However, recent moves by Macau's government could put a lid on growth.Timing could be right for new casinos in Macau. Wynn will open its newest multibillion-dollar casino -- Wynn Palace in the trendy Cotai Strip area of Macau -- on Aug. 22. Meanwhile, Sands is slated to open the doors to its newest resort, the French-themed Parisian Macao, on Sept. 13.Sands, the world's largest casino company by revenue, broke out of a bullish consolidation with a 51.33 buy point last week. Shares ended trading Monday up 1.5% to 52.56 on the stock market today.Wynn advanced 4% to 103.74, closing in on a 105.01 buy point. MGM Resorts, which has a 25.39 entry area above a two-year high, rose 1.4% to 24.84.Melco Crown advanced 5.2% to 15.52. Melco is not near a buy point, but it did rise above its 200-day line Monday.Red Rock Resorts (RRR), a Las Vegas-based casino company that caters exclusively to Las Vegas and Southern California locals, dipped 0.5% to 21.91, rising from an April IPO price of 19.50. Red Rock is scheduled to report Q2 earnings after the market close Monday.

Wynn Resorts (WYNN), Las Vegas Sands (LVS), MGM Resorts (MGM), Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) and other Macau-centric casino operators are seeing signs that the recession there may be nearing an end.Wynn Resorts is among those in the group opening new multi-billion-dollar casinos to welcome back tourists and high roller "VIP" gamblers when the expected upturn comes. July year-over-year gross gambling revenue for Macau was down 4.5% to $2.22 billion, slowing from an 8.5% drop in June and a 9.6% decline in June. But Macau officials told Steve Wynn that his new $4.2 billion Wynn Palace resort, scheduled to open by end of the year, will get 150 gaming tables. That's a little more than a third of the number he asked for. The Macau government also set a limit of 1,145 gaming machines for the casino.Wynn Resorts is "satisfied" with the table allocation, spokesman Michael Weaver told Bloomberg in an e-mail statement Friday.Lionel Leong, economy and finance secretary for Macau, said in a written statement that the government of the semi-autonomous region on China's southern coast will "strictly follow" the principle of allowing a compound annual growth rate of no more than 3% for new tables at casinos until Jan. 1, 2023, a limit meant to prevent overbuilding.IBD'S TAKE: Wynn Resorts has formed a couple of cup bases this year but has failed to break out amid continuing recession in Macau. Investors are expecting a rebound. To see a group that's already outperforming the market, check out this take on the software industry.Wynn Resorts stock plunged from an all-time high at 249.31 in early March 2014 to a 49.95 bottom on Jan. 14 of this year, when it turned up. It's up about 100% since then and has formed a short cup-with-handle base with a 105.01 buy point. Shares fell 2.8% to 99.75 in the stock market today.Las Vegas Sands, world's largest casino company, has also placed an application for new gaming tables for its $2.7 billion, 3,000-room Macau Parisian resort, slated to open its doors next month. Leong said that application is under review. Sands stock lost 0.6%, closing at 51.79.MGM Resorts International, which is the top casino company in Las Vegas and is less exposed in Macau, slid 1.6% to 24.50.Hong Kong-based Melco Crown's U.S. shares fell 0.3% to 14.75.

Macau's total gambling revenue was down 4.5% in July vs. the same month a year earlier, dipping to about $2.22 billion from $2.33 billion in July 2015,the smallest decline in five months.But shares of Macau-centric casino companies such as Las Vegas Sands (LVS), Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL), along with MGM Resorts International (MGM), all retreated in early trading on the stock market today.Investors had already priced in better news. Las Vegas Sands last week reported weaker-than-expected Q2 earnings, but CEO Sheldon Adelson said he sees "signs of stabilization" in Macau. That news sent Sands' stock up 6% last Wednesday. Wynn Resorts rallied after its Macau chief touted a "return of some of the higher-end premium mass players." Some analysts say the July report from Macau's Gaming Inspection and Coordination Bureau indicates the long recession in the world's top casino gambling spot may be bottoming, and its economy may be poised for growth again.Wells Fargo analyst Cameron McKnight said in a report Monday that he is still cautious on Macau, but "July revenues (were) up in seasonally adjusted terms. July revenues were up 12% vs. June. This was above the trailing five-year average growth rate of around 4%-5% month-over-month for July -- suggesting revenues were up in seasonally adjusted terms."McKnight maintained his market perform (neutral) rating on Las Vegas Sands, Wynn and MGM Resorts.IBD'S TAKE: Las Vegas Sands is forming the right side of a cup base, its first base this year, with a 54.90 entry point. Sands is still in recovery mode. To see some highly rated stocks that have outperformed Sands and the market see the IBD Stock Checkup.Sands stock is up about 45% from a 2016 low of 34.88 on Jan. 20, and it has been forming its first pattern this year, a three-month-long first-stage cup base with a 54.90 buy point. Sands fell 0.8% to 50.24 Monday. It has a 57 IBD Composite Rating, meaning it's outperformed 57% of all stocks on key metrics in recent quarters.Las Vegas Sands and Wynn Resorts are set to open new Macau casino resorts soon.Wynn Resorts and MGM both lost 2 cents, to 97.93 and 23.96, respectively. Melco Crown Entertainment fell 0.8% to 13.85.

Red Rock Resorts (RRR), which launched its initial public offering just three months ago, may be holding a winning hand as the Las Vegas economy improves.The parent of Station Casinos, Red Rock owns and operates nine large casino resorts and 10 smaller casinos in the Las Vegas regional market. It also collects management fees for operating casinos owned by Native American tribes.The Las Vegas-based company distinguishes itself from nearby global giants such as Las Vegas Sands (LVS), Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and MGM Resorts International (MGM) by mainly catering to Las Vegas residents and people who drive in from Los Angeles and other Southern California cities."(Red Rock) is the dominant operator of assets in the Las Vegas locals market and it's the most direct play on Las Vegas growth in our universe," Wells Fargo analyst Cameron McKnight wrote in a recent note to clients. McKnight initiated coverage on Red Rock on May 23 with an outperform rating and a 21-24 target price range.Red Rock was founded by Frank Fertitta Jr. in 1976 under the name Station Casinos, went public in 1993 and was taken private again in 2007.Fertitta died in 2009. His son Frank III, now chairman and chief executive, took it public again under the name Red Rock Resorts in April, selling 27 million shares and raising $531 million.Recent history suggests Frank III has a golden touch. He and his brother Lorenzo recently sold Ultimate Fighting Championship, the most successful mixed martial arts franchise, for $4 billion to a group led by talent agency WME-IMG, a record for a sports franchise. It was all the more impressive when you consider the brothers picked up UFC for a mere $2 million in 2001, when it was on the ropes and nearly bankrupt.Red Rock competes directly with regional casino companies like Boyd Gaming (BYD) in Las Vegas and soon with Eldorado Resorts (ERI), based in Reno, Nev.IBD'S TAKE: Red Rock Resorts launched its IPO in late April and has risen a decent 18% since then. The stock has been basing bullishly for the past five weeks. Check out Pattern Recognition on MarketSmith to see the proper buy point.According to Union Gaming analyst John DeCree, Red Rock is planning to build its first Reno casino."They have filed some permits and are prepping some land in Reno for a small $70 million development there," DeCree told IBD.The casino company also is growing via acquisitions. On May 10, Red Rock announced it agreed to buy Palms Casino Resort in Las Vegas for $312.5 million cash."As a hybrid property that appeals to both Las Vegas residents and tourists alike, the Palms is uniquely positioned to benefit from the strong economic trends in southern Nevada as well as record visitation and visitor spending in Las Vegas," Red Rock Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer Marc Falcone told analysts on the company's first-quarter earnings call on May 12.Tourist visits to Las Vegas in the first quarter reached a record 10.5 million, and convention attendance jumped nearly 15% vs. a year earlier. Based on public announcements, more than $13 billion in projects are in the works in Las Vegas. Nevada's total "gaming win" of $887 million for June was a 6.8% increase vs. June 2015.Red Rock began trading on April 27 after pricing at 19.50 a share. It's risen about 17% in the intervening three months. The stock holds an 89 IBD Composite Rating, meaning it's outperformed 89% of all stocks on key metrics such as sales and profit growth. Shares ended trading Monday down 1.6% to 22.65.Union Gaming's DeCree said that Frank Fertitta III, with 35 years casino industry experience, and Lorenzo Fertitta with 21 years, are capable leaders."They have been at the helm quite a while. They're experts at that business and they are also very familiar with the local market," he said.

Matt Murphy, a managing director at venture capital firm Menlo Ventures, sees something happening in Silicon Valley that he hasn't seen in a very long time."There are more amazing private companies now than I can remember in my 17-year career in venture capital," said Murphy. "There are more potential IPOs today than I can remember since 1999."This ain't no 1999, for good and bad. The dot-com bubble sparked a near-record 486 initial public offerings in 1999. Early this year, IPO offerings hit a seven-year low. The lessons of the dot-com bust and Great Recession remain fresh, and the weak global economy has fueled caution.But the window has cracked open to show some of Murphy's buoyant view. Several stocks have made strong debuts, and several analysts say the enthusiastic welcome should lure more companies off the fence and into the public market in the second half.Eyes opened when cloud software provider Twilio (TWLO) popped 92% on its first day of trading June 23. The stock priced at 15, finished day one near 29 and was up 0.9% Monday at 41.85. The IPO raised $150 million."Twilio broke the logjam," said Murphy.Acacia Communications (ACIA) (up 35% on its first trading day), Japan-based Line (LN) (up 27%) and software company Talend (TLND) (up 42%) are the other IPO highlights of a soft year.Two IPOs this past week got early bounces. At Home Group (HOME) priced at 15 and opened Thursday at 16.26. It raised $130 million. First Hawaiian Bank (FHB) priced at 23 and opened at 24.20. It raised $485 million. First Hawaiian is the largest U.S. bank IPO since Citizens Financial Group (CFG) in September 2014. At Home, a home decor retailer with 115 large-format stores, is the first retail chain IPO since Ollie's Bargain Outlet (OLLI) in July 2015.IBD'S TAKE: Acacia Communications, Twilio and U.S. Foods report quarterly earnings for the first time as public companies this week. For earnings estimates on these and other top-rated companies, check out IBD's weekly Investing Action Plan.Spotify, the online music service, is perhaps the biggest name that could be next up to the plate.An IPO, when a company sells its shares to the public for the first time, is a rite of passage for startups and an economic engine. Yet some of the biggest startups, like ride-hailing firm Uber, are happy to put off making IPOs. Uber has raised so much cash it doesn't need an IPO infusion and can avoid the scrutiny that comes with being publicly traded, while waiting for stronger economic conditions.But IPOs often provide the funding fuel that young companies use to grow into multibillion-dollar businesses that innovate and create jobs. Apple (AAPL), Amazon (AMZN) and Facebook (FB) were once tiny outfits that ballooned after their successful IPOs.IPOs also bring big gains to VC firms and other early investors, allowing them to invest in the next star companies.But since the dot-com bust, more companies taking the plunge must show strong sales growth. They also need to show either earnings or a quick road to earnings.Even when those requirements are met, uncertainties in the global economy can weigh on the new-issue market, cooling investors' appetite for riskier investments. Brexit and potential interest rate hikes are just two of the factors fueling doubts this year.The 56 IPOs on U.S. stock exchanges in 2016 are 56% fewer than in the year-earlier period, and the $9.6 billion raised is down 57%, says Renaissance Capital, which manages two IPO-focused exchange traded funds.Q1 marked the slowest quarter for IPOs in seven years. A mere eight, all in the health care field, raised just $700,000 combined.Q2 brought 33 IPOs, raising $5.5 billion. That's still far below average, but it sparked hopes for an IPO rebound. This year's average return for IPOs is about 17% above the IPO price. This is a big turnaround from the IPO class of 2015, which is down 11%, says Renaissance."That 17% return is very strong, and it's even higher if you take out small IPOs," said Kathleen Smith, a principal at Renaissance and manager of its IPO-focused ETFs. "When the IPO market shuts down for long droughts, the market revives when we see a strong rate of return."Twilio helped, as the first "unicorn" to make an IPO this year. Unicorn is the nickname for privately held companies valued above $1 billion. Twilio now has a market valuation of $3.4 billion.Venture capitalists count more than 150 unicorns in the U.S.There have been a few other biggies.Acacia came public on May 13 at 23 and has rallied sharply since, rising nearly 2% Monday to 65.24. Acacia makes high-speed fiber-optic communications gear.Line priced at 32.75 on July 14 and its shares edged up 0.6% Monday to 39.88. The mobile messaging service raised $1.1 billion, making it the largest tech IPO since Chinese e-commerce giant Alibaba (BABA) roared onto the scene in September 2014, raising $25 billion in history's biggest IPO ever.The IPO market is always on a short leash. Even after a company files for an IPO with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission, the offering doesn't really start to take shape until execs begin a road show to make their formal pitches to institutional investors.How big is the current pipeline of potential IPOs? At first glance, the numbers underwhelm.Just five companies are on a road show now, four biotechs and a provider of wireless networking technology.Four IPOs are scheduled to begin the week of Aug. 8, led by Medpace Holdings. It looks to raise $151 million by offering 7 million shares at a price range of 20 to 23. Medpace provides clinical development services to the biotech field. Displaying characteristics of a good IPO, Medpace is profitable, with revenue growing at a double-digit clip. In the first half of this year, Medpace reports revenue of $205.5 million, up 20%, and net income of $8.4 million. It's scheduled to begin trading Thursday under the ticker MEDP.But the IPO market typically slumbers in August.There are 101 companies in public registration for an IPO, down from 118 at the start of the year.But the decline in registrations doesn't change VC Murphy's outlook."We think the second half will have significantly more IPOs than the first half, and expect substantially more IPOs in the next 12 months compared with the previous year," he said.Murphy says the number of Silicon Valley startups with annual revenue of $50 million to $100 million could be near an all-time high, providing a fertile field of potential IPOs.But whether the successful offerings of Twilio, Acacia, Line and Talend will spark more IPOs is impossible to say. Big-name unicorns Uber, Snapchat, Airbnb and Pinterest are making no IPO noises yet.Renaissance Capital's Smith expects a pickup this year. But she doesn't see 2016 matching the 170 IPOs and $30 billion raised in 2015, which itself was down from the two preceding big IPO years.IPO optimism can fade fast if the economy slumps."The enemy of a healthy IPO market is uncertainty and volatility," said Garvis Toler, global head of capital markets at the New York Stock Exchange. "We've had some high volatility in the past year, but that's moderated back down to normal levels."The IPO window is ready to open, "it's just a matter of when," he said. "People need to perceive that it's a hospitable environment."Some firms indeed have perceived the climate is right.Two consumer IPOs each raised more than $1 billion in Q2. MGM Growth Properties (MGP), a real estate investment trust spun out of MGM Resorts (MGM), raised $1.05 billion. It priced at 21 in April and was up 1.5% Monday at 26.92.The other was food distributor U.S. Foods (USFD), which raised $1.02 billion. It priced at 23 in late May but is edging closer to that level, trading Monday at 23.62.The first high-profile unicorn that might come public this year is music service Spotify, which has a market valuation of about $8 billion.Another possible brand-name IPO is Jose Cuervo, the world's largest tequila producer, with an estimated market value of $3 billion.Univision Holdings, the largest Spanish-language broadcaster in the U.S., is another possible IPO this year, observers say. It could raise as much as $1 billion. The company was taken private in 2007 in a $12.3 billion leveraged buyout by a group of investors led by Saban Capital Group.Univision postponed plans to make its IPO last year while it waited for more attractive market conditions. That's also true of grocery store chain Albertsons and retailer Neiman Marcus.They might be waiting awhile, says Greg Brogger, CEO of Sharespost. He doesn't expect a big IPO rebound this year. Sharespost connects buyers and sellers of shares in privately held companies and manages the Sharespost 100 Fund, a mutual fund that invests in late-stage, VC-backed companies."I don't hear anyone thinking there will be a stampede, even if an IPO window opens," Brogger said. He says companies will continue to stay private as long as they can, in part to avoid the scrutiny that comes with being public."The public market is not always a friendly place to be," he said. "The strong private companies will stay private because they can" as long as they are able to get funding."I think a shift has happened," Brogger said. "Companies want to stay private longer and get larger, with more predictable earnings, before coming public."

Gilead Sciences (GILD), Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and Texas Instruments (TXN) report quarterly results after the close Monday.Estimates: Analysts expect Gilead, the maker of hepatitis drugs Sovaldi and Harvoni and the HIV drug Truvada, to report second-quarter earnings per share down 4% to $3.02, with sales falling 6% to $7.768 billion.Results: Gilead earned $3.08 a share excluding items. Revenue was $7.776 billion. Both topped views but it was the first quarterly sales and earnings decline in years. Gilead's hepatitis C businesses has slowed, but the company has put more focus on potentially treating hepatitis B.HCV drug sales were $4 billion vs. $4.9 billion a year earlier. Gilead blamed weaker Harvoni sales. HIV and other antiviral drug sales rose to $3.1 billion from $2.7 billion. Gilead cut full-year net product sales forecasts.Gilead is the first of 5 big drugmakers reporting this week.Shares fell 4% in after-hours trading. Gilead closed up 2.3% to 83.55 in the stock market today.IBD'S TAKE: The iShares biotech ETF IBB is close to breaking a downturn. It's meeting resistance near 286-288. Getting above those levels would also push IBB over its 200-day moving average for the first time in 10 months.Estimates: Wall Street expects the casino operator's second-quarter EPS to slip 7% to 56 cents, with revenue falling 6% to $2.756 billion.Results: Las Vegas Sands earned 52 cents a share adjusted. Revenue was $2.65 billion.Las Vegas Sands, like rivals MGM Resorts International (MGM) and Wynn Resorts (WYNN), has struggled in the Macau region, a global casino hub in China that has been hurt by a weaker economy and a crackdown on money laundering and other corruption. MGM will report earnings on Aug. 4."The operating environment in Macao remained challenging during the quarter; but we do see signs of stabilization, particularly in the mass market," Las Vegas Sands CEO Sheldon Adelson said in a statement. He expects strong June activity to continue.Las Vegas Sands rose more than 4% in after-hours action, despite missing EPS and revenue views, on those Macau "stabilization" signs. Sands stock climbed 1% to 47.80 at the close.MGM Resorts and Wynn Resorts also rose late after climbing during the regular session.Estimates: Second-quarter EPS of 72 cents, up 10%, on revenue of $3.2 billion, down around 1%.Results: Texas Instruments earned 76 cents a share on revenue of $3.273 billion.TI sees Q3 EPS of 81-91 cents on revenue of $3.34 billion-$3.62 billion. Analysts have expected 81 cents and sales of $3.38 billion.Texas Instruments cited strong demand for chips used in cars.Shares rose 5.5% in after-hours action. TI closed 1.1% higher at 66.22, hitting a fresh all-time high.

Las Vegas Sands (LVS), MGM Resorts International (MGM), Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and other Macau-centric casinos aren't out of the woods yet.Gambling revenue for Macau, the world's top casino destination, fell in June. That marks the 25th month in a row revenue has fallen, despite earlier signs that the recession there may be nearing an end.Macau officials said total gambling revenue for the special administrative district on China's southern coast fell 8.5% in June vs. the same month a year ago to about $2 billion, worse than the 6.6% drop that many analysts expected. Shares of Las Vegas Sands closed up 0.5% at 43.71 in the stock market today. Sands dropped to a 3-1/2 year low at 34.88 on Jan. 20 of this year and then turned up on glimmers of possible recovery in Macau, where it and other Las Vegas Casinos operate multi-billion-dollar casino resorts. As of Friday midday it was up about 26% from that low point.MGM rose 0.7%, while Wynn Resorts climbed 1.3%. Hong Kong-based Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) added 2.5%.Wells Fargo analyst Cameron McKnight said Macau's June revenue was 14% lower than May, two percentage points below the average 12% drop from May to June. He forecasts that Macau gambling revenue will decline 8%-10% in July vs. a year earlier, worse than consensus for a milder 5.8% drop.With Macau-centric casino stocks up 2% so far this year, "we believe many investors are taking the view that Macau revenues have stabilized, vs. our view that additional regulation and new supply could weigh on (second-half) results," McKnight said.Macau went into recession a little more than two years ago amid weakening economic growth in China and the imposition of tough regulations by the Chinese government as part of a nationwide crackdown on corruption.The rate of revenue decline slowed earlier this year from the 20%-plus year-over-year drops seen in the early part of the recession, leading some market watchers to say the worst may be over in Macau. McKnight says that may be a bit premature.Wynn and Sands have confirmed plans to open new casinos in Macau in the third quarter. Wynn Palace is expected to open on Aug. 22 and Sands' Parisian in mid-September. That will boost the number of casinos and gaming lounges in Macau to nearly 50, according to the World Casino Directory, at a time when fewer tourists and high rollers are visiting the region.McKnight noted that, according to the Supreme People's Court in China, bankruptcies soared 52.5% in first quarter 2016 vs. the same quarter a year ago, to 1,028. That's 44% higher than the average quarterly case total over the past seven years amid weakened economic growth in China.Additionally, reports last week suggested that China's central bank is considering allowing a fall in the yuan to as low as 6.8 per dollar."We note that a weaker Chinese currency would reduce mainland gamblers' purchasing power in Macau given the MOP (Macau currency) is pegged to the dollar, not the yuan," McKnight said.

Following a Q1 that was the slowest quarter for initial public offerings in seven years, activity picked up in Q2, with 33 IPOs raising $5.5 billion.The second quarter was still well below average, but the returns were good, reports Renaissance Capital, which manages two IPO-focused exchange traded funds.The latest quarterly report from Renaissance said technology and consumer IPOs re-emerged, led by a highly successful debut from venture-capital-backed Twilio (TWLO), the first "unicorn" to complete an IPO in 2016. Unicorn is the designation given to companies with premarket valuations above $1 billion, and Twilio, a cloud-based communications company, was valued just above $1 billion.Health care IPOs have maintained their lead this year in the deal count. In Q2, the health care group had 14 IPOs, but half of those were among the worst-performing. There were four IPOs in the tech sector, compared with none in Q1.Twilio priced at 15 and popped 92% on its first trading day, June 23. Twilio stock finished 1.6% lower at 36.50 in the stock market today. But earlier Thursday, Twilio rose as high as 41.89, a record high for its short public life.Another big tech winner was Acacia Communications (ACIA), which priced at 23. Acacia stock rose 5.5% to 39.94 Thursday. Acacia technology is used for high-speed fiber optic communications gear."Even with the aftermath of the Brexit vote and elevated volatility, we expect IPO activity to maintain its current pace or modestly improve for the balance of 2016, supported by a full pipeline, news of more tech companies and LBOs (leveraged buyouts) readying their IPOs, and the string of recent IPOs that have delivered double-digit returns," Renaissance said in its report.The largest IPO in Q2 was MGM Growth Properties (MGP), a real estate investment trust spun out of MGM Resorts (MGM). MGM Growth Properties raised $1.05 billion. The stock priced at 21 in April and is now trading near 26.50.The 33 IPOs in Q2 compared with eight in Q1, and the $5.5 billion in proceeds raised dwarfed the $700 million in Q1. The average IPO gained 9.9% in Q2, and 56% of deals ended June above the offer price, outperforming the S&P 500's 1% decline.

Las Vegas officially has its first professional sports team after the National Hockey League decided to gamble on Vegas. On Thursday, the league's board of governors unanimously approved the 31st NHL team.Las Vegas Sands (LVS) CEO Sheldon Adelson immediately said he  wants to up the ante and bring a pro football team to the city as well.Getting the NHL team is expected to boost revenue and profits for Las Vegas Sands, MGM Resorts International (MGM), Wynn Resorts (WYNN), Caesars Entertainment (CZR) and other casino resorts there.The new hockey team will begin playing at the at T-Mobile Arena, which has a hockey seating capacity of 17,500 in 2017. It means more people staying at their hotels, attending other entertainment events, eating at casino restaurants, shopping at their stores and gambling in their casinos.Wells Fargo analyst Cameron McKnight said in a report that the new Las Vegas NHL team will increase the number of events held at the arena by 30% to 35% a year, "potentially driving up to 600,000 new visitors to the arena." McKnight didn't speculate on how much money it could bring to the city.For Vegas casinos, it could help offset ongoing losses in Macau, the world's top casino gambling destination, on China's southern coast. Macau has been in recession for two years and Vegas casinos, which own the bulk of properties in Macau, have seen their revenue and profits there shrink.Las Vegas has tried in vain for years to get a pro sports team but met with resistance from sports leagues that didn't want to tie pro sports to gambling.Geoff Freeman, president of the American Gaming Association, said in a commentary in CDC Gaming Reports that the NHL team could open the door to other sports teams in Las Vegas and change people's perceptions regarding professional sports and gambling."Most significantly, by breaking the Las Vegas dam, the NHL is pouring cold water on the argument that regulated sports betting harms the integrity of sports -- and boosting efforts to legalize sports betting across the country," Freeman said.Shares of Sands, the world's largest casino company, fell 60% from an all-time high at 88.28 in early March 2014 to a bottom at 34.88 on Jan. 20 of this year before turning up amid signs the recession in Macau may be nearing an end. Las Vegas Sands rose 2.7% at 46.16 on the stock market today.Wynn Resorts rose 1%, MGM Resorts was up 0.7% and Caesars gained 3.5%.Meanwhile, Adelson's Sands has partnered with Majestic Realty Co. and others in a consortium that proposes to build a $1 billion 65,000-seat domed stadium for a National Football League team, various reports said.Representatives of the consortium were slated to meet with a committee of government leaders on Thursday to review the plan. The Oakland Raiders have been reported looking for a new city to play in, and could be among teams courted by Las Vegas if the deal goes through.

Berkshire Hathaway (BRKB) head Warren Buffett, Facebook (FB) COO Sheryl Sandberg and Alphabet (GOOGL) Executive Chairman Eric Schmidt were among the dozens of business leaders announcing Thursday their endorsement for Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton."Trump would destroy much of what is great about America," said Netflix (NFLX) CEO Reed Hastings in a statement released by the Clinton camp that includes the full list of endorsements. "Hillary Clinton is the strong leader we need, and it's important that Trump lose by a landslide to reject what he stands for."Also on the list are Delta Air Lines (DAL) Executive Chairman Richard Anderson, Salesforce (CRM) CEO Marc Benioff, Sunrun (RUN) CEO Lynn Jurich and Qualcomm (QCOM) Executive Chairman Paul Jacobs.Some are switching party allegiances to vote for Clinton, including General Motors' (GM) former chairman and CEO Dan Akerson and AT&T (T) Services senior executive vice president Jim Cicconi."Serving as the leader of the free world requires effective leadership, sound judgment, a steady hand and most importantly, the temperament to deal with crises large and small," said Akerson in the statement, who has "consistently" voted for Republicans for president. "Donald Trump lacks each of these characteristics. Hillary Clinton has the experience and judgment to serve as an effective commander in chief. In this election, I will cast my ballot for Secretary Clinton."Meanwhile, Continental Resources (CLR) CEO Harold Hamm, Home Depot (HD) co-founder Bernard Marcus and Facebook board member and PayPal co-founder Peter Thiel are among those in the business world supporting Donald Trump's run for presidency.The full list of those announcing Clinton endorsements, as published on her campaign site, is as follows:

Las Vegas and Macau may be the top two locations that pop into most folks' minds when they think about gambling destinations. But Eldorado Resorts (ERI) has been expanding its reach since its humble beginning in 1973 with Eldorado Reno, which featured 282 guest rooms and a 10,000-square-foot gaming floor. By 1995, the casino had grown to include more than…

Gaming revenue from Macau this month could see its first annual growth in two years, an analyst said, potentially providing some relief for Las Vegas Sands (LVS), MGM Resorts International (MGM), Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and Hong Kong-based Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL).Union Gaming analyst Grant Govertsen said in a report that the worst is nearly over in Macau, and that June gross gambling revenue (GGR) could be in line with the daily rate of around $72.46 million that's been reported in recent non-holiday months."This would result in total GGR of $2.2 billion and would represent the first year-over-year increase in GGR after 24 months of declines," Govertsen said.Govertsen expects Macau's gambling revenue in July and August to see mid-single-digit declines before returning to growth in September."We feel better about fall GGR trends generally staying in the black simply because the two properties likely to come online in this period -- Wynn Palace and Parisian Macao” -- have potential to drive further growth, he said.Shares of Las Vegas Sands, the world's largest casino company, closed up 0.3% in the stock market today. MGM Resorts rallied 2.5% to 23.42, near a 23.44 buy point, and Wynn Resorts rose 0.6% as it forms a cup base with a 102.54 buy point. Melco Crown fell 1%.Wells Fargo analyst Cameron McKnight said in a note to clients that he remains on the sidelines on Macau gaming names, as the region "adjusts to a 'new normal' of (1) a weak Chinese economy, and (2) a recovery that is likely to be flatter than prior rebounds."McKnight forecasts a 1%-7% decline for June vs. a year ago, with the midpoint a bit better than analyst consensus for a 3.7% drop.But May was a "really tough calendar comp" that saw two fewer weekend days for the month compared to a year earlier, Govertsen noted.Macau's Gaming Inspection and Coordination Bureau reported 18.39 billion Macau patacas ($2.3 billion) gambling revenue from all casinos for the month, down 9.6% from a year before. It was worse than expectations for an 8% drop, as well as lagging April's 9.5% decline.

Moody's Investors Service downgraded Macau's credit rating as a deep recession in China's gambling hotspot drags on, which could impact Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and other Macau-centric casino companies.Sands, MGM Resorts International (MGM), Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and Hong Kong-based Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) are among the top Macau-centric casino companies. But shares of all four rose Wednesday amid broad stock market gains.Moody's lowered Macau by one grade to Aa3, three notches below its highest rating, and assigned a negative outlook, saying it expects the economic contraction in the special administrative region on China's southern coast to continue this year and into 2017.In a written statement, the ratings agency said in part, "Our expectation of a decrease in gaming revenues this year and next suggests that Macao's economic, fiscal and external metrics will likely weaken considerably from prior robust trends."The city's monetary authority responded, saying in part, "Macao’s economic and financial conditions are fundamentally sound," and prospects are "supported by its solid external financial position, credible policy framework and reliable linked exchange-rate system."Las Vegas Sands, the world's biggest casino company, saw its share price tumble 60% to a 34.88 intraday low on Jan. 20 of this year when it turned up. It's risen about 32% since then.But Sands shares rose 1.65% to 46.30 in the stock market today. Las Vegas Sands also announced plans to build a Vegas music venue with Madison Square Garden (MSG).MGM Resorts International rose 0.6%. Wynn Resorts, which has been forming a flat base for about a month, was up 3.7%. Melco Crown Entertainment climbed 0.9%.

Under Armour (UA) shares are down late on slashed guidance, and Alibaba (BABA) sold off after SoftBank (SFTBY) cut its stake, TiVo (TIVO), Zoe's Kitchen (ZOES) and Workday (WDAY) all reported after the close Tuesday. Staples (SPLS) announced its CEO was leaving.The Nike (NKE) rival said it now expects $4.925 billion in revenue for 2016, down from prior guidance for $5 billion, as a result of Sports Authority's recent bankruptcy filing."Given the recent decision of the bankruptcy court to approve the liquidation of the Sports Authority's business rather than a restructuring or sale of the ongoing business, the company now expects to recognize an impairment charge of approximately $23 million related to the Sports Authority during the second quarter of 2016," said Under Armour in a statement.Under Armour said it still sees "high 20s percent range" sales growth for Q2. Analysts are looking for 28.5% revenue gains.Shares are down 3.8% late after ending the regular session down fractionally.Japanese telecom giant SoftBank (SFTBY) will sell $7.9 billion in Alibaba shares, cutting its stake in China e-commerce leader Alibaba to 28% from 32%. Alibaba agreed to buy $2 billion in shares from SoftBank.Alibaba shares fell 2.9% in extended trade. Yahoo, which owns 15% of Alibaba, fell 1.5% in late trade. Yahoo has been trying to spin off its Alibaba holdings. Yahoo has recently soliciting bids for its core holdings as a lower-tax split from its Alibaba and Yahoo Japan assets.The DVR company, which agreed in late April to be acquired by Rovi (ROVI) in a $1.1 billion cash-and-stock deal, said subscriptions grew 24% to 7 million in its first quarter.Diluted net income per common share sank 50% to 4 cents, below views for 8 cents a share. Revenue from service and software and technology segments rose 8% to $99.7 million. The company logged total net revenue of $107.3 million, including hardware sales. Analysts had expected $99.6 million in revenue.TiVo shares fell 1.5% after hours, while Rovi was unchanged late.Workday swung to an unexpected profit in its fiscal Q1 2017, with EPS of 5 cents, compared with expectations for a 2-cent per-share loss. Revenue rose 38% to $345.4 million, topping estimates for $338.68 million.The company, which develops cloud-based solutions for the human-resources and finance sectors, expects Q2 revenue of $371 million-$373 million, above views for $370.88 million.Shares dropped 1.9%.Zoe’s Kitchen, a fast-casual chain serving Mediterranean-inspired dishes, late Tuesday reported Q1 EPS jumped to 6 cents, 2 cents better than expected.Revenue for the 16 weeks ended April 18 rose 27.6% to $80.4 million vs. the 16 weeks in Q1 2015, topping Wall Street’s $78.88 mil target. Zoe’s expects 2016 revenue of $277 million-$281 million, amid plans to add 34-36 new locations, just below consensus for $280.36 million.Shares were up 4.8% in early extended trading, after closing up 2.5% at 36.92Boyd Gaming (BYD) said it will sell 50% of its stake in Marina District Development, parent of Borgata Hotel Casino & Spa in Atlantic City, to MGM Resorts International (MGM). MGM will pay $900 million -- $600 million including debt -- as well as a 50% share of any future property tax settlement benefits from Borgata.Boyd Gaming shares rallied 4.4% late.Office supply retailer said CEO Ron Sargent will step down next month, after regulators blocked Staples attempt to buy rival Office Depot (ODP). Shira Goodman was named interim CEO.Staples edged up 0.5%.

Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and MGM Resorts International (MGM) both topped first-quarter earnings estimates Thursday, but revenue missed on Macau weakness.Wynn said late Thursday adjusted Q1 EPS jumped 53% to $1.07, easily beating the consensus estimate by 24 cents a share. Revenue slid 8.7% to $997.7 million, a bit lighter than the $998.49 million analysts anticipated.Wynn saw revenue from its Macau operations decline 13.8% to $608.2 million, which was partly offset by a 0.7% increase from its Las Vegas operations to $389.4 million. In Macau, table games turnover in the VIP segment, primarily baccarat, was $13.47 billion, a 21.4% drop from Q1 2015.But shares rose 1% in late trading, after closing down 1.8%.MGM's adjusted earnings per share dropped 64% to 12 cents compared to Q1 2015, a penny above analysts' consensus. Total revenue dropped 9% to $2.21 billion, as higher income from U.S. operations was outweighed by an 11% drop in casinos gambling revenue, mainly on a smaller take from table games in Macau.Net revenue at the company's U.S. casinos rose 3%, and room revenues for U.S. hotels climbed 7%.However, net revenue from its casinos in the Chinese gambling hotspot of Macau, which has been mired in a nearly two-year long recession, plunged 26% to $469 million. However, there have been some recent signs that Macau casino revenue woes generally are starting to ease.Nevada May Legalize Online Sports Betting In All 50 States: Here's HowMGM competes in Macau with the world's largest casino company Las Vegas Sands (LVS), as well as Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) and Wynn.During Q1, MGM completed the spinoff of its land holdings as a real estate investment trust. MGM received a total $1.6 billion cash from the $1.2 billion MGM Growth Properties IPO and a separate special distribution from the sale of The Shops at Crystals, a shopping, dining and entertainment venue at its CityCenter complex in Las Vegas.MGM also opened The Park, an outdoor pedestrian area with dining and entertainment, during the quarter, and the T-Mobile Arena, a 20,000-seat theater, both on the Las Vegas Strip.MGM shares closed up 1.9% on the stock market today. MGM has formed a cup-with-handle base with a potential 23.44 buy point.Las Vegas Sands fell 1.7%, and Melco Crown lost 2.2%.

Shares of Macau-centric casinos Las Vegas Sands (LVS), Wynn Resorts (WYNN), MGM Resorts (MGM) and Melco Crown (MPEL) were up sharply Monday on new signs the slump in the gambling mecca may be easing.The Macau Gaming Inspection and Coordination Bureau said that monthly gross gaming revenue for the world's top casino gambling destination fell 9.5% to $2.17 billion, topping some estimates.Analysts polled by Bloomberg forecast a 13.5% decline. Sterne Agee analyst David Bain was looking for something closer to a 14.2% retreat.Wells Fargo analyst Cameron McKnight had expected 11%-12% drop.Las Vegas Sands shares climbed 3.5% in the stock market today, finding resistance at their 200-day line. Shares of the world's biggest casino company skidded 9.2% on April 21 to 47.39 after it reported worse-than-expected first-quarter earnings. Wynn Resorts surged 6.8% Monday. MGM Resorts rose 1.7%, and Hong Kong-based Melco Crown climbed 3.8%.Macau's gambling revenue sank 16.3% in March, dipped 0.1% in February as the Lunar New Year provided a boost, and tumbled 21.4% in January.Some analysts and casino executives have said they see signs of recovery in Macau, which was plunged into recession as a result of weaker economic growth in China, a crackdown on corruption by the Chinese government and a partial smoking ban that caused some tourists to stay away.But McKnight said in a report Monday that the latest figures from Macau weren't that encouraging."We remain on the sidelines on the Macau gaming names as estimates and valuations adjust to a 'new normal' of (1) a weak Chinese economy and (2) a recovery that is likely to be flatter than prior rebounds, contributing to more muted revenue growth in Macau," he said.In May, he sees total Macau gambling revenue falling 7%-11% in May vs. consensus for a 7.2% drop. Sterne Agee's Bain forecasts May sales will be down 9%-12%.Bain recommended adding to holdings of Macau-centric casinos catering to "mass market" tourists and middle class gamblers, while avoiding shares of casinos catering to "VIP" high roller gamblers.

The drive to legalize online sports betting for money may get a boost this year as the Nevada Gaming Commission gets set to consider a process that would effectively legalize it nationally -- with restrictions.The proposed legislation would radically change the U.S. gambling environment and could draw the attention of casino giants such as Las Vegas Sands (LVS), MGM Resorts International (MGM) and Wynn Resorts (WYNN).They offer on-premise sports betting in their casinos and would likely participate in online gambling if it becomes widely legalized. So could smaller Las Vegas-based casino operators like Pinnacle Entertainment (PNK) and Boyd Gaming (BYD). The top casinos already offer apps for in-state online gambling in states that allow it.So far, only four states have legalized sports betting for money, whether online or in casinos: Nevada, Oregon, Delaware and Montana. But it's mainly confined to Nevada.Quinton Singleton, vice president and deputy general counsel at gaming technology company CG Technology, in February submitted a proposal to the Nevada Gaming Commission to amend the state's gambling regulations to allow betters in all 50 states to set up and fund mobile sports-betting apps. CG Technology's products include Alphabet (GOOGL)-owned Google Android- and Apple (AAPL)-compatible smartphone apps.It's not clear when the gaming commission will take up the proposal.The proposed rules would also simplify registering for online gambling, Legal Sports Report said, citing comments by Singleton. The report said the Nevada Gaming Commission could consider the proposal as early as this year.The proposed amended rules would only allow certain types of sports betting and would require a difficult registration process. Potential betters would have to complete a one-time in-person verification step at a Nevada-based sports book or casino. And betting on single game sports events would still not be permitted outside the state of Nevada.Las Vegas Sands, the world's biggest casino company, has seen its earnings-per-share growth contract for five quarters in a row amid a nearly two-year-long recession in Macau. Sands and other top casino companies operate billion-dollar-plus casino resorts in the gambling hot spot on China's southern coast. Sands shares, which have a weak IBD Composite Rating of 30 out of a best-possible 99, fell 1.2% to 44.96 in the stock market today.Wynn fell 3.4%, MGM Resorts rose fractionally, Pinnacle slid 2.6% and Boyd Gaming was up 0.3%.

Las Vegas Sands (LVS) reported a 32% drop in first-quarter earnings per share to 45 cents on a 10% decline in revenue to $2.72 billion, badly missing analyst estimates.Consensus was for EPS of 63 cents on $2.88 billion in revenue for the March 31-ended quarter.Shares sank 4.9% in after-hours trading, after closing down 0.6% in the stock market today."The operating environment in Macao remained challenging during the quarter," CEO Sheldon Adelson said in a written statement, adding "but we do see signs of stabilization."Sands competes with Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and MGM Resorts International (MGM) in Macau, as well as Hong Kong-based Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL). The gambling mecca on China's southern coast has been in recession and those companies' resorts have seen visitor numbers and gambling revenue crumble.Union Gaming analyst John DeCree said in a report Wednesday that "We continue to see signs of stability in the mass market (tourist/middle class)" in Macau. However, he cautioned that there is still risk. Recent data points to improvement but most analysts don't expect growth to return until end of this year or next year.Meanwhile, MGM priced its real estate investment trust initial public offering on Tuesday and began trading on Wednesday, a sign that the dormant IPO market may be stirring.MGM Growth Properties (MGP) priced 50,000 shares at $21 per share, at the top of its expected $18 to $21 range, raising $1.05 billion. On Wednesday, it gapped up as much as 9% before settling to a 5% gain for the day, to 22.11. MGM Resorts fell 2% to 22.30.Wynn Resorts CEO Steve Wynn is focusing on Las Vegas as he awaits recovery in Macau. Earlier this month he announced Wynn will develop what he called a "recreational lake concept" theme park in Las Vegas with hotels, a small lake with beach for water skiing, paddle boarding and parasailing, complete with nightly fireworks.

Struggling wireless carrier Sprint (S) was downgraded Wednesday while online payments leader PayPal Holdings (PYPL) and video game publisher Activision Blizzard (ATVI) got their price targets raised.Pacific Crest downgraded Sprint to underweight from sector weight as the No. 4 U.S. wireless carrier continues turnaround efforts and attempts to raise cash to remain solvent.Sprint shares fell 2% on the stock market today.SunTrust Robinson Humphrey raised its price target on PayPal to 44 from 38, with a "buy" rating, even it is seeing new competition from Amazon (AMZN), which is trying to make inroads with its own payments platform.PayPal stock rose 2.6%.Video-game publisher Activision also got its PT raised to 40 from 35 with a buy rating at Stifel Nicolaus. Shares climbed 4%.Meanwhile, on the casino front, Deutsche Bank downgraded Wynn Resorts (WYNN) to hold from buy while Citigroup maintained its buy on the company and a PT of 117. Wynn shares rallied to end up 0.5%.Citigroup maintained a buy on MGM Resorts (MGM), with a PT of 32. MGM Resorts' real estate investment trust -- MGM Growth Properties -- began marketing its planned IPO in the U.S. this week; it could reportedly raised up to $1.2 billion. MGM shares rallied 1.9%.Citigroup also maintained a buy on Las Vegas Sands (LVS), which is controlled by billionaire Sheldon Adelson. The rating came with a PT of 62. The casino company has agreed to pay $9 million to settle a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation into its expansion into gaming mecca Macau in China. Shares rose 2.9%.In other action, Harley-Davidson (HOG) got its PT cut by Wedbush to 42 from 46. The iconic motorcycle company, which is facing tough competition outside the U.S. from Japanese manufacturers, reports Q1 results on April 19. Shares added 4.3%.Image provided by Shutterstock.

Wynn Resorts (WYNN) CEO Steven Wynn bought nearly 73,000 shares of his casino company, boosting his holdings to more than 12 million shares worth about $1.194 billion.In December, Wynn disclosed the purchase of more than 1 million shares for about $63.8 million.The latest buy comes amid analyst reports that the worst may be over for Macau, the world's top casino gambling destination, as it works through its deepest recession ever. Wynn, along with other Las Vegas majors Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and MGM Resorts International (MGM), owns multibillion-dollar casino resorts in the former Portuguese colony on China's southern coastal area, across the strait from Hong Kong.After jumping 3% early, Wynn stock closed essentially flat on the stock market today. It plunged from an all-time intraday high above 249 in early March 2014, bottomed at 49.95 on Jan. 14 and then began climbing. It's shot up about 98% in the last three months. Wynn Resorts has a 58 IBD Composite Rating, which means that it's outperformed 58% of all stocks on key metrics such as sales and profit growth in recent quarters.Deutsche Bank analyst Carlo Santarelli on Wednesday downgraded Wynn to hold from buy, saying, “Macau fundamenals ... in our view are merely less bad but haven’t truly improved.” Santarelli raised his price target to 101 from 94.Macquarie Research analyst Chad Beynon said in a report last month that after doing market checks, "we've positively adjusted our Macau market estimates as well as company estimates," including maintaining an outperform rating on No. 1 global casino company Sands and raising his price target to 54 from 48.Beynon maintained a neutral rating on Wynn but with a positive bias, saying, "We believe estimates are achievable."Others are more cautious. Wells Fargo Analyst Cameron McKnight said in a report Monday that, for now, he remains on the sidelines on Macau-centric casino stocks "as estimates and valuations adjust to a 'new normal' of a weak Chinese economy and a recovery that is likely to be flatter than prior rebounds, contributing to more muted growth in Macau."Las Vegas Sands, which reports earnings next Wednesday after the market closes, declined 0.55%. Hong Kong-based Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) fell 1.9%. MGM Resorts, which is in the process of separating its real estate holdings in a real estate investment trust to unlock share value, lost 1.3%.Image provided by Shutterstock.

Wynn Resorts' (WYNN) head Steve Wynn unveiled plans for a water park next to his Las Vegas hotels, complete with a lake, mile-long white sand beach with boardwalk and a nightly fireworks display -- putting yet another twist on what hotel-casino operators will do to get an edge in America's gambling capital.In what the company referred to as a "recreational lake concept," the attraction will tentatively be called Wynn Paradise Park and is estimated to cost about $1.6 billion. The park will be constructed behind the company's two properties, the Wynn and Encore hotels, on what is now a 130-acre golf course operated by the company.In addition to the beach-front attractions, the park will offer water skiing, paddle boarding and parasailing. The nightly fireworks display will be launched from a small island in the center of the park's lake. Wynn also is planning to build a 1,000-room hotel on the site.Wynn shares gapped up 11.7%, closing at 99.99 on the stock market today. The stock dropped to an intraday low at 49.95 on Jan. 14 then turned up. In the intervening three months, it's shot up about 96%, trading above both its 10-week and 200-day lines.Wynn's plan is a new strategy for an industry that will do just about anything to attract families and visitors along with gamblers to Vegas. While other hotel-casinos have tried to attract families with everything from exotic big cats to medieval jousting to a replica of the Eiffel Tower, this is the first attempt to replicate, well, a day at the beach."We could bring beach life to Las Vegas," Wynn told investors in a call on Wednesday. "And we could charge admission to come into Paradise Park, which is what it’s going to be called, I hope."Telsey Advisory Group analyst David Katz wrote in a note Thursday that the golf course brings in about $5 million in adjusted earnings. Paradise Park, meanwhile, could bring in $300 million to $400 million, Katz wrote.Katz said he saw the project as a "shrewd move on the part of (Wynn) to unlock further value from the land." He upgraded Wynn's stock to outperform from market perform and raised its price target to 112 from 67.It's unclear how Wynn competitors -- such as MGM Resorts International (MGM), and the world's largest casino resort company Las Vegas Sands (LVS) -- will respond to this move. All three are heavily dependent on their casinos in Macau, the hot spot on China's southern coast that's become the world's top gambling destination. But Macau has been in its worst recession ever for the last year and a half, while Las Vegas continues to grow at a slow, steady pace.Las Vegas Sands owns a couple of key properties on the main Las Vegas strip, including the Venetian. MGM, meanwhile, controls many of the name-brand hotel-casinos on the strip, including the Bellagio, Excalibur, Luxor, New York-New York, and its namesake MGM Grand. It also has a 50% stake in the strip's expansive City Center complex.Shares of Las Vegas Sands edged up 0.9%. MGM Resorts rose 1.45%.Image provided by Shutterstock.

Casino giants Las Vegas Sands (LVS), Wynn Resorts (WYNN), MGM Resorts International (MGM) and Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) have all seen their shares rally in recent months on hopes Macau's recession may be coming to an end, but a rebound might take longer than some hoped.Macau's Gaming, Inspection and Coordination Bureau said Friday that gross gambling revenue for the month of March shrank 16.3% year over year to $2.25 billion.That was worse than consensus estimates early in March for a roughly 10% drop, Sterne Agee CRT said Friday, though its survey suggested a decline of 18%."We consider the result neutral to slightly negative," Sterne Agee's David Bain said in a report, adding that March's drop ended three consecutive months of increases and was below the historical month-over-month average for an 8% increase.Bain forecasts that April gross gambling revenue will be down 10% annually to $2.2 billion.Las Vegas Sands, the world's largest casino resort operator, closed up less than 0.1% in the stock market today. Wynn Resorts initially fell but finished up 1.4%. MGM Resorts, which has less exposure than its rivals in Macau, rose 2.2%. Melco Crown Entertainment lost 1.1%.

A chill that hit the IPO market in December turned into an all-out freeze in the first quarter, with the number of initial public offerings hitting a low not seen since the Great Recession of 2007-09.Just eight IPOs got out the door in Q1, down 76% from 34 in Q1 2015. That was the fewest IPOs since Q1 2009, which had just one. The $700 million in proceeds raised was the lowest total in 20 years, down 87% from the $5.5 billion raised in Q1 2015, according to Renaissance Capital, which manages two IPO-focused exchange traded funds.All eight IPOs were in the medical sector, and most of those only happened thanks to substantial buying of shares by existing shareholders and a reduction in the initial asking prices. Insider buying accounted for 67% of shares sold in the IPO of Editas Medicine (EDIT), and 48% at Corvus Pharmaceuticals (CRVS), for example.Recent trends provide hope that the IPO window will reopen in the second quarter, though the big names expected to be waiting for an opening -- companies such as Uber and Snapchat -- have been quiet on the IPO front.“While the IPO market has been frozen, we know it will open up again,” said Kathleen Smith, principal at Renaissance Capital. “There’s a buildup of companies waiting for the appropriate time to raise capital.”The primary cause of IPO droughts has always been weakness in the stock market. Markets started tanking in late December and bottomed in mid-February. The uptrend in market indexes could ease jitters and bring institutional investors -- and companies -- back to the IPO table.The IPO rebound will likely proceed slowly at first, as it did in 2009, Smith says, but she see signs some IPO icebreakers could hit the market in April or May. Companies that could debut include US Foods, the second-largest food-service distributor, which submitted an IPO filing in early February that could raise up to $1 billion. Another is MGM Growth Properties, a real-estate investment trust backed by MGM Resorts (MGM) that also could raise up to $1 billion, Renaissance estimates.But there’s no sign yet that any high-profile names will come forward soon to spark a heat wave. This week, Uber CEO Travis Kalanick said the ride-hailing company would wait as long as possible before coming public. It's among a large number of private companies that have raised hundreds of millions, in some cases billions, of dollars, with estimated market valuations well above $1 billion. An IPO is about the only route for investors in those privately held companies to get a healthy return from those investments.The IPO chill has been worsened by the sickly performance of last year's high-profile new offerings. Among them was Fitbit (FIT), the maker of wearable fitness devices. Fitbit had a heart-pounding start, with the stock jumping 48% on its first trading day June 18, pricing at 20 and closing above 29. Fitbit stock peaked at 51.90 in August, but now trades near 13.Box (BOX), the online storage service provider, had a similar story. It popped 66% on the first trading in January and closed at 24.73 on day one, which is still its peak. Box now trades near 12.50.Among all IPOs of 2015, their stocks are down 18% on average from their IPO price and down 28% after the first trading day, Renaissance says.The firm says the ultimate pace of the 2016 IPO market remains tough to call, yet it does expect some eye-catching IPOs to launch and deliver attractive returns to investors.Image provided by Shutterstock.

With Wynn Resorts (WYNN) expected to capture more Macau market share when its new $4.1 billion Wynn Palace opens in the next few months, at least one analyst is wagering on the company right now.Shares of the Las Vegas-based casino company rose 2.4% to 95 in the stock market today, rising as high as 96.60 intraday, after Morgan Stanley analyst Thomas Allen upgraded its stock to overweight from neutral, with a $120 price target.The 28-story, 1,700-room Wynn Palace hotel and casino will be the second resort that the company owns in Macau, the former Portuguese colony on China's southern coast that's grown into the world's top gambling destination.
