Wynn competes there with MGM Resorts International (MGM), Las Vegas Sands (LVS), Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) and others.Macau entered its worst-ever recession in mid-2014 amid slowing economic growth in China, a crackdown on corruption by the Chinese government and a partial smoking ban in Macau. Casino executives and many analysts have said that the region shows signs of stabilizing and could begin growing again as early as this year.Allen said in a report that there's still too much market risk in Macau to recommend both Wynn and Sands, the top two Macau casino operators, but he thinks that Wynn's expanding market share as it opens the new facility makes it "a good bet.""With Macau at least stabilizing, and Wynn going from a double-digit EBITDA (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization) decliner to double-digit grower in the next six months, we believe stock momentum can continue, given Wynn's long-term potential," Allen said in the report.After plunging 80% from its all-time intraday high of 249.31 in March 2014, Wynn stock bottomed at 49.95 on Jan. 15 of this year before turning up. It's nearly doubled in the last two months.  Its stock has an IBD Relative Strength Rating of 93.As expected, MGM Resorts International on Tuesday filed for an initial public offering of its real estate investment trust, MGM Growth Properties. The company announced the IPO, which is projected to be valued at about $1 billion, on its third quarter 2015 earnings call.Wells Fargo analyst Cameron McKnight said in a report Tuesday, "Any multiple uplift from the IPO is largely in the stock." McKnight has an outperform rating on MGM, which rose fractionally to 20.96.Las Vegas Sands, the world's biggest casino company, was flat at 53.27. Melco Crown Entertainment fell 1.35% to 16.85.

Prospects are improving for Macau-centric casinos like Las Vegas Sands (LVS), Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and MGM Resorts International (MGM), but they're not out of the woods yet, said Macquarie analyst Chad Beynon.He expects total Macau gambling revenue to shrink 6% this year, after sinking 24% in 2015, then go flat next year, and grow 3% in 2018.Macau went into recession in mid-2014 because gamblers and tourists stayed away in droves as China's economic growth began to cool, Chinese officials launched a nationwide crackdown on corruption, and Macau enacted a partial smoking ban.In a report on Friday, Beynon said that, based on a forecast model and channel checks, he has "positively adjusted" Macau market estimates, as well as company estimates. He maintained an outperform rating on his top pick, Sands, and raised his price target to 54 up from 48.He remains neutral on Wynn and lifted his price target to 70 from 63, saying Wynn "historically generates the highest EBITDA per table among gaming companies."He noted that both Wynn and MGM have delayed planned new Macau casinos. That's lowered total Macau gambling revenue but "will help overall industry margins."Beynon has an outperform rating on MGM and maintained a price target of 30.Shares of the big three Las Vegas casinos, which all depend in large part on Macau for growth, plus Hong Kong-based Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL), another top Macau casino operator, have collectively risen an average of about 57% since mid-January.Other analysts have projected a return to revenue growth for Macau, on a quarterly basis, could come as early as the second half of this year. In February, revenue was virtually flat.In a report on Friday, Deutsche Bank analyst Carlo Santarelli maintained a buy rating on Wynn and raised his price target to 94 from 82, saying, "we remain longer term bullish, given our favorable view of the Cotai (Macau) project, for which our current forecasts leave meaningful room for upward revisions."On March 7, UBS analyst Robin Farley said in a report about Macau-centric casino stocks, "Step up and pay today, or be constructive on a pullback." She added that "investors may have to pay more on entry now that the fundamentals are more clearly improving." Farley raised her rating on Wynn to buy from neutral, and lifted her price target to 95 from 73.Shares of Las Vegas Sands closed up 0.5% in the stock market today, up more than 50% from a Jan. 20 intraday low of 34.88. Wynn Resorts gapped up 5.9%, MGM rose 2.2%, and Melco Crown Entertainment added 4%.

Leading dividend stock Simon Property Group (SPG) has moved up into buying range ahead of its first-quarter earnings report later this month. The real estate investment trust, or REIT, is just past a 206.98 buy point after its breakout Tuesday. The stock is up 8% so far this year, topping the S&P 500's gain of about 1%. Indianapolis-based Simon Property…

MGM Resorts International (MGM) got a pair of good reviews from Morgan Stanley and from activist investor Land and Buildings, pushing its stock price higher.In an open letter to MGM investors, Land and Buildings CEO Jonathan Litt chastised Wall Street for what he sees as the "distressingly low level" of MGM's stock price relative to its peers.A separate Morgan Stanley report said that MGM is the most-efficient operator in Macau, besting Las Vegas peers Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and Wynn Resorts (WYNN), as well as Hong Kong-based Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL).Land and Buildings severely criticized MGM early last year and successfully pushed the casino operator to separate its land holdings and free shareholder value. In a turnaround from last year, Litt in the letter praised MGM's recent performance, saying there are "multiple catalysts that should lead to substantial upside from current levels.""MGM is many analysts' top pick with 40% upside to target price of $28.50," Litt said, adding that "Fourth-quarter results and the outlook for 2016 are unambiguously robust." He added, however: "We will continue to watch the results of MGM very carefully to see if their actions back up their words."After losing 44% of its stock value in the last two years, MGM bottomed at 16.18 on Feb. 9 before turning up. It has climbed about 24% from that point and closed 3.7% higher in the stock market today.On Oct. 29, MGM complied with Land and Buildings' request and agreed to place 10 of its properties, including seven on the Las Vegas Strip, into a real estate investment trust that's 70% owned by the casino giant.As reported earlier, recent numbers in Macau, the former Portuguese colony turned gambling hot spot on China's southern coast, have pointed to an upturn there after the special administrative district, beginning in mid-2014 went through its worst-ever economic downturn.Morgan Stanley analyst Praveen Choudhary said in a report Wednesday that staff is the largest fixed cost item for Macau casinos, contributing up to 70% of operating expenses. Choudhary said on that basis, "MGM China generates higher EBITDA per person employed when compared to Wynn Macau," which traditionally had the best staff costs.In a comparison of all Macau operators, MGM China scored an 88 on employee efficiency costs in the Morgan Stanley report, vs. an 82 for Sands China, a 75 for Wynn Macau and 73 for Melco Crown Entertainment.Las Vegas Sands rose 2.25% and Wynn Resorts added 1.6%. Melco Crown climbed nearly 3.5%.

Shares of Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and other Macau-centric casino companies have rallied recently, but Sterne Agee CRT says the upward move may be too much, too soon.Sterne Agree CRT analyst David Bain downgraded Wynn on Friday to a neutral rating from buy, with an 85 price target. Bain said its stock may be rising too fast, given conditions in Macau. Investors ignored the report and Wynn stock continued its weeks-long climb.Bain noted that at the time he wrote the report, Las Vegas-based Wynn's shares had risen 46% since Feb. 10 (Wynn was up 49% from that point as of Friday afternoon).Las Vegas Sands (LVS), MGM Resorts International (MGM) and Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) also have large casino resorts in Macau and have seen their stocks rise at a rapid rate this month on an increasing number of upbeat indicators from the Chinese special administrative district.Bain sounded a note of caution about Wynn's Macau casinos, saying, "We believe upside is limited, especially with the backdrop of still continuing struggles in the VIP segment, which Wynn is more levered to versus peers."Wynn plans to open the Wynn Palace in Macau in the back half of 2016, but Bain said benefits from that new casino are already priced in and "the bear case may be underappreciated, given initial relatively soft results" of competitors' recent expansions.UBS on March 7 upgraded Wynn Resorts to buy from neutral, with a 95 price target. UBS analyst Robin Farley said in a report that conditions in Macau are stabilizing and this might be a good time for investors to consider getting back into casinos with Macau exposure.Macau's slump began in mid-2014 amid a weakening of China's economy, partial smoking ban on casinos and a crackdown by the Chinese government on corruption, which made some VIP category high rollers nervous.Wynn shares closed up 2.4% in the stock market today. After five straight quarters in which its earning per share growth shrank at a double-digit rate, year over year, analyst consensus is for Wynn's EPS to climb 9% this quarter.Las Vegas Sands rose 1.9% Friday. MGM Resorts International added 2.3%. Wynn, Sands and MGM were all trading above both their 50-day moving averages and their 200-day lines. Melco Crown Entertainment climbed 3.2%, above its 50-day, but still below the 200-day.Image provided by Shutterstock.

Evidence continues to mount that Macau casinos are poised for recovery, which could give a boost to Las Vegas Sands (LVS), Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and MGM Resorts International (MGM).During the critical Chinese New Year holiday, gambling revenue on Macau was flat vs. a year earlier -- a sign of stabilization, as Macau's collective casino revenue has collapsed since mid-2014. UBS sees other signs of improvement."We have three quarters of sequential stabilization in mass (tourists and middle-class gamblers) revenues and now two quarters of sequential stabilization in VIP revenues," according to a Monday report, which also noted that gaming stocks with Macau exposure have risen 20% year to date.UBS upgraded Wynn to buy from neutral and lifted its price target to 95 from 73, citing "improved outlook and mitigating risk factors." UBS raised its price target on Las Vegas Sands, the world's biggest casino company, to 52 from 45 and maintained a neutral rating.Wynn, Sands, MGM and Hong Kong-based Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) all relied on Macau for the bulk of their growth until 2014, when the Chinese special administrative district across the strait from Hong Kong went into recession.The slump came amid slowing economic growth in China, a crackdown by the Chinese government on corruption, and a partial smoking ban that drove some gamblers away.Wells Fargo analyst Cameron McKnight in a March 4 report said that he, too, is seeing improvement in Macau, but he wasn't ready to call a bottom, noting that March is a better gauge of real demand, "free of Chinese New Year volatility and other noise."Wynn Resorts shares closed down 1.7% in the stock market today. Wynn has outperformed its peers recently. It's risen 69% since hitting a 17-year intraday low at 49.95 on Jan. 14 of this year. It's now trading above both its 50-day average and 10-week line.Las Vegas Sands fell 1.9%, but is up 47% from a Jan. 20 low at 34.88. MGM Resorts International ended flat, up about 23% from a Feb. 9 low. Melco Crown Entertainment skidded 3.55%.Image provided by Shutterstock.

Odds are the Macau recession is nearing an end, and good times may soon be rolling again for Las Vegas Sands (LVS), MGM Resorts International (MGM) and Wynn Resorts (WYNN).Macau Gaming Inspection and Coordination officials said gambling revenue dipped 0.1% last month to 19.5 billion patacas ($2.4 billion), the smallest decline in 20 months and well above analyst consensus for a 2%-10% drop.Macau went into a deep slump, starting in mid-2014. A broad crackdown on corruption by the Chinese government kept some gamblers away from casinos, and a smoking ban and the slowdown of China's economy all combined to knock Macau's economy down.Union Gaming analyst Grant Govertsen said in a report Tuesday that "February was shaping up well and it delivered."Govertsen sees light at the end of the tunnel, but still in the distance. "We would then look to June as the most likely month to see a return to year-over-year growth, which would be exactly two years after the first y/y decline in June 2014."Last month, which included the Lunar New Year holiday and an extra leap year day, he noted that "revenue per day was 4% higher than the month that included the most recent major holiday period (October Golden Week)."Shares of Las Vegas Sands, the world's biggest casino company by revenue, shot up 5% on the stock market today and have risen 37% from a Jan. 20 low.MGM Resorts climbed 5.3% and Wynn rose 2.5%. Hong Kong-based Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL), another Macau casino operator, rose 5.7%.Image provided by Shutterstock.

Recovery for casinos may be just around the corner, but it's not in sight yet. Battered MGM Resorts International (MGM) missed Q4 estimates, and shares fell hard. Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL), a Hong Kong-based company that owns has casino resorts in Macau, the gambling hub on China's southern coast, also reported worse-than-expected results and saw its stock punished. MGM Resorts lost…

Charlton Heston had already starred in 1952's Oscar-winning “The Greatest Show on Earth” and was Moses in 1956's “The Ten Commandments.”But he wasn’t the first choice for the lead in 1959’s “Ben-Hur,” playing a Roman slave who earns his freedom and becomes a champion charioteer. Burt Lancaster, Paul Newman, Marlon Brando, Rock Hudson and Leslie Nielsen all turned down director William Wyler.Once Heston got the part, he spent four weeks learning to drive a chariot for the race that remains one of the most spectacular scenes in movie history. It took five weeks to shoot on an 18-acre set, the largest ever built, with 15,000 extras.“Ben-Hur” was another Heston box office smash, made for $15 million and raking in $90 million worldwide (equal to $731 million now), saving MGM from bankruptcy.It won 11 Academy Awards, including Oscars for best picture and, for Heston, best actor -- a record that only “Titanic” in 1997 and “The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King” in 2003 would equal.Heston (1923-2008) was born John Charles Carter in a suburb of Chicago. The family soon moved to rural St. Helen, Mich., so his father could work at a sawmill.The boy was shocked when his parents divorced when he was 9, and he lost touch with his father. A loner, he spent much of his time hunting and fishing.His mother married Chester Heston, who would provide his stepson’s surname for the stage and screen. (Charlton was his mother’s maiden name). They moved to Winnetka, Ill., where the youngster saw his first professionally produced play, Shakespeare’s “Twelfth Night.”“He was hooked,” wrote Michael Munn in “Charlton Heston: A Biography.” “He joined the high school drama class. From that moment on, he never wanted to do anything else in life but be an actor. He certainly had a gift for it, which he developed through sheer enthusiasm and determination.”In 1941, his senior year, Heston was recruited for a Northwestern University play, Henrik Ibsen’s “Peer Gynt,” to replace the lead when he dropped out. It was to be staged and filmed. The resulting amateur silent movie with subtitles was his first time on the screen, and he used the name Charlton Heston. He entered NU in the fall.“The film was an incomparable learning experience for me,” he wrote in “In the Arena: An Autobiography.” “Somehow I left behind the nerd I’d been in high school. Now I was at NU, on a drama scholarship I’d earned, with an actual movie under my belt. … I managed to find the confidence that has never left me since.”In one of the acting courses, he met actress Lydia Clarke. But World War II interrupted his education, and in 1943 he began serving two years in the Army Air Corps. After training at bases around the country in radio and aerial gunnery on a B-25, he married Lydia in March 1944 (they would have a son and daughter). He flew to the Aleutian Islands off Alaska, but the Japanese had been driven out a few months earlier, never to return.Later, once he became famous, he was given top secret clearance to narrate classified instruction films for the military.Charlton and Lydia moved in 1948 to New York City, where he appeared in a Broadway revival of Shakespeare’s “Antony and Cleopatra” and had roles in dramas on CBS (CBS) TV’s “Studio One.”A Hollywood producer offered him a film contract, and he went West to make 1950’s crime drama “Dark City.”Then he turned down the lead in another picture, opposite Marilyn Monroe, because he wanted to be in a new play, "The Tumbler," directed by Lawrence Olivier in February 1951. Critics hated it, but Heston said he “learned from him in six weeks things I never would have learned otherwise.”The Heston couple decided to keep their apartment in New York and rent one in Los Angeles in 1952, so that they could do theater and movies. She made a few films, and he was in front of the cameras eight times that year.His most important movie was Cecil B. DeMille’s “The Greatest Show on Earth.” While playing the circus manager, Heston had to work with a crew of actors and real-life circus pros. The film received the best picture Oscar and earned $36 million in the U.S. (adjusted for the price of movie ticket inflation, it would be equivalent to $321 million today).“When I went to DeMille’s office the next morning after he picked up his Oscar to congratulate him, he said, ‘You’ve gotten some fine personal notices for this picture, but I want to read you one that may be the best review you’ll ever get in your life,’ ” Heston wrote. “He then read me a letter from a man who was enchanted with the picture … and concluded, ‘I was amazed at how well the circus manager did in there with the real actors.’ ”Heston's career stalled as he made forgettable films over the next three years.Then DeMille cast him as the star of “The Ten Commandments” because he thought Heston had an uncanny resemblance to the statue of Moses by Michelangelo in Rome.“Heston had meticulously prepared himself for the role, reading 22 volumes on the life of Moses, and he could recite whole passages of the Old Testament,” wrote Munn.The filming in Egypt was as lavish as the final film, with 10,000 extras on the set. DeMille recalled of Heston, “Before the big scene, he’d go off by himself for half an hour in costume and walk up and down in solitary thought. … When he came to the set and walked through the crowd of extras, their eyes following him, and they murmured reverently, ‘Moussa! Moussa!’ To them, Moslems all, he was the Prophet Moses.”The $90 million (worth $731 million now) that “Commandments” earned in the global market was exactly as much as “Ben-Hur” would.For this next spectacular, Heston was cast as the Jewish prince Judah Ben-Hur in the Roman-ruled Jerusalem of 26 A.D.When Stephen Boyd's Messala, a childhood friend who is now a Roman leader, orders Ben-Hur to name critics of the government, he refuses and is made a galley slave. During a battle, he saves the life of the admiral (Jack Hawkins), who has all the charges against him dropped. Ben-Hur wins the chariot race against Messala, who dies soon after crashing in the race."Ben-Hur" is ranked No. 2 among the American Film Institute’s Top 10 epic movies, just below “Lawrence of Arabia” (“Commandments” is No. 10).Over the next decade, Heston continued to portray strong leaders in epics:“El Cid” in 1961, as the 11th century Spanish hero in the wars against the Moors.“55 Days at Peking” in 1963, as a U.S. soldier battling Chinese rebels in the early 1900s.“The Greatest Story Ever Told” in 1965, as John the Baptist.“The Agony and the Ecstasy” in 1965, as Michelangelo battling the pope over the Sistine Chapel.“Khartoum” in 1966, as a British general in North Africa."Planet of the Apes” in 1968, as an astronaut who time-travels to a future Earth ruled by apes.Heston served as president of the Screen Actors Guild from 1965 to 1971, but his politics increasingly clashed with more liberal members'. He had marched for civil rights and campaigned for gun control, but in the 1970s he often voted Republican. By 1998, he was president of the National Rifle Association and served until 2003.“Even those in Hollywood who did not care for Heston’s political stances could not help admiring his professionalism on the set,” Beverly Gray, a film historian and author of “Roger Corman: Blood-Sucking Vampires, Flesh-Eating Cockroaches, and Driller Killers,” told IBD. “He took pride in always showing up on time, knowing his role and never demanding what might be called the perks of stardom. Temper tantrums and other forms of self-indulgence were for him out of the question.”Heston’s remaining career was mixed. His successes included the science-fiction classic “Soylent Green” (1973), a theater production of Herman Wouk’s “The Caine Mutiny” (1985) and a starring role in the TV soap opera “The Colbys” (1985-87).When director James Cameron was asked why he cast Heston as the CIA director in 1994’s “True Lies,” he explained, “I need someone who can plausibly intimidate Arnold Schwarzenegger.”After announcing that he was diagnosed with the first stage of Alzheimer’s disease in 2002, Heston died six years later at 84.Star of epic films such as “The Ten Commandments” and “Ben-Hur.”Overcame: Partisan prejudices of Hollywood.Lesson: Have the courage to say truths that are unpopular.“Political correctness is tyranny with manners.”

Shares of Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and other Macau-centric casinos fell hard Tuesday on a report that Macau's government may cap the number of tourists coming from inland China. Credit Suisse revised its forecast for Macau casinos downward.Macau's government has decided to fight a decline in visitors that's led to its worst financial slump ever by — wait for it — proposing a cap on the number of visitors.Macau Business, a news publisher, said the government of the former Portuguese colony, now a special administrative district like Hong Kong, is proposing to China's government that the number of mainland tourists allowed to visit Macau be limited to fewer than 21 million a year.It wants to cap China tourists, who are mainly middle-class gamblers, to focus on attracting more high-roller VIP category gamblers, the report said. VIP gamblers are fewer in number but spend more, and most don't come from the mainland.Macau casinos' total revenue has already plunged amid tighter regulations by China's government and the shrinking growth rate of China's economy.Last year, Macau reported its first decline in year-to-year revenue, and the slump has continued this year.Macau's plan could backfire if the number of tourists from China falls and it isn't able to boost global tourist count. That could cause more pain for Sands, Wynn Resorts (WYNN), MGM Resorts International (MGM) and others.Sterne Agee analyst David Bain said Macau's government may be posturing, saying "a key Macau contact with political insight suggests that comments regarding limiting visitation growth acts as a lever to address the mainland for additional (much needed/desired) land allowance for Macau for resident housing, etc."Bain expects a 35% year-to-year decline in Macau gambling revenue in April. He doesn't expect much improvement in Macau until later this year, although by midyear the situation should be "less bad."Credit Suisse analyst Kenneth Fong on Tuesday cut his first-quarter forecast for Macau gross gambling revenue to a range of 23% shrinkage to 9% growth, from an earlier forecast of 21% reduction to 10% growth.And "with fundamentals continuing to weaken" and valuation of Macau casinos relatively high, "gaming names may see downside here," Fong said.Sands shares gapped down 4% in strong volume in Tuesday afternoon trading in the stock market today.The world's biggest casino company's stock price is down 37% from a six-year high set in March 2014, and it fell below its 50-day average Tuesday.Wynn Resorts skidded nearly 5% and MGM,which has less exposure in Macau, fell 1%. Hong Kong-based Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) was down 4%.Follow James DeTar on Twitter: @IBD_JDeTar.

Total gross gambling revenue for Macau fell nearly 40% to $4.76 billion in March vs. the same month a year ago, continuing the slide that began last summer for Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and other Macau-centric casinos.Though severe, the 39.4% drop in March was better than the 48.6% fall in the prior month, and in line with analyst estimates as market watchers and investors get used to the "new normal' for the world's top gambling destination.Chinese officials last year imposed tighter government restrictions on lending and other practices in Macau as part of an ongoing national "anti-corruption" campaign. Many high-roller, VIP-category gamblers had relied on short-term loans to get around restrictions against bringing more than a limited amount of outside currency into Macau and are staying away.Additionally, shrinking economic growth in China and a smoking ban that went into effect in casinos last fall are keeping some some tourists away.Wells Fargo analyst Cameron McKnight said the decline was in line with consensus. McKnight said in a report that, based on channel checks in Macau "we expect April and May gaming revenue growth could be down 30%-plus."We remain neutral on Macau gaming as estimates and valuations adjust to a 'new normal' of (1) tighter government oversight, (2) 10% and 15%-20% medium-term industry revenue and earnings growth, and (3) a recovery that is likely to be flatter than reflected in valuations."Shares of Sands, the world's biggest casino company, closed down 0.1% on the stock market today. MGM Resorts International (MGM) lost 0.7%, its ninth straight lower close.Wynn Resorts (WYNN) dipped 0.3%, while Hong Kong-based Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) finished up 2.3%, reversing an earlier loss.Follow James DeTar on Twitter: @IBD_JDeTar .

Shares of Las Vegas Sands (LVS) rose above their 50-day average intraday. Monday, on track to close higher for a seventh day in the last eight trading sessions, on upbeat reports about the global gambling hub Macau.HSBC Bank last Thursday said it thinks the strong dollar rally is coming to an end. The unfavorable currency rate has hurt U.S. global companies' revenue by weakening the value of revenue they derive from overseas operations. The dollar has continued to slide since the Federal Reserve signaled last Wednesday that rate hikes may be later and slower than previously expected.Early Monday, HSBC's head of equity strategy in Asia-Pacific, Herald van der Linde, said in a follow-up report said that Asian stocks will benefit from a more stable dollar.Van der Linde said among Asian equities, including subsidiaries of U.S. casinos with Macau interests: "Consumer discretionary names tend to benefit the most from a weaker U.S. dollar."Last Wednesday after the market closed, Brean Capital analyst Bryan Maher launched coverage of Sands and three other top casino companies with buy ratings. Maher expects the slide in gambling revenue there to reverse later this year and urged investors to position themselves for an uptick in share values.Sands fell hard in the back half of 2014 as the Chinese government continued a crackdown on casinos, China's economic growth weakened and Macau put a smoking ban into effect that kept some smokers away.Sands, the world's largest casino company by annual revenue, MGM Resorts International (MGM) Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and others with casino resorts in Macau rose in Monday afternoon trading even though the upbeat reports were tempered by a cautious outlook in Macau, where officials slashed their average monthly gambling revenue outlook 27% to $2.5 billion a month for calendar 2015.Macau Chief Executive Fernando Chui said in his annual policy address that Macau has also entered a period of slower growth and casinos need to add new features to the resort side of the business to attract visitors.Wells Fargo Securities analyst Cameron McKnight has doubts Macau is ready for a turnaround."We remain neutral on Macau gaming, and continue to believe stocks will remain range-bound this year as Macau adjusts to the 'new normal' of greater government intervention and lower, steadier longer-term growth," McKnight said in a report Monday.After peaking at 57.27 by late morning, Sands shares had settled somewhat, still up 0.5% at 56.40 in afternoon trading in the stock market today. Wynn was up 2% while MGM fell 0.4%. Hong Kong-based Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) was off 1%.Follow James DeTar on Twitter: @IBD_JDeTar.

Casino stocks have declined for the last year, but the worlds's largest casino company Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and other battered Macau-centric casino stocks popped early Thursday on a report their luck may be turning. Brean Capital analyst Bryan Maher after the market closed on Wednesday initiated coverage on Sands and three other top casino companies with buy ratings. Brean…
Gaming and Leisure Properties (GLPI) hopes to get lucky with its $4.1 billion hostile offer for casino operator Pinnacle Entertainment's (PNK) properties.
Gaming and Leisure Properties said its offer was rebuffed and it plans to take the offer to the company's shareholders if Pinnacle refuses talks.

Real estate investment trust Gaming and Leisure, itself a spinoff of Penn National Gaming (PENN), sent a letter to Pinnacle's board offering to acquire its real estate assets and assume debt in exchange for shares.
Pinnacle responded Monday afternoon, saying it received a proposal from Gaming and Leisure on Jan. 16 and that it was willing to talk at that time "under appropriate terms."

Pinnacle added that it received a revised proposal last Friday and told Gaming and Leisure its board would review the offer and respond promptly, "but GLPI decided not to wait for the consideration of Pinnacle's Board."

Pinnacle owns 15 casinos in eight states and a majority interest in Retama Park Racetrack near San Antonio. Last November, it announced plans to separate its gaming operating business and real estate assets.
Under terms of the latest offer, Pinnacle's operating business would become a separately traded public company and would be operated by its current management and board.
The Pinnacle operating company would enter into a master lease agreement with Gaming and Leisure for its casino properties.
Pinnacle shareholders would receive one share of the new operating company and 0.5517 share of Gaming and Leisure stock for each share of Pinnacle they own.
After the deal concludes, current Pinnacle shareholders would own 100% of the operating company and about 20% of the combined real estate company.
Pinnacle shares were up 15% in afternoon trading on the stock market today. Gaming and Leisure was up 11%. Pinnacle stock shot up from a four-month consolidation with a 27.45 pivot point.

Meanwhile, shares of casino giants Las Vegas Sands (LVS), MGM Resorts International (MGM), Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) were down after Macquarie Securities warned that the worst is yet to come for Macau gaming, and forecast that dividends will be slashed across the board for companies with heavy presences in the Chinese gambling hub.
Macau casinos have seen revenue drop sharply in the last year amid a crackdown by the Chinese government and weakening economic growth in China.

Macau's gambling revenue tumbled almost 49% as China's anti-corruption campaign continued and high rollers took their money elsewhere in February. But the timing of the Lunar New Year also impacted results, says one analyst.
Monthly gross revenue sank 48.6% to 19.5 billion patacas, or $2.4 billion, down from 38 billion patacas the year before, according to Macau's Gaming Inspection and Coordination Bureau.
Shares of Las Vegas Sands (LVS) fell 0.8% by early afternoon in the stock market today (Tuesday). Wynn Resorts (WYNN) shares were down 0.8%, too. But MGM Resorts International (MGM) shares rose 0.7%.

The February decline came amid a crackdown on corruption and weaker economic growth in the country. But the month nevertheless ended strongly, which one analyst attributed to the timing of the Lunar New Year, which arrived on Feb. 19 this year. The Lunar New Year falls in January or February.

"Typically, early days of Chinese New Year are spent at home with family — not in a casino — and we believe this led to an initial lull in early February Chinese New Year results," said Sterne Agee analyst David Bain in a note.
"Recall that February of last year did not show a pre-holiday slowdown as (the Chinese New Year) began Jan. 31 versus Feb. 19 this year."
Gross gaming revenue during the last five days of February climbed nearly 80% from the previous seven days as people flocked to the casinos after the close-to-home festivities ended.

The VIP segment sank about 56% year over year, while the mass gaming segment fell about 33%, said Bain; he added that Sands gained market share in February on its appeal to mass gaming, but Wynn's share was "slightly disappointing," given the casino renovation and a new junket group.
RELATED:
MGM Resorts Loss Widens On Plunge In Macau Revenue.

MGM Resorts International's (MGM) fourth-quarter loss widened and its revenue was lighter than expected as Macau operations continued to be a drag on results.
Shares fell early Tuesday, pulling the casino sector down, even though MGM announced a special $400 million dividend.
MGM Resorts reported a 70 cents per share loss minus one-time items, far worse than the 6-cent profit Wall Street expected. It was the third quarter in a row the company missed earnings estimates.
Revenue of $2.39 billion was down from $2.51 billion a year ago. Analysts expected $2.41 billion.

MGM Macau revenue of $719 million was down 22% from Q4 2013. In contrast, revenue at U.S. casinos rose 5% year over year to $1.55 billion, with management fees and other operations accounting for the balance of revenue.
The company noted that Q4 results were hurt by a one-time tax charge.
MGM CEO Jim Murren is looking for stronger results in 2015 and said, "In fact, we are already off to a good start with strong January results in the U.S."

But Wells Fargo analyst Cameron McKnight said the situation in Macau is likely to stay negative well into 2015, which could keep a lid on earnings for MGM and other Macau-centric casinos such as Wynn Resorts (WYNN), Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL).
In a report prior to MGM's earnings release, Wells Fargo said total China credit contracted 20% year over year in January, a negative for Macau casinos .

MGM shares dropped from a 5-1/2-year high of 28.75 on March 7 to a 2014 low 17.25 on Dec. 17 amid a slump in Macau resulting from a crackdown by China on lending practices, a smoking ban that drove some customers away and weaker China economic growth.

MGM had recovered to nearly 22 per share on Friday and was down less than 1% in early Tuesday trading in the stock market today. It dropped further below its 200-day line but was still trading above its 50-day.
Among other casinos, Sands and Melco Crown were both down fractionally while Wynn Resorts dropped more than 2%.

Revenue for Macau's casinos could fall a jaw-dropping 35% to 42% in February vs. the same month a year ago, according to a new market analysis. That could further drive down shares of battered Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and other Macau-centric casinos. Early February's average daily receipts for Macau casinos hit $83.27 million through Feb. 8, down 13% from January's…
Macau gambling revenue plunged 17.4% to $3 billion in January, the eighth monthly drop in a row.
The decline pushed down shares of Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and others that get the bulk of their revenue from the Chinese gaming enclave.

It followed a 30.4% drop in December and 19.6% drop in November as the global gambling hub in 2014 posted its first-ever gambling revenue decrease, according to figures released by the Macau Gaming Inspection and Coordination Bureau.
Sands shares were down 1.8% in Monday morning trading on the stock market today.
Among other large casinos, MGM Resorts International (MGM) and Wynn Resorts (WYNN) were down about 1%.
Wynn is slated to report earnings Feb. 3. Consensus is for earnings per share to fall 37% to $1.43 on a 20.4% drop in revenue to $1.21 billion.
Hong Kong-based Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) rose fractionally.

"Mass market" gamblers — tourists and middle-class inland Chinese visitors to the southern China coast hot spot — fell 20%. "VIP" high-roller revenue dipped 16%, Wells Fargo analyst Cameron McKnight said.
The slide is likely to continue, McKnight said, as a crackdown by the Chinese government on alleged corruption and weakening Chinese economic growth keep a lid on spending.
"Based on current ADR (average daily revenue rate) and seasonal trends we believe February gaming revenue growth could be closer to -35%, vs. our -31% estimate."
Chinese New Year, which falls on Feb. 19 this year, could have major impact. McKnight said channel checks show Chinese New Years vacation travel bookings are lower than in prior years.
Sands, the world's largest casino company hit a six-year high in early March 2014 and slid for the rest of the year. It's down about 39% from that point, trading below its 50-day and 200-day lines.

Gambling revenue in the hot Macau resort may shrink much more than earlier thought.
In one of the first bets on 2015 casino gambling, Wells Fargo cut its estimate for existing Macau casinos to a steep 15% fall from the 4% decline projected earlier.
The projected revenue drop could further drive down shares of struggling Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and other Macau-centric casinos.
Wells Fargo analyst Cameron McKnight has a market perform (neutral) rating on Sands and other casinos the bank tracks.

"For 2015, we now expect revenue sequentially flat with (fourth quarter) trends, resulting in -15% year-over-year same-store growth and -10% year-over-year total growth," factoring in casinos that are expected to open this year, McKnight said.
China has cracked down on lending in Macau, the gambling hotspot on China's southern coast, as part of a nationwide "anti-corruption" drive.
It has also put visa restrictions on visitors from inland China to the Macau special administrative district and implemented strict currency regulations, McKnight said.
"We are not being bearish for the sake of it, but currently don't see a reason to expect any same-store revenue improvement in the near term, given China's policy actions toward Macau," he said.
McKnight reduced his price target range for Sands, the world's largest casino company, from 60-70 to 55-60.
He cut his target for Wynn Resorts (WYNN) to 150-170 from 170-190, and for Hong Kong-based Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) to 23-27 from 26-29.
McKnight left his target for MGM Resorts International (MGM) unchanged at 23-26.

Sands shares were down 2.2% in late afternoon trading in the stock market today, Tuesday. Although it's the highest-rated global casino company in the struggling group, it has a weak 40 IBD Composite Rating, meaning 60% of all stocks have performed better in recent quarters on key metrics such as sales and profit growth.
Sands hasn't formed a viable base recently, and is trading well below both its 50-day and 200-day averages.
Wynn shares were down 1.6%, MGM 3.2% and Melco Crown 2.8%.

Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and other Macau-centric casinos face further pain amid even gloomier predictions for gambling revenue next year, dashing hopes that the extended downturn in the gaming mecca might end soon.

Macau Chief Executive Fernando Chui expects 2016 casino revenue of $25 billion and called his estimate of the latest decline "conservative," according to the Financial Times and South China Morning Post.

This year, Macau gambling revenue is already expected to sink 30%-35% to $28.6 billion-$30.8 billion. While that's still twice the expected revenue for Las Vegas casinos, it's down from $45.2 billion in 2013 and $44 billion in 2014.

Macau, a city on China's southern coast across the strait from Hong Kong, is home to multibillion-dollar casino resorts owned by Sands, Wynn Resorts (WYNN), MGM Resorts International (MGM), Hong Kong-based Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) and others.
Shares of Las Vegas Sands closed up 1.4% in the stock market today.

Wynn Resorts finished 0.4% lower. The casino company on Wednesday announced the delay of the opening of a new casino in Macau, the Wynn Palace in the trendy Cotai area of Macau. Wynn said the casino resort won't be completed until June 25, pushed back from its prior March 25 target. Wynn said it was notified of a delay by its general contractor.
MGM Resorts International rose 2%, and Melco Crown Entertainment rose 1.2%.

China's slowing economy has cut the number of Chinese tourists visiting the resort city. A crackdown by Chinese officials on the gambling industry and recent partial smoking ban have further curtailed business in Macau.
Wells Fargo analyst Cameron McKnight in a report Monday said he sees signs suggesting the market trend is still in decline.

"We remain on the sidelines regarding the Macau market, and we expect no V-shaped recovery, as the credit-induced bubble of the past five years continues deflating, and Chinese policies continue to suppress growth," McKnight said.

This is Frank Sinatra's moment. This year's Dec. 12 marks his 100th birthday. CBS recently broadcast "Sinatra 100: An All-Star Grammy Concert," featuring Tony Bennett, Alicia Keys, Garth Brooks, John Legend and Celine Dion.
The Grammy Museum in Los Angeles has a special exhibit through Feb. 15 for Sinatra (1915-98).
Yet the man many call the greatest entertainer of the 20th century seemed to have peaked in 1946.
Five years earlier, he had been America's favorite male singer.

In 1942, there was a riot when 35,000 fans couldn't get into a New York City concert. He co-starred in the first of three hit movies with Gene Kelly in 1945. The next year he sold 10 million records and CBS gave him a weekly radio show.

Then came the crash of 1947-52: His sales plummeted and the label dropped him, the MGM studio terminated his film contract, he suffered a hemorrhaging of the vocal chords, had to borrow $200,000 to pay back taxes, and his wife, Nancy, divorced him.
In 1953, he begged his way into being cast in the movie "From Here to Eternity" by working just for expenses.
Presto. He won an Academy Award for best supporting actor.
The Comeback Kid
By 1954, he was at the top of the public polls again.

"It was the biggest comeback in entertainment history, and he became the greatest popular singer of the 20th century," James Kaplan, author of "Sinatra: The Chairman," told IBD. "Although he was a high school dropout, he was intellectually ambitious, a voracious reader and did the New York Times crossword puzzle every day — in ink because he knew he wouldn't need to change his answers. He had a great appreciation for other talented people and learned from his mother the importance of having brilliant advisors, which became one of the secrets of his success."
Francis Albert Sinatra was born in Hoboken, N.J., the only child of two Italian immigrants.
The delivery had to be done with forceps because he weighed 13-1/2 pounds, scarring on the left side of his face and neck and perforating his left ear drum.
His father, Marty, was an illiterate boxer and later a fireman.
His mother, Dolly, was a midwife and community activist who was smart and driven, toughing up her son, instilling self-confidence and making sure he always dressed well.
His parents owned a tavern where Frank did his homework and sang for tips. But he was a troublemaker in high school and left before graduating.
When he was 19, he was invited to join a local singing group mainly because he had a car and could drive the guys to events, but he helped them win a radio contest, and they went on a national tour.
Back doing odd jobs, he got vocal training and in 1939, at 23, made his first solo record.

Soon he was hired by bandleader Harry James, then a few months later jumped to a hotter band led by Tommy Dorsey. In 1940, the Sinatra single "I'll Never Smile Again" topped the charts for 12 weeks. The next year public polls voted him the No. 1 male singer, and he soon had 1,000 fan clubs.
His first album, "The Voice of Frank Sinatra," with Columbia Records, came out in 1946.
The Right Tone And Roles

"He worked very hard at perfecting his technique, including the ability to hold long phrases without pausing to inhale," said Kaplan, who wrote about his early career in "Sinatra: The Voice." "He made a profound study of the lyrics so that by the time he sang them, he could communicate depths of meaning beyond what others could."

Sinatra had been disqualified from military service during World War II because of his bad ear, being four pounds underweight and emotionally volatile (today he would be diagnosed with bipolar disorder).
During the war years, he taught himself acting and received rave reviews with Kelly in "Anchors Aweigh" and later also with the dancer in "Take Me Out to the Ball Game" and "On the Town."

The series of 1947-52 disasters pushed him into such a deep depression that he made a feeble suicide attempt. The lowest point came after his 1939 marriage to Nancy Barbato fell apart in 1951, and she left with their three children. Later that year, Sinatra married Ava Gardner, though they would divorce in 1957. He would be married to Mia Farrow from 1966 to 1968, with his last wedding to Barbara Marx in 1976, a marriage that lasted until his death.

After Sinatra's resurrection in 1953 due to "From Here to Eternity," he became a full-fledged 1950s star, earning a best actor Oscar nomination for "The Man With the Golden Arm" and a Golden Globe best actor award for "Pal Joey."
Capitol Spin

When Columbia dumped him, Sinatra made a wise move to Capitol Records. His 1950s hit singles included "I've Got the World on a String," "Come Fly With Me," "I've Got You Under My Skin" and "The Lonely." He also earned a Grammy Award for best album with 1959's "Come Dance With Me!"

"Capitol paired him with fellow musical genius Nelson Riddle, whose arrangements produced a series of incomparably great albums, but Sinatra grew frustrated with being unable to own the master recordings, something that very few artists have ever had the rights to," said Kaplan. "That would have given him total control of the music when it was reissued or included in other albums.
"He left to form Reprise Records in 1960, but it had some very rough times early on, partly because he refused to sign any rock 'n' roll acts.

"Jack Warner wanted him for his movies, and Sinatra's attorney, Mickey Rudin, one of the sharpest lawyers of all time, required the deal to include Reprise. Warner agreed in 1963, and the label went on to become a powerhouse."
Sinatra's classic songs in the 1960s included "That's Life," "It Was a Very Good Year," "Strangers in the Night" and "My Way."
He won Grammys for best album with two LPs, "September of My Years" and "A Man and His Music," as well as the Lifetime Achievement Award.
And his string of motion picture box office smashes continued with "Ocean's 11," "The Manchurian Candidate" and "Von Ryan's Express."
But 1970 was another rough year. A critically acclaimed LP, "Watertown," sold just 30,000 and reached only 101 on Billboard's chart.
Out, But Not For Long
He stopped performing at Caesars Palace in Las Vegas after an executive pulled a gun on him.
The next year, he announced his retirement.
Restless, Sinatra returned in 1973 with an album and a TV special titled "Ol' Blue Eyes Is Back," which rose to No. 13 on Billboard.
He also began touring, selling out major venues (having previously favored more intimate settings).
In 1979, on his 64th birthday, he received the Grammy Trustees Award for 40 years in showbiz.

In 1980, he released his first album in six years, "Trilogy: Past Present Future," an ambitious triple record set that covered the variety of pop across the decades, including rock. It reached No. 17 and featured his late-career signature song, "New York, New York."
After decades of heavy smoking and drinking, his voice was no longer quite so golden, though he could still at times mesmerize audiences.
He did more than 1,000 concerts from 1976 to 1990 before slowing down due to health problems, performing 48 times in his last year of touring in 1994.
Despite his lavish living (often spending several million a year), Sinatra didn't need the money. He had invested wisely and ultimately left a net worth of $100 million.
"He owned a ton of real estate, chartered jets, bought a company making missile parts and was so diversified he was a walking conglomerate," said Kaplan.
His last two albums paired him with other singers: "Duets" in 1995 and the next year "Duets II," which earned his 13th Grammy.

His final live performance came in 1995 before a private audience of 1,200 at the close of the Sinatra Desert Golf Classic in Palm Desert, Calif., with the last song "The Best Is Yet to Come." The family had that inscribed on his tombstone three years later when he died at 82.
Cheers

"He was a one-of-a-kind maverick. The ultimate nonconformist, and as such, a monument to Emersonian self-reliance," wrote David Lehman in "Sinatra's Century." "Sinatra is also a brand. You will hear him in commercials for vodka, as background music in your head, as the song playing over movie credits ... invaluable to one who believes in the greatness of the classic American popular song."This is Frank Sinatra's moment. This year's Dec. 12 marks his 100th birthday. Casino stocks got clobbered again Monday on a report projecting more bleak numbers from the world's top gambling destination, Macau, China.Las Vegas Sands (LVS), Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and MGM Resorts International (MGM), as well as Hong Kong's Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL), which all have multi-billion-dollar casino resorts in Macau, fell hard.The rout was led by declines of up to 10% for both Wynn and Melco Crown.Las Vegas Sands, the world's largest casino company, closed down 6.4% Monday on the stock market today, just above its 50 day average line. It's already well below its 200-day line and hasn't formed a viable base so far in 2015.Wynn Resorts recovered a bit from morning losses and closed down 7.3%, while Melco Crown Entertainment fell 6.8%. MGM Resorts International, which is the biggest casino operator in Las Vegas and less exposed to Macau than its Vegas peers, dropped 2%.Macau Revenue Worse Than ExpectedChecks with Macau casinos indicate a 30% to 34% decline in Macau revenue in November vs. the same month a year ago, Wells Fargo analyst Cameron McKnight said in a Monday report. That could be worse than the bank's estimate for a 30% drop.McKnight said in the report, "Weekly numbers have been volatile since early June, and (we) expect this pattern to continue given continued instability in the VIP segment."Deutsche Bank noted that after Macau's long run that made it the globe's premier gambling destination, optimism for a recovery is running out.Deutsche Bank analyst Karen Tang said in a research note reported by StreetInsider that November numbers are tracking weak, and pointed to "unexciting" early results from Melco Crown's huge new Studio City resort.Tang said that bad luck was partly responsible for the low initial turnout for Studio City but added that the data are still weak, considering the resorts' many attractions. Deutsche Bank has a hold rating on Melco Crown.High roller "VIP" category gamblers, who mainly play baccarat, account for a large portion of Macau profits, although "mass market" tourists who play other table games spend the most in dollars.In an earlier report, McKnight called out the recent opening of Melco Crown's Studio City resort, which is the first to have TV and movie studios on site, along with casinos, hotels and shops, saying it could give Macau a lift if it was a hit. No such luck.McKnight said in the report that checks suggested the average daily revenues last week for Macau were around 525 million Macau patacas (about $65.76 million), down 9% sequentially and off 36% vs. the same week last year "despite a full week of results following the Oct. 27 opening of MPEL's Studio City." As a result, he said, "We remain on the sidelines on the Macau gaming names."Follow James DeTar on Twitter @IBD_JDeTar and Facebook.

China's official manufacturing index fell to a 3-year low in November. But the services PMI rose, highlighting an economic shift helping Apple (AAPL), Nike (NKE) and Starbucks (SBUX). The manufacturing activity gauge fell 0.2 point to 49.6, the worst since August 2012, according to the National Bureau of Statistics on Tuesday local time. The reading was slightly below views and…

Stocks ended lower in light volume Monday on concerns that the Federal Reserve appears poised to raise interest rates as early as next month. The Nasdaq, S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average each fell 1%. Volume fell 14% on the Nasdaq and 10% on the NYSE compared with Friday, according to preliminary data.Traders increased their bets that the Federal Reserve would soon raise interest rates following Friday's strong jobs report. That could saddle consumers with higher borrowing costs and boost the dollar, which could slow the U.S. economy.Leisure and discretionary consumer stocks were hit hardest in the stock market todayOnline travel broker Priceline.com (PCLN) plunged nearly 10% after a weak Q4 outlook overshadowed a better-than-expected Q3 earnings report.The stock sank below a 1394.10 buy point of a cup-type base and sliced through its 50-day moving average.Meanwhile, gambling stocks fell on expectations of weakness in the Chinese gambling enclave of Macau, the world's top gaming destination. Wynn Resorts (WYNN) fell more than 8%. Las Vegas Sands (LVS) sank 6% and MGM Resorts International (MGM) slipped 2%.On the upside, IBD 50 stock LinkedIn (LNKD) rose 2% as it continues to climb the right side of a deep, cup-type base with a 276.28 buy point.D.R. Horton (DHI), Luxoft (LXFT), Zebra Technologies (ZBRA) and Amdocs (DOX) are among companies due to report quarterly earnings Tuesday.Economic data scheduled for Tuesday include import and export prices for October and wholesale inventories for September.

The latest combined revenue numbers for Macau casinos including those run by Las Vegas Sands (LVS), Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and MGM Resorts International (MGM) remained bleak, but a huge new casino project is a bright spot on the horizon, a report said.
Total gambling revenue for Macau casinos fell 28% in October vs. the same month a year earlier to $2.5 billion, in line with Wells Fargo's estimate.
Despite slow but steady growth in smaller Las Vegas, the outlook for Macau — where Sands, MGM Resorts and Wynn Resorts all operate multibillion-dollar casino resorts — is cloudy.
Wells Fargo analyst Cameron McKnight said in a report that he expects Macau casinos' November revenue to fall 30% year over year.

"We remain neutral on the Macau names (Sands, Wynn and Hong Kong-based Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) as the market adjusts to a 'new normal' of (1) tighter government oversight, (2) more muted medium-term industry revenue growth and (3) a recovery that is likely to be flatter than prior rebounds," he said.
McKnight didn't include MGM Resorts in his Macau report. Although it operates casinos in Macau, MGM is the top operator in Las Vegas and less exposed than peers Sands and Wynn in Macau.
McKnight noted that a huge new casino just opened in Macau: Studio City, which is 60% owned by Melco Crown and partly owned by U.S. and Hong Kong private investment firms.
Studio City is the first venue in Macau to feature integrated TV and film production facilities, as well as retail stores, casinos and hotels. It held its grand opening on Oct. 27.

"In our view, early results at Studio City will be a key catalyst for the group, and likely a 'lightning rod' for both bulls and bears," McKnight said, adding, "We believe the extent to which Studio City can grow the market will be a key driver for stocks."

Las Vegas Sands, the world's biggest casino resort company, closed up 2.2% at 50.61 in Monday trading in the stock market today, its fourth straight higher close. It hit an intraday low of 36.53 on Oct. 1 and has rebounded 39% from that point.
MGM Resorts rose 2.5% and Melco Crown 3%. Wynn Resorts jumped 3.2%.

Follow James DeTar on Twitter @IBD_JDeTar and Facebook.The latest combined revenue numbers for Macau casinos including those run by Las Vegas Sands (LVS), Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and MGM Resorts International (MGM) remained bleak, but a huge new casino project is a bright spot on the horizon, a report said.Total gambling revenue for Macau casinos fell 28% in October vs. the same month a year earlier to $2.5 billion, in line with Wells Fargo's estimate.Despite slow but steady growth in smaller Las Vegas, the outlook for Macau — where Sands, MGM Resorts and Wynn Resorts all operate multibillion-dollar casino resorts — is cloudy.Wells Fargo analyst Cameron McKnight said in a report that he expects Macau casinos' November revenue to fall 30% year over year."We remain neutral on the Macau names (Sands, Wynn and Hong Kong-based Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) as the market adjusts to a 'new normal' of (1) tighter government oversight, (2) more muted medium-term industry revenue growth and (3) a recovery that is likely to be flatter than prior rebounds," he said.McKnight didn't include MGM Resorts in his Macau report. Although it operates casinos in Macau, MGM is the top operator in Las Vegas and less exposed than peers Sands and Wynn in Macau.McKnight noted that a huge new casino just opened in Macau: Studio City, which is 60% owned by Melco Crown and partly owned by U.S. and Hong Kong private investment firms.Studio City is the first venue in Macau to feature integrated TV and film production facilities, as well as retail stores, casinos and hotels. It held its grand opening on Oct. 27."In our view, early results at Studio City will be a key catalyst for the group, and likely a 'lightning rod' for both bulls and bears," McKnight said, adding, "We believe the extent to which Studio City can grow the market will be a key driver for stocks."Las Vegas Sands, the world's biggest casino resort company, closed up 2.2% at 50.61 in Monday trading in the stock market today, its fourth straight higher close. It hit an intraday low of 36.53 on Oct. 1 and has rebounded 39% from that point.MGM Resorts rose 2.5% and Melco Crown 3%. Wynn Resorts jumped 3.2%.Follow James DeTar on Twitter @IBD_JDeTar and Facebook.
Struggling Caesars Entertainment (CZR) expects its merger with a unit it spun off in late 2013 will move it closer to resolving its debt through bankruptcy.
Caesars provided details of its latest restructuring move Monday, the Wall Street Journal said, after announcing a week ago on Dec. 22 that it planned to buy Caesars Acquisition in a stock swap deal.
Caesars Entertainment set up Caesars Acquisition to buy online gaming sites, and split it off in late 2013.
Shares of Caesars, the top U.S. casino company, rose 1.9% in Monday morning trading on the stock market todayhttps://www.investors.com/stock-market-today/.

Caesars earlier missed the boat to Macau, where rivals Las Vegas Sands (LVS), MGM Resorts International (MGM) and Wynn Resorts (WYNN) all built multibillion-dollar casinos years ago that today generate the bulk of their growth.

Caesars' proposed merger would give the combined company, to be called Caesars Entertainment Operating Co., an additional $1.7 billion cash, it says, to help alleviate its estimated $18.4 billion in debt.

The new operating company would be controlled by a real estate investment trust. That REIT would continue to be controlled by private equity firms Apollo Global Management and TPG Capital, the reports said.

Las Vegas Sands lost the lead in market share to Hong Kong-based SJM Holdings, one of the six casino companies licensed to operate the 35 casino resorts in the world's most popular gambling hotspot.
SJM, operator of the Grand Lisboa, Casino Babylon and 16 other casinos, had about 22.6% of Macau's gross gaming revenue in November, various reports said, citing Macau gambling commission figures.
Sands Macau — a unit of Las Vegas Sands (LVS), the world's largest casino company — saw revenue decline 4% on a year-over-year basis, giving it a roughly 22.5% share.
But Sands Cotai Central, the company's new $4 billion casino on Macau's popular Cotai peninsula, continued to outgrow the market, according to Wells Fargo analyst Cameron McKnight.

Hong Kong-listed Galaxy Entertainment had a market share of 21.5%. Wynn Resorts (WYNN) had 9%. MGM China, a unit of MGM Resorts International (MGM), had 11%, and Hong Kong-based Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) had 13.4%.
Las Vegas Sands stock was down fractionally on the stock market today. Wynn and Melco Crown shares were up less than 1%, while MGM fell less than 1% on Tuesday.
The market-share shift comes as Macau's overall gambling revenue continues to shrink. In November, according to government figures, total revenue dropped nearly 20% to $3.94 billion.

"We believe China policy settings are negatively affecting growth, specifically: (1) visa restrictions (on tourists from inland China to the Macau special administrative district), (2) the anticorruption drive, (3) a pullback in credit and (4) a soft housing market," wrote Wells Fargo's McKnight in a report Tuesday. "We remain on the sidelines as uncertainty remains high."
In November, total "mass" market revenue — middle-class tourists — fell 13% vs. a year earlier in Macau, and the volume of junkets plunged 31%, McKnight said.

So-called junket operators bring gamblers to Macau, especially affluent "VIP"-category high rollers, often lending them money to get around local restrictions on how much cash can be brought into Macau.
The Chinese government has cracked down on the lending practice as part of a broad "anticorruption" campaign, arresting several junket operators earlier this year on charges of money laundering.
VIP revenue fell 24% for the month, McKnight said.

Gambling revenue in Macau fell nearly 20% on a year-over-year basis to $3.94 billion in November, continuing a downward trend that began last summer.
The greater than expected drop also drove down shares of Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and other Macau-centric casinos on Monday.
The Macau gaming inspection bureau reported the raw number and will release a detailed breakdown later this week.
According to bureau figures, after Macau gambling revenue shrank by single digits monthly from June to August, it plunged 23.2% in October before sliding 19.6% in November.

Gambling revenue in Macau has fallen amid a government crackdown on junket operators who lend money to gamblers, tighter restrictions on visas for Chinese tourists to visit the special administrative district and a new smoking ban in casinos.
Las Vegas Sands shares were down 3.9% in early afternoon trading on the stock market today.
MGM Resorts International (MGM) was down 2.4% and Wynn Resorts (WYNN) dipped 2.1%. Hong Kong-based Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) was down 3%.

December growth might also disappoint, Wells Fargo Securities analyst Cameron McKnight stated in a report, due to President Xi Jinping's visit to Macau. "Historically, December gaming revenue has seasonally improved 6% month over month, implying a 23% year-over-year decline, based on current November trends," he said.
McKnight projects that December revenue could fall 25%, based on November trends, which would be below consensus.

The touted recent interest rate cut by Beijing is a signal that China's economy is worsening, McKnight said. "Reports suggest that People's Bank of China officials do not view the rate cut as a change in the Central Bank's monetary policy."
He added that recent key monthly data out of the Middle Kingdom "suggest that China's economic growth continues to decelerate."
Sterne Agee analyst David Bain agreed.
"President Xi Jinping's visit to Macau is likely to disrupt the gaming appetite of some VIP (high roller) and premium mass (affluent tourist) players," Bain said.
Sterne Agee forecasts a 23%-28% drop in Macau gambling revenue in December.

Analysts began warning this past spring that a summer slowdown would impact Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and other Macau-centric casinos. But the slump has dragged on, and a report out Tuesday forecasts the downturn will extend into 2015. "We continue to forecast mostly negative high- to mid-single digit growth declines for early next year," Sterne Agee analyst David Bain said.…
Hedge fund manager Jim Chanos warned that he expects overcapacity will squeeze profits for Macau-centric casinos such as Las Vegas Sands (LVS).
Sands and other casino stocks shrugged off the reports as casino stocks staged a strong rally early Friday.

"I think estimates are going to come down," Chanos, founder and managing partner of Kynikos Associates, was cited as saying in various reports. "The stuff that is being built, as that's happening, the revenues have now turned down due to credit crunch, corruption, all the things we've been talking about. Take your pick."
The small city of Macau on China's southern coast became the world's top gambling destination after China opened the door for Las Vegas-based casinos to build there.
Analysts began warning of a slowdown last spring on a convergence of negatives.

China's economic growth cooled. China's government tightened regulations, reined in credit rates and launched a massive anti-corruption campaign that included a cracking down on lenders in Macau that provide funds to gamblers.
Democracy protests in nearby Hong Kong last summer curbed travel to and from that island, further cooling Macau gambling, as did a smoking ban that recently went into effect.

Revenue and earnings for Sands, MGM Resorts International (MGM), Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and Hong Kong-based Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) could be curbed after massive building in Macau has created what could be a glut, Chanos said.
Sands was up 1.7% in Friday morning trading in the stock market todayhttps://www.investors.com/stock-market-today/ , although it's down 29% from a 2014 high of 88.28 on March 7.
MGM rose 2.2%, Wynn Resorts 1% and Melco Crown Entertainment 2%.

The Nevada Gaming Control Board said Tuesday that September gambling revenue for the Las Vegas Strip fell 12% to $495 million, led by a whopping 30% decline in Baccarat revenue as high-roller…

Macau-centric casinos such as Las Vegas Sands got a glimmer of hope Friday in a report that the number of visitors to the world's most popular gaming destination rose to 2.41 million, up 3% last month vs. the same month a year earlier .But it's unclear whether the rise in visitors will translate into a revenue increase for Macau casinos.The report comes ahead of Wynn Resorts' (WYNN) third-quarter earnings, slated for Tuesday after the market closes.The consensus of 19 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters is for Wynn to report $1.84 earnings per share for the September-ending quarter, unchanged from a year ago, and a 1.8% drop in revenue to about $1.37 billion.Like Las Vegas Sands (LVS), MGM Resorts International (MGM) and Hong Kong-based Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL), Wynn gets the bulk of its revenue from its Macau casinos.Macau finance secretary Francis Tam, in an interview with Macau radio and TV broadcaster Teledifusao de Macau, last week forecast the city's drop in casino revenue will worsen in October, and projected that recovery won't come until the second half of 2015.Meanwhile, the number of visitors from inland China to Macau, on China's southern coast across the strait from Hong Kong, rose 6% to nearly 1.6 million last month, macaubusiness.com reported, citing government figures.The number of visitors from South Korea and Japan rose, too. But the numbers from Hong Kong and Taiwan fell amid recent democracy protests in Hong Kong that curbed travel to and from the island.Investors are looking for any sign of upturn in the battered casino sector after stocks plunged over the summer and the downturn extended into fall.The slump in Macau came as China's economic growth slowed, and China's government tightened credit rules and cracked down on casinos amid a broad anti-corruption campaign. A smoking ban on Macau casinos that goes into effect this month also turned off some gamblers.June showed the first year-over-year monthly decline in Macau gambling revenue in five years. Revenue has now fallen an unprecedented five months in a row, according to Macau's Gaming Inspection and Coordination Bureau.Wynn shares were up fractionally in Friday-afternoon trading on the stock market today.Sands, the world's largest casino company, rose more than 6% on Oct. 16 after it lifted its dividend 30% and reported higher Q3 earnings but lower revenue, missing estimates on both. It's since dropped back a bit and was down 1% Friday afternoon.MGM Resorts rose 0.6%, and Melco Crown edged lower.Follow James DeTar on Twitter: @IBD_JDeTar.

What at first looked like a summer hiccup for Macau-centric casinos such as Las Vegas Sands (LVS) is quickly turning into a long-term slump. Shares of Sands, which is slated to report third quarter earnings after the market closes Wednesday, fell to a 52-week low early Tuesday. But the stock recovered for a modest advance in the afternoon amid a…

MGM Resorts International's (MGM) balanced portfolio of casinos in Las Vegas and Macau, the world's top two gaming spots, has helped make it the apparent favorite casino company of the moment, as it got a second stock rating upgrade this week.

Craig-Hallum analyst Bryan Maher upgraded MGM to buy from hold Thursday, citing MGM's improving fundamental trends and saying investor sentiment on Macau is at "maximum pessimism," which indicates a bottom is near. Maher maintained a 28 price target.

The upgrade came after Deutsche Bank on Tuesday raised its rating on MGM to buy from hold and lifted its price target to 30 from 29. Deutsche Bank analyst Carlo Santarelli also downgraded Las Vegas Sands (LVS), the world's largest casino company, to hold from buy and cut its price target to 65 from 74.

Shares of Macau-centric casinos including MGM, Sands, Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and Hong Kong-based Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) were pounded over the summer as Macau posted its first multi-month gambling revenue decrease in years.

The slump resulted largely from a crackdown by China's government on junket operators in Macau who allegedly made illegal loans to gamblers. The crackdown made some gamblers stay away. More recently, pro-democracy demonstrations in Hong Kong, just across the strait from Macau, may have driven some business away.
Maher said MGM, the biggest casino operator in Las Vegas, is poised to grow.
"I wouldn't call it robust, but there has been a healthy increase in gaming revenue of 5% in Las Vegas on a trailing 12 months basis," Maher told IBD.
But the real story is Macau, which generated just above $45 billion in gaming revenue last year, roughly six times that of Las Vegas.
Recent reports indicate the Chinese government may be scaling back its broad "misbehavior" crackdown.
"If the Chinese government takes its foot off the throttle on misbehavior to any degree, it will resonate to a degree throughout the (Macau) market" in a positive way, Maher said.
And China has good incentive to throttle back.
"I would submit that with a tax rate in Macau of 39.2% the Chinese government has an extremely vested interest in making sure it thrives," Maher said.
Maher noted that visits to Macau during its Golden Week celebration, which began Oct. 1, rose 17%.

"That caught people by surprise. With protests in Hong Kong there was thought it would be weak. But people bypassed Hong Kong and went to Macau. And people in Hong Kong may have gone to Macau to get away from demonstrations," Maher said.
MGM shares were down 1.8% in Thursday afternoon trading on the stock market today amid a sector selloff. Sands was down 2%, Wynn 2.4% and Melco Crown 1.6%.

Shares of Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and other Macau-centric casinos climbed early Monday after Macau said September gambling revenue was in line with estimates, an indicator of improvement after a steep drop over the summer.

Macau casinos have seen revenue decline for four months in a row amid a crackdown by Chinese officials on the practice of some junket operators who lend money to gamblers in the special gambling district on China's southern coast.
More recently, pro-democracy protests in Hong Kong — just across the straits — and associated travel bans caused visitors to stay away over the summer after years of surging growth.
Total casino revenue fell 12% to $3.2 billion last month, a bit better than the projected 12%-13% decline from the same month a year ago, Macau officials reported.
Roughly 20% to 25% of Chinese tourists go to Macau and Hong Kong on the same trip, Bloomberg quoted Deutsche Bank analyst Karen Tang saying.
Wells Fargo analyst Cameron McKnight projected October revenue will be down 19% from the comparable month in 2013, lower than Wall Street's outlook for a mid-teens decline.

"Of note, Golden Week visitation was up 14% year over year vs. August visitation growth of 12% year over year," McKnight said in a report, referring to the Golden Week celebration that begins Oct. 1 each year and usually lifts gambling revenue in Macau.

Sands shares were up 1.2% in Monday morning trading on the stock market today. Wynn Resorts (WYNN) 1.4, MGM Resorts International (MGM) surged 1.1% and Hong Kong-based Melco Crown International (MPEL) 5%.

Just when it looked like Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and others might see an upturn from a deep summer slump, Hong Kong protests have taken some of the wind out of their sails.
Macau was looking to Golden Week, a two-week celebration that starts on Oct. 1 every year, to boost revenue this month.
But Hong Kong protests, labor unrest in Macau, an ongoing anticorruption campaign and other factors threaten to derail Macau's recovery, at least for now.

Hundreds of casino workers in Macau walked off the job on Friday, Voice of America said. The report quoted a union leader there saying workers are demanding higher wages and better benefits. It was the latest in a wave of labor unrest to hit casinos facing shrinking revenues.

Still, shares of Las Vegas casinos that operate in Macau, including Sands, MGM Resorts International (MGM) and Wynn Resorts (WYNN) rose Friday afternoon. They've stabilized a bit recently amid a slowly accelerating recovery in Las Vegas and a rising number of casinos in various states besides Nevada.

Wells Fargo analyst Cameron McKnight said in a report Friday that Macau casinos are in trouble in part on protests in — and travel suspensions to and from — Hong Kong amid continuing protests by pro-democracy activists to persuade the government to open local elections to all candidates.
"Investor sentiment (on Macau-centric casinos) is definitely more negative/cautious than a month ago, though we don't feel we're at the bottom," McKnight said.
Many investors also misread a report in China Daily on Tuesday that said "a campaign to put a check on misbehavior by party officials may just be ending," he said.

The campaign that's ending was just one facet of a larger anticorruption drive by China's Communist Party that also targets Macau junket operators who lend money to high rolling VIPs in Macau, he said.
Gamblers get loans from junket operators to get around Chinese rules that strictly limit the amount of cash visitors can bring into Macau.

Wells Fargo's checks with Macau contacts suggest "the anticorruption drive could ramp and persist for some time." As a result, VIPs who account for a large portion of Macau casino profits are likely to stay away for some time to come.
And a smoking ban about to go into effect in Macau casinos will "be strictly enforced" and could drive other gamblers away.
Sands shares were up 2% to 63.16 in Friday afternoon trading in the stock market today. The world's largest casino company has fallen about 29% from a 2014 high of 88.28 on March 7.

MGM and Wynn were both up more than 1%. Hong Kong based Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL), another Macau casino operator, rose less than 1%. Morgan Stanley on Friday downgraded Melco Crown from overweight (buy) to equal weight (hold) with a 28 price target.
