The report quoted a union leader there saying workers are demanding higher wages and better benefits. It was the latest in a wave of labor unrest to hit casinos facing shrinking revenues.Still, shares of Las Vegas casinos that operate in Macau, including Sands, MGM Resorts International (MGM) and Wynn Resorts (WYNN) rose Friday afternoon. They've stabilized a bit recently amid a slowly accelerating recovery in Las Vegas and a rising number of casinos in various states besides Nevada.Wells Fargo analyst Cameron McKnight said in a report Friday that Macau casinos are in trouble in part on protests in — and travel suspensions to and from — Hong Kong amid continuing protests by pro-democracy activists to persuade the government to open local elections to all candidates."Investor sentiment (on Macau-centric casinos) is definitely more negative/cautious than a month ago, though we don't feel we're at the bottom," McKnight said.Many investors also misread a report in China Daily on Tuesday that said "a campaign to put a check on misbehavior by party officials may just be ending," he said.The campaign that's ending was just one facet of a larger anticorruption drive by China's Communist Party that also targets Macau junket operators who lend money to high rolling VIPs in Macau, he said.Gamblers get loans from junket operators to get around Chinese rules that strictly limit the amount of cash visitors can bring into Macau.Wells Fargo's checks with Macau contacts suggest "the anticorruption drive could ramp and persist for some time." As a result, VIPs who account for a large portion of Macau casino profits are likely to stay away for some time to come.And a smoking ban about to go into effect in Macau casinos will "be strictly enforced" and could drive other gamblers away.Sands shares were up 2% to 63.16 in Friday afternoon trading in the stock market today. The world's largest casino company has fallen about 29% from a 2014 high of 88.28 on March 7.MGM and Wynn were both up more than 1%. Hong Kong based Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL), another Macau casino operator, rose less than 1%. Morgan Stanley on Friday downgraded Melco Crown from overweight (buy) to equal weight (hold) with a 28 price target.Follow James DeTar on Twitter: @IBD_JDeTar.

A campaign by the Chinese government that roiled the Macau gambling market appears to be coming to an end, which could help Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and other casinos in the world's top global gaming destination.Casinos in the special administrative district on China's southern coast have been battered in recent months as revenue fell for perhaps the first time since China opened the door to foreign casinos in 2002.Investors eager for any positive news after the summer slump bid shares up Tuesday.A perfect storm of negatives has impacted Sands and other Macau-centric casinos such as MGM Resorts International (MGM) and Wynn Resorts (WYNN) .China's economic growth has slowed this year. China cracked down on what it said were illegal lending practices in Macau, and new rules including a smoking ban in casinos have driven some players away.Chinese officials arrested some lenders in Macau earlier this year, saying they illegally used the government-sanctioned credit-card system to get around rules that limit how much cash Chinese citizens can bring into the former Portuguese colony.The crackdown made some gamblers uncomfortable, analysts said, so they stayed away.Chinese newspaper China Daily on Tuesday said a campaign to put a check on misbehavior by Chinese party officials may be ending."The campaign has reached its goals," the report quoted the Communist Party of China saying in a statement. The report noted that "lavish banquets and entertainment at VIP clubs," such as those at Macau casino resorts, were targets of the crackdown.Las Vegas casinos also may have gotten a boost from a Bloomberg report that a Japanese lawmaker backing a bill to legalize casinos in that country said he expects the bill to win approval in Japan's lower house as early as next month.Casinos have plans on the drawing board to build Macau-like casino resorts there if the bill passes.Sands shares were up 4.3% in afternoon trading on the stock market today. They had tumbled 32% from a 2014 high 88.28 set on March 7. Wynn climbed 5.3% and MGM 3.2%. Hong Kong-based Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL), another top Macau casino company, rose 3.7%.Follow James DeTar on Twitter: @IBD_JDeTar.

MGM Resorts International (MGM) shares gapped up to nearly a one-year high intraday Thursday after reporting strong third-quarter earnings and saying it will shift its casino properties into a real estate investment trust.Under pressure from activist shareholders, the casino company announced the formation of the REIT during its earnings call, saying it will put real-estate associated with 10 of its properties into the new company, to be called MGM Growth Properties (MGP).The move is an apparent win for real-estate investment firm Land & Buildings, which has a 0.4% stake in MGM Resorts.In April, Land & Buildings put forth four candidates for MGM's board in a push to split MGM into a casinos company and a landholding company. Land & Buildings dropped its bid for the board seats in May after failing to gain sufficient support from other investors but continued to push for the split-up.Wells Fargo analyst Cameron McKnight said the REIT came as a surprise."We're still working through the math," McKnight said in a report, adding that the 10 properties in the REIT will include seven in Las Vegas and three regional casinos: MGM Grand Detroit, Beau Rivage in Biloxi, Miss., and Gold Strike Tunica in Tunica, Miss.MGP will assume about $4 billion of debt, which MGM Resorts expects to refinance with proceeds of debt and equity issuance.MGM also submitted a registration form to the Securities and Exchange Commission related to MGP's proposed initial public offering. It expects to complete the REIT formation in Q1 2016.MGM's revenue and earnings have plunged over the last year, as have those of rivals Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and Las Vegas Sands (LVS) amid a sharp pullback in in Macau, the world's top gambling destination.For Q3, MGM earned 12 cents per share amid continuing steady growth in Las Vegas, tripling the 4-cent profit that analysts expected and reversing a 2-cent per-share loss in Q3 2014.Revenue fell 8.1% to $2.28 billion, below the $2.3 billion Wall Street consensus.

"Star Trek Beyond," "Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows" and the entire James Bond franchise are among the films set to be available on Tencent (TCEHY), reflecting the company's escalating battle with rivals Alibaba (BABA) and Baidu (BIDU) for online-video dominance in China.

Tencent, China's leader in online social-media and gaming, said Friday it will become the exclusive online provider in China — in both transactional video on demand and subscription video on demand — for new Paramount Pictures films beginning in April.
Tencent also said Friday that it acquired the online rights to the James Bond franchise from MGM, making it the only company in China to offer the titles online.

Tencent's rights to be Paramount's exclusive online distributor in China will last for a year after new films first hit theaters. Users will be able to watch those and the Bond titles via Tencent's video app and other platforms.

Paramount's "Star Trek Beyond" is set to appear on screens next year, around the 50th anniversary of the space drama's debut on TV. Other highly awaited films include "Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows" and "Jack Reacher: Never Go Back," Tencent noted in a statement.
Tencent shares finished up 1% in the stock market today. Viacom (VIAB), which owns Paramount, closed up 2%.

As China's middle class has grown, the film market there is set to dislodge the U.S. as the world's biggest in the coming years, triggering a race among other Internet giants to attract viewers who increasingly consume films online.
In recent weeks, Comcast's (CMCSA) Universal Pictures signed a multiyear deal allowing Baidu's online video service iQiyi to offer new Universal movies, an expansion of an existing pact.
And e-commerce giant Alibaba on Friday said it would take over Youku Tudou (YOKU), another online video provider in China.

And speaking of "Star Trek," CBS (CBS) said this week that it will run an entirely new "Star Trek" series starting in 2017 on its online streaming service CBS All Access, which already offers all old "Star Trek" TV episodes.
CBS' move has been seen as an attempt to compete with Amazon's (AMZN) Prime Video and Netflix (NFLX), whose own plans on how to compete in China remain uncertain.

The world's largest restaurant chain, McDonald's (MCD), is close to deciding what to do with its real estate holdings, amid calls for a spinoff of those assets into a real estate investment trust.Board member Miles White, who is chairman and CEO of diversified medical products maker Abbott Laboratories (ABT), told the Wall Street Journal in an interview that the fast-food giant has done a lot of due diligence but hasn't yet made a final decision.McDonald's shares changed little in extended-hours trading Thursday after rising 0.8% in the regular session on the stock market today.As customers have shifted away from McDonald's to fast-casual chains such as Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG), some investors and analysts have pushed for a REIT.In fact, McDonald's has been mulling taking action on its real estate as part of a broad restructuring undertaken by new CEO Steve Easterbrook, who took the reins in March.In May, Easterbrook said that McDonald's would examine "all opportunities" and might look at spinning off real estate assets or creating a REIT structure.Other companies have faced similar calls to spin off their real estate. MGM Resorts International (MGM) has been under pressure from shareholder Land and Buildings Investment to sell real estate.Sears (SHLD) spun off its property into Seritage Growth Properties (SRG). And several hedge funds asked Macy's (M) to consider options for its real estate.Follow James DeTar on Twitter @IBD_JDeTar and Facebook.

Stocks reversed higher in early afternoon trading after starting off with steep losses on the heels of a disappointing September job report. The Nasdaq led with a 0.7% gain while the S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average were each up 0.5%. Volume was tracking slightly higher in the stock market today vs. the same time Thursday.Gold miners, casino operators and biotechs were among the session's top gainers. Casino stocks gained despite a 33% year-over-year drop in Macau gambling revenue in September, on a Bloomberg report the Chinese government may take steps to support the once-hot gambling enclave's economy.Wynn Resorts (WYNN) led with a 18% jump, Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) soared 13%, Las Vegas Sands (LVS) 10% and MGM Resorts International (MGM) 4%. All four stocks are still well below their 52-week highs.Bank stocks sagged as a disappointing September job report fueled uncertainty over when the Federal Reserve will hike interest rates. Goldman Sachs (GS) and JPMorgan Chase (JPM) continued to weigh on the Dow, down about 1% each."(The job report) likely rules out an increase in the fed funds rate when the FOMC next meets in late October, and a mid-December rate increase now looks less likely," PNC Senior Economist Gus Faucher said in note. "Financial markets are now pricing in the first increase in the funds rate in March."But Pfizer (PFE) reversed upward for a 3% gain in heavy volume, on track for a fourth straight advance. The drugmaker on Wednesday said it expects its recently completed buy of Hospira to boost 2015 EPS by 3 cents a share and revenue by $1.5 billion. It guided profit of $2.04-$2.10 per share on revenue of $46.5 billion to $47.5 billion.Among IBD 50 stocks, NetEase (NTES) led with a 4% gain, nearly reclaiming its 50-day moving average, where it's found resistance since mid-August. Cambrex (CBM), Dave & Buster's (PLAY) and Edwards Lifesciences (EW) were each up 3%.Follow Nancy Gondo on Twitter @IBD_NGondo.

The big bets that Las Vegas casino operators have placed on Macau have been drawing some unlucky cards. Macau is the world's largest gambling region and the only place in China where gambling is legal. Gross gaming revenue topped $44 billion in 2014, while Las Vegas pulled in $6.4 billion. The Macau gambling trade was, for 40 years, a monopoly…

Mutual funds are hot on U.S. casinos Pinnacle Entertainment (PNK) and Isle of Capri Casinos (ISLE), which are outperforming giants such as Las Vegas Sands that are suffering from a slump in Macau. IBD's Screen Of The Day is Accelerating Mutual Fund Ownership, highlighting the stocks that mutual funds have been diving into for the past three quarters. Pinnacle and…
In addition to being affected by the market's volatility, Netflix (NFLX) shares are getting hit hard in the stock market today as competition in the streaming space heats up.

Variety reported late Monday that Apple (AAPL) has had early talks with Hollywood executives about obtaining original content to go along with its not-yet-announced streaming service. It's not yet apparent whether Apple would develop movies and/or TV shows, create an in-house studio or work with outside production companies, as Netflix has.

Netflix gapped down 8.6% in fast trade, falling back below its 50-day moving average. It's on track for its third straight session of losses. Shares are now about 18% below their all-time high of 129.29, reached on August 5.
Apple shares were also trading lower, down 2.4%.

Netflix is looking to expand its own original content. It confirmed over the weekend that it was dropping its deal with Epix, a joint venture of Lions Gate Entertainment (LGF), Viacom (VIAB)-owned Paramount and MGM. That means no more "Hunger Games: Catching Fire" or "Transformers: Age of Extinction," among other high-profile flicks, at the end of September.

But the streaming site noted that it has Adam Sandler and Judd Apatow original movies in the pipeline. And starting next year, Netflix says, it will be the home for the latest movies from Disney (DIS), including its upcoming Pixar, Lucasfilm and Marvel films.

The company's decision not to renew its agreement with Epix opened up an opportunity for rival Hulu to become the cable network's partner. Disney, Comcast (CMCSA) and 21st Century Fox (FOXA) own Hulu. Amazon (AMZN) also has a deal with Epix.

Overseas markets beckon for U.S. media and entertainment companies amid hand-wringing over the state of the U.S. pay-TV industry. Media companies face cord-cutting and loss of traditional TV subscribers as millennials flock to Web streaming and on-demand viewing. So there's upside in taking content abroad and investing in untapped markets.

"International growth is important as it offsets a slowing U.S. market," said Michael Nathanson, an analyst at MoffettNathanson. "The biggest headroom for international growth could be found at Fox due to India, Disney due to China and Discovery from Eurosport," he told IBD.

Discovery, with 51% of 2014 revenue outside the U.S., has the most international exposure. 21st Century Fox (FOXA) garnered 33% of revenue from beyond our shores in 2014, followed by Time Warner (TWX) at 30%, Viacom (VIA) at 26%, Disney at 25%, AMC Networks (AMCX) at 20% and CBS (CBS) at 13%, says Nathanson.
Other analysts point to overseas growth for Time Warner, from its HBO channel as well as Turner International, which has expanded kids and news programming in Latin America and Asia.
AMC Networks in early 2014 acquired Chellomedia, the international channel unit of pan-European cable giant Liberty Global, for $1 billion.

AMC has rebranded Chellomedia's MGM channel and other programming. AMC on Aug. 23 launched "Fear the Walking Dead," its sequel to a zombie TV show hit, in more than 120 countries, aiming to boost its international brand.

Disappointing earnings guidance, weak summer audience ratings, Walt Disney's (DIS) warning over slowing revenue growth from affiliate fees, and Discovery Communications' (DISCA) move to hit the brakes on stock buy-backs all combined to torch media stocks in early August.
While the ranks of doomsayers are growing, Sanford Bernstein analyst Todd Juenger says concern is justified.

"The market is now valuing U.S. ad-supported TV businesses as structurally impaired assets," Juenger said. "When an industry is undergoing a massive structural upheaval — one major revenue stream is already impaired and now there are signs the second one may be as well — investors won't wait for final conclusive evidence to re-evaluate how much they are willing to pay for the existing status-quo cash flow streams."

While analysts expect international growth to provide an incremental boost to some U.S. media companies, none seem on the same trajectory as Web video streamer Netflix (NFLX), whose subscriber growth is expected to come mostly from overseas. Netflix's services are expected to be available in markets covering 385 million broadband households by the end of 2016, making them possible customers, says Pacific Crest Securities.

Media company management was keen to tout international prospects on Q2 earnings calls, says Anthony DiClemente, a Nomura Securities analyst. Time Warner noted that HBO's pay-TV service is available to only 10% of 750 million potential global pay-TV viewers.

"Given headwinds in the U.S. market, companies pointed to international growth," DiClemente said in a report. "Owing to expanded use of subscription VOD services in several markets, management teams are increasingly shifting focus as well as investments toward international markets."
While currency exchange rates pose a near-term issue for media companies as the dollar strengthens, they still aim to prosper from long-term trends.
For Fox, India looms as a growth market as incomes rise, making broadband and ad-supported TV services more affordable for consumers.

In India, Fox owns TV service Star India as well as a new Web streaming business called Hot Star. The ad-supported streaming platform lets users watch live TV shows, cricket and on-demand content for free.
While Fox has been investing heavily in sports rights for Star India, it was rewarded in April when the Cricket World Cup garnered record TV and online digital viewership.
Discovery also is betting on upside from sports.

Discovery in July acquired full ownership of Eurosport, which operates across the Continent and Asia. Eurosport recently paid $1.4 billion to acquire all the TV and digital platform rights for four Olympic Games, from 2018 through 2024.
Discovery took a 20% stake in Eurosport in 2012 and upped its investment to 51% two years later.

"Executing on its international prospects is now more important than ever to offset industry headwinds impacting U.S. advertising growth," said Amy Yong, a Macquarie Capital analyst, in a report on Discovery.
In December, Discovery aims to show its reach, broadcasting the documentary "Racing Extinction" in 220 international markets within a 24-hour period.

The core Discovery Channel has mustered improved ratings in India, Brazil and Mexico. But some analysts say Discovery's international business has matured, with advertising and programming fee growth slowing.

"Over the prior half-decade, core international growth in advertising has ranged from the high 20% range to high singles to low double digits. While we still view international as a longer-term growth opportunity, a combination of macroeconomic, geopolitical, competitive and acquisition headwinds is probably going to keep core international advertising growth at the low end of the range for the next several quarters," said David Bank, analyst at RBC Capital Markets in a report.
Discovery in August named a new president of international content, Marjorie Kaplan.
Disney, a diversified media company, still counts on sports channel ESPN for much of its profit. Even so, with U.S. costs rising, ESPN has pulled back on bidding for sports rights overseas.

Disney is expected to open a $5.5 billion theme park and resort in Shanghai in the spring of 2016. Disney has built the Shanghai theme park, much bigger than its older Hong Kong park, with a consortium of state-owned companies known as Shanghai Shendi Group. Disney has already opened its largest retail store at the Shanghai location. The new theme park will feature attractions based on Marvel comics and Star Wars, and others based on Chinese culture.Overseas markets beckon for U.S. media and entertainment companies amid hand-wringing over the state of the U.S. pay-TV industry. The spectacle of former child stars self-destructing has become so common as to be a cliche. The entertainer who defied that scenario was the girl whose star shone the brightest:Shirley Temple.Not that Temple, who dominated the Hollywood box office as a child during the Great Depression, didn't encounter hard times; she did.She had to cope with fickle moviegoers who lost interest in her when she reached adolescence.Her father, though loving and supportive, squandered her fortune on bad investments.There was a turbulent first marriage that ended in divorce and, later, a bout of breast cancer.But Temple enjoyed a solid second marriage and raised a family.And she became a diplomat and an ambassador to two countries.Solid StartHow did Temple avoid the conventional path of child stars?Part of it had to do with her mother's influence."I was absolutely bathed in love," Temple wrote of her relationship with her mother, Gertrude.All the while, Gertrude protected her daughter from lavish praise and undue criticism.The main ingredient of Temple's perseverance was her optimism. As her second husband, Charles Black, said about her in 1988, "I have participated in her life 24 hours a day through thick and thin, traumatic situations, exuberant situations, and I feel she has only one personality. She would be catastrophic for the psychiatric profession. ... What everybody has seen for 60 years is the bedrock."Temple (1928-2014) was born in Santa Monica, Calif. Her father, George, was a bank employee, her mother a homemaker.Shirley had two older brothers, but Shirley was the one whom Gertrude was intent on making a star.At age 3, Shirley was enrolled in a Los Angeles dancing school and was soon spotted by a casting director who gave her an audition and movie contract. Then it was off to acting, singing and modeling gigs.Precocious, dimpled and curly-haired, Shirley emerged onto the movie scene in 1932's "War Babies," part of the "Baby Burlesks" series of short films.At age 6, she starred in "Bright Eyes," where she won global fame and performed her signature song, "On the Good Ship Lollipop."Next came a string of hit films such as "Curly Top," "Little Miss Marker" and "Stand Up and Cheer!" Still 6 in early 1935, Shirley became the youngest actor to be honored by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts & Sciences when she won its first Juvenile Award.Temple was on a streak. From 1935 to 1938 she was Hollywood's No. 1 box-office draw, starring in such films as "The Littlest Rebel" and "Wee Willie Winkie."It's tough to overstate Temple's immense popularity in the last half of the 1930s. She was said to have been photographed more often than President Franklin Roosevelt during those years. Her fan clubs comprised 384 branches, with nearly 4 million members.Face TimeTemple look-alike contests were held across the globe.And at the hysteria's height, the name Shirley rose from the 10th most popular baby name in the country to No. 2.Temple commanded today's equivalent of close to $1 million a movie before she turned 10 years old — on the way to what's worth $50 million now in earnings before she hit puberty. Her studio, 20th Century Fox, cashed in with $350 million in today's money.Temple's ascendancy in Hollywood coincided with the rise of the consumer culture in America.She endorsed numerous products: dolls and other toys, breakfast cereal, clothing lines, even items made by General Electric (GE).Her dolls alone generated $45 million (worth $725 million now) in sales before 1941.By the mid-1930s, her income from licensed merchandise royalties came to today's equivalent of $1.7 million a year.As John Kasson put it in his book "The Little Girl Who Fought the Great Depression," "Shirley Temple's films, products and endorsements collectively stimulated the American consumer economy at a crucial time, so much so that to some she appeared to be a relief program all by herself."Temple's box office appeal began to fade as she moved into adolescence and turned in a couple of subpar performances.Slide And ComebackA bump in her road came in 1940 when 20th Century Fox terminated her contract.Temple then signed with MGM Studios and made other screen appearances, but never recaptured the critical or popular acclaim of her childhood.Her golden hair had turned brown, the wartime moviegoing tastes had turned to action and adventure films, and her stardom was eclipsed by that of other young actresses such as Judy Garland.Temple retired from acting at age 22, declaring, "Enough of pretend."Temple's late teens and early 20s were a tumultuous time. She married Army Air Forces Sgt. John Agar when she was 17. The couple had a daughter, Linda. Agar became a professional actor, and the couple made two movies together before divorcing after four years.Not long after, she met and married Charles Black, a World War II Navy intelligence officer and Silver Star recipient. That marriage would last 55 years until his death in 2005. The Blacks had a son, Charles Jr., in 1952 and a daughter, Lori, in 1954.Around this time, Temple learned that her father had wasted her millions on faulty investments.Temple responded with levelheadedness. "I felt neither disappointment nor anger," she later wrote about the revelation.All these experiences kept Temple grounded. "I think having a child, and finding herself broke and having to work in her early 20s kept her head on straight, as did a feckless first husband," Kathy Fuller-Seeley, a film professor at the University of Texas, told IBD. "As did finding her really strong second husband, a military fellow who kept her busy raising a family."After an unsuccessful run for Congress in 1967, Temple launched a diplomatic career, joining the Foreign Service and representing the U.S. at the United Nations under President Nixon.She served as ambassador to Ghana under President Ford, then as the first female chief protocol officer of the U.S. — in which she was responsible for advising the president and Cabinet members on global diplomatic procedures.Meanwhile, Temple faced down physical disaster. In 1972 she was diagnosed with breast cancer and became one of the first women to speak openly about the disease. She even held a press conference in her hospital room and encouraged women to get checked for lumps in their breasts.Temple underwent a mastectomy, with the cancer removed.From 1989 to 1991, with another Republican, George H.W. Bush, in the White House, Temple served as ambassador to Czechoslovakia and was present during the Velvet Revolution, in which dissident poet Vaclav Havel became the nation's first democratically elected president in four decades.In her later years, Temple was on numerous boards of corporations, including Disney (DIS), Del Monte Foods and Bank of America (BAC).When she died at age 85, Temple was hailed by many as the most popular child star in Hollywood history. Her immense popularity was partly a product of her ability to raise the spirits of a nation during soaring unemployment."Shirley Temple was undoubtedly an astonishingly talented little girl as well as a delightfully cute one with a radiant personality and remarkable camera presence," said Kasson. "Yet crucial to her achievement as the greatest child star in history was her historical timing. Her breakthrough came in 1934 during the depths of the Great Depression, when the American public craved figures of confidence, hope and cheer. Like FDR, she exuded optimism."Kasson explained in his book, "In all of her major roles in the 1930s Shirley's central task was emotional healing. ... Amid gloom, she encouraged everyone to keep on the sunny side of life."John Belton, a film professor at Rutgers University, also notes that cheer as the secret to her screen triumph: "Temple quite often played a destitute orphan with no interest in wealth or fame, whose only desire was for a stable family with which to share her boundless optimism for the future."It was a bright outlook that Temple also rode to off-screen heights."I don't like to do negatives," she said. "There are always pluses to things."

Shares of Las Vegas Sands (LVS) climbed more than 5% intraday Monday, the biggest one-day gain this year, on a Macau Business report that Macau may back off of its proposed full ban on smoking in casinos.
The report also lifted other Macau-centric casino resort companies including Wynn Resorts (WYNN), MGM Resorts International (MGM) and Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL).
The move gave investors relief from a prolonged drop in casino stocks amid a slump in the world's most popular casino gambling destination.

Macau, a special administrative district in China, with a strong local government like Hong Kong's, has already limited smoking to smoking rooms and VIP gaming areas and is considering a full smoking ban

But Macau Business said Alexis Tam Chong Weng, Macau's secretary of social affairs and culture, told Macau's Legislative Assembly the government might let casinos retain smoking rooms if the company can prove that its smoking rooms could protect employees and customers from harm by tobacco smoke.

Wells Fargo analyst Cameron McKnight said in a report Monday that, despite the proposed easing of the smoking ban, Macau is not flashing signs of recovery yet. He noted that casino operators would have to provide "empirical proof" that smoking rooms protect employees and customers.

McKnight is skeptical. "We expect additional color in the next few days, and continue forecasting July revenues down 30% to 32% year over year. We remain neutral as the market adjusts to a 'new normal' of: (1) tighter government oversight, (2) more muted medium-term industry revenue growth, and (3) a recovery that is likely to be flatter than prior rebounds," he said.

Macau casino revenues and profits have slumped for the last year amid weakening economic growth in China that's curbed visits from inland tourists, stricter regulation from China's central government and the smoking ban.
Las Vegas Sands shares rose 4.5% to 57.33 in afternoon trading on the stock market today.
The world's largest casino company's stock hit an all-time high at 88.28 in March 2014 and has fallen sharply since then, failing to form a viable base. It has recently been forming a cup base.
Wynn Resorts, the No. 2 casino company by revenue, was up 4.4%. MGM Resorts International rose 3.9% and Hong Kong-based Melco Crown Entertainment popped 5.8%.

With Cuba's doors now open again to American tourists, the island is looking a lot like Macau to a top Chinese developer. No one's rolling in the baccarat, blackjack, poker and roulette tables just yet. But speculation about whether Havana could again be a casino gaming capital, as it was before communism under Fidel Castro, has spread to the East.

Macau, an administrative region of China off Hong Kong, became the Las Vegas of Asia and then far surpassed the original in gambling receipts, taking in more than $15.2 billion in the first half of 2015 — and that's a lull from 2014.

After rule changes more than a decade ago, dozens of casinos arose in Macau. The peninsula includes casinos by Wynn Resorts (WYNN), Las Vegas Sands (LVS), MGM Resorts International (MGM) and Hong Kong-based Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) .
Cuba has parallels to Macau, the CEO of U.S. operations for China's largest real estate developer, Greenland Group, said at a recent real estate conference in Miami.
"It's a very short travel from here by ferry to Cuba," I-Fei Chang of Greenland USA said when asked whether Chinese developers might plan projects there.

The extent to which Cuba might again embrace casino projects is as yet unknown. But, Chang said, "I can foresee some business model like from Hong Kong ... a one-hour ferry to Macau, to build this Macau to be the casino and resort business."
Amid the red tape of longstanding sanctions, U.S. developers can't as yet build in Cuba. But China has closer ties — it's Cuba's biggest trading partner.

Havana is about 220 miles from Miami. A little more than 180 miles off Florida's coast, in the Bahamas, Chinese investors are involved in the four-hotel, $3.5 billion Baha Mar casino resort project, which filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in June.

Talks are underway this week to move the project forward after construction and money disputes. The general contractor is the China State Construction and Engineering Corporation, billed as the largest construction company in China, with some financing by the Export-Import Bank of China.
Chang said she didn't know of any Chinese developers planning work in Cuba, but she linked the issue of future Cuba development to Miami's own development.

"If Miami can continue its own investment to really build this great city to be a gateway city, not just the South Wall Street, I believe we have the opportunity to bring in more investors from Asia because then we'll have more direct flights from China, because more business will want to be here and more tourists too."

Chang, a Yale graduate, was in Miami to take an initial look at South Florida as her company surveys which American property developments to consider next. She addressed the National Association of Real Estate Editors' conference on June 26, five days before the U.S. announced the re-establishment of diplomatic relations with Cuba and its plans to reopen an embassy.

Greenland's U.S. unit is a joint-venture partner with Forest City Enterprises (FCEA) in the big Pacific Park (formerly Atlantic Yards) mixed-use project in Brooklyn, N.Y. It has put nearly $5 billion into the project, which entails 16 residential towers plus commercial and retail space. Greenland USA is also working on the Metropolis in downtown Los Angeles — three residential towers, a hotel and retail — in which it has invested $1.4 billion.

China's state-owned Greenland Group has more than $57 billion in assets worldwide, according to a Knight Frank report. In China, it is involved in building the world's third, fourth and seventh tallest buildings, among other projects.With Cuba's doors now open again to American tourists, the island is looking a lot like Macau to a top Chinese developer. Pinnacle Entertainment (PNK) stock climbed 6% early Tuesday after the company confirmed that it received a sweetened offer from Gaming and Leisure Properties (GLPI) for its land holdings and said that the two are negotiating.
The combination would create the third largest publicly traded triple-net real estate investment trust in the country, the companies said.

Smaller Gaming and Leisure Properties, with about $640 million in annual revenue vs. Pinnacle Entertainment's roughly $2.25 billion, raised its offer to $47.50 per share, or $5 billion, from $4.1 billion earlier.
Gaming and Leisure Properties originally approached Pinnacle in January about a possible land deal.

In March, Gaming and Leisure, itself a spinoff of Penn National Gaming (PENN), said its offer to discuss a deal was rebuffed and it then made a hostile $4.1 billion bid and said it planned to take the offer to the company's shareholders if Pinnacle refused to talk. Pinnacle said at the time it was willing to talk "under appropriate terms."

Pinnacle Entertainment owns and operates 16 casinos and race tracks in Nevada, Colorado, Indiana and five other states. The company said Tuesday that it will continue working through plans to separate its properties in a REIT.
The move comes amid a trend by casinos to leverage properties to create shareholder value by forming a REIT, often as a result of pressure from an activist investor.

MGM Resorts International (MGM) shares, for example, jumped early this year after shareholder Land & Buildings bid to put four people on MGM's board to force it to split the company in two and spin off its massive land holdings, possibly in a REIT. That effort failed and in late May Land & Buildings dropped its bid to gain board seats.

Pinnacle Entertainment stock climbed 95% from a Jan. 30 low to a 40.42 all-time high on April 14. The stock has traded in a narrow range since then and was near the high at 39.73, up 6% by early afternoon in the stock market today, Tuesday.
The company's stock has a near-best 96 IBD Composite Rating, meaning it has outperformed 96% of all stocks on key metrics in recent quarters.
Gaming and Leisure Properties shares were down 4%. Penn National was off less than 1%.

MGM Resorts International, the nation's second largest casino company behind global leader Las Vegas Sands (LVS), was down 1%. Like Las Vegas peers Sands and Wynn Resorts (WYNN), MGM has been hurt by a slump in Macau, where it has extensive holdings.

Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and other casino stocks staged a rare, brief rally after Chinese officials eased restrictions on travel to the gambling mecca, only to reverse Thursday on a fresh report of further tightening of restrictions. In a surprise move on Wednesday, Macau's regional government said starting on July 1 mainland China passports will enable Chinese visitors to stay…
Las Vegas Sands shares fell to the lowest point in more than a year, and other Macau-centric casinos dropped hard after Wells Fargo said that the dire situation in Macau is continuing to deteriorate.

The bank lowered its rating on the large-cap gaming sector from overweight to market weight, and cut its ratings on Las Vegas Sands (LVS), Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and Hong Kong-based Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) from outperform to market perform, citing a variety of factors including an upcoming investigative report on the Macau gambling industry.
Wells Fargo left its rating on MGM Resorts International (MGM) unchanged at market perform, saying that it's less at risk because of its huge casino resort holdings in Las Vegas.

The analyst report came after China's Finance Minister Lou Jiwei said over the weekend that economic growth in that country continues to face downward pressure. More ominously, Lou also said that the country doesn't plan any major policy changes in response to shrinking growth, dashing hopes for more stimulus.
Wells Fargo's Cameron McKnight said that Monday's ratings cuts were his fourth this year and came "after what we thought were fairly hefty cuts last month."
He reiterated that he's still bullish on Macau casinos long-term but added, "It's possible things will get worse before they stabilize and get better."

Three major negatives are at work, McKnight said. There's a shift in the mix away from affluent, high-margin "VIP" gamblers toward the high end of the middle-class "mass market" gamblers. China has tightened lending standards, cooling visits by VIPs, who often borrow heavily to play baccarat.

Second, various China policy initiatives are impacting Macau, including a crackdown by the government on alleged corruption among junket operators who bring visitors to Macau. And a pending partial smoking ban could cause some to stay away. An employee union has also said that it may call for a full smoking ban, further dampening enthusiasm for Macau.
Finally, China's economic growth has slowed, so tourist dollars from inland Chinese are drying up.

McKnight added that there are other negative events on the near horizon, especially an upcoming Frontline investigative report that was four years in the making and is due to air on PBS Sept. 30. A preview of the documentary said that hundreds of billions of dollars end up in Macau despite currency controls, with organized crime also involved.
Sands shares were down nearly 4% on the stock market today. It's down about 32% from a more than six-year high of 88.28 set on March 7.
Wynn was down nearly 3% and MGM a bit more than 3%. Melco Crown fell 3.4%.

Shares of Las Vegas Sands (LVS) jumped 3% early Friday, leading a sector surge after it said its Macau casinos will be full during Golden Week, a two-week Chinese celebration that begins Oct. 1.A spokeswoman for Sands China, a Chinese casino company controlled by Sheldon Adelson's Las Vegas Sands, told Bloomberg News that its hotel room booking rate is close to 100%. Macau, located on China's southern coast, is the world's largest and fastest growing casino resort destination.The report was a bright spot in what has been a dismal period for global casinos, both in Macau and No. 2 global gambling venue Las Vegas.Nevada gaming officials said Friday that Las Vegas Strip year-to-date gaming revenue as of Aug. 31 was down a bit more than 1% at $1.09 billion, vs. $1.1 billion a year ago.Gambling revenue for the state of Nevada, according to Nevada's Gaming Control Board, was 1.5% below a year ago, at $1.85 billion.Investors shrugged off the weak Las Vegas numbers and eagerly focused on the possibility of strong Golden Week revenue in Macau.Macau saw revenue fall in August for a third month in a row amid a slowdown in Chinese economic growth and a crackdown by Chinese officials on illegal lending practices in the special administrative district.MGM Resorts International (MGM), the largest casino operator in Las Vegas, was up 1.4% in Friday afternoon trading in the stock market today. Smaller peer Wynn Resorts (WYNN) rose 1.6%.Hong Kong-based Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) advanced 2.3%. Caesars Entertainment (CZR), which doesn't operate any casinos in Macau but is the largest casino operator in the U.S., was up more than 3%.Follow James DeTar on Twitter: @IBD_JDeTar.

The predicament for Macau-centric casinos like Las Vegas Sands (LVS) is worse than originally thought, according to various reports.Wells Fargo, Sterne Agee and other analysts began warning early this year of a summer slowdown in gambling revenue in Macau, the popular gambling hub on China's southern coast, across the strait from Hong Kong.But Morgan Stanley analysts, who just returned from a fact-finding trip to Macau on Monday, said Macau casinos have not found bottom yet and Macau casinos valuation "is not compelling."FBR Capital said Macau gambling revenue is on trajectory for a fourth straight monthly decline in September, and its first quarterly decline in years. FBR is looking for a midteens decline in September and said a recent sharp sell-off in casino stocks still hasn't revealed a possible bottom.Macau gambling revenue is weak amid sluggish China economic growth and a crackdown by Chinese officials on illegal lending practices in the former Portuguese colony.Additionally, a casino smoking ban that goes into effect in October, in a country where smoking is still popular among gamblers, is expected to cool enthusiasm for casino visits.Wells Fargo Securities analyst Cameron McKnight said Tuesday that, based on channel checks through Sept. 14, he expects September Macau revenue to be down in the midteens, worse than his prior estimate for a high single- to low double-digit decline."The Chinese economy and Macau continue to remain soft, and weak growth trends into Golden Week and the smoking ban may create additional uncertainty," McKnight said.China's two-week Golden Week holidays in early October usually generate a big chunk of Macau casinos' fall revenue.Official numbers aren't out yet, but Macau Business Daily estimated Macau gambling revenue slid 5% in the June-to-August quarter. Like others, that report cited China's weak economy and aggressive stance against corruption in Macau.Shares of Las Vegas Sands, the world's largest casino company, were down 2% in Tuesday afternoon trading on the stock market today. Sands' stock price has fallen 31% from a March 7 high of 88.28.Among other companies with casino resorts in Macau, Wynn Resorts (WYNN) was also down 2%, MGM Resorts International (MGM) slid 3% and Hong Kong-based Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) skidded 4%.Follow James DeTar on Twitter: @IBD_JDeTar.
Las Vegas Sands (LVS) stock was downgraded by Argus Research to hold from buy, but investors initially shrugged it off, as the company's share price barely budged.
Argus' downgrade for the world's largest casino resort company follows that of UBS and others amid a slump at the gambling enclave Macau on China's southern coast.
Macau, the top global gaming destination — and fastest growing — saw a rare shrinkage in gambling revenue growth over the summer.

Some gamblers, especially affluent VIPs, have stayed away due to a crackdown by the Chinese government on junket operators and pawn-shop lenders that China says use the government-backed debit/credit card system to illegally launder money.
But Wells Fargo analyst Cameron McKnight and others expect the slump in Macau to be brief, with a recovery as early as this year.

"Despite a choppy near-term outlook, we remain positive on Macau and LVS with the Macau market still significantly underpenetrated and expected to reach $100 billion of gaming revenues by 2018," which would nearly double last year's Macau gambling revenue, McKnight said in a client note last month.

Still, shares of Sands and other Macau-centric casinos such as MGM Resorts International (MGM), Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and Hong Kong-based Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) have fallen the last couple of months.
Sands, which is down about 28% since early March, had slipped less than 1% in midday trading in the stock market today, Thursday. MGM and Wynn were up more than 1% and Melco Crown climbed 3%.

Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and other Macau-centric casinos could be in trouble in the waning months of 2014 after Hong Kong, about 40 miles across the strait from Macau, on Friday cut its full-year economic forecast.

Hong Kong officials now see the economy expanding 2%-3% this year, down from a February projection of 3%-4% growth, after data showed gross Q2 domestic product fell 0.1% vs. the prior quarter, below analyst estimates.
Hong Kong Financial Secretary John Tsang said on his blog that purchases of watches, jewelry, electronics and other high-end goods fell sharply.
"Annual investment spending fell markedly; private consumption over the same period recorded only a slight increase," he said, adding performance for those sectors was the worst since Q1 of 2009.
Macau casino resorts rely on tourists from throughout China and nearby Asian countries, as well as affluent VIP customers from around the globe.

Gambling revenue for the world's top casino destination has contracted in recent months amid a perfect storm of factors. Among them: China has made it harder to get credit amid a deliberate belt-tightening.

And gamblers, especially VIPs, have shied away due to a crackdown by the Chinese government on junket operators and pawnshop lenders. China says some lenders use the government-backed debit/credit card system to illegally launder money.

Wells Fargo analyst Cameron McKnight, citing the government crackdown, began warning early this year that the second half would be choppy for Sands, Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and MGM Resorts International (MGM), which rely on Macau for the bulk of their revenue and growth.

On Friday, McKnight said the situation is deteriorating. "With slowing mass (middle-class tourist spending) growth in July and few signs of improvement in August, trends have turned from choppy to rocky," he said in a report.
Wells Fargo cut its stock price target for Sands from 90-100 to 80-85, and for Wynn from 260-270 to 245-250.
Additionally, "We are reducing our 2H14 Macau market total revenue growth estimate from 4% to -2% on lower mass market revenue growth assumptions," McKnight said.

Still, McKnight projects Macau casino growth will resume eventually as the effects of these factors are absorbed. "We remain bullish on the medium and long-term outlook. We see a $100 billion-plus Macau market over the next five years," up from about $50 billion currently, he said.
Sands shares were down 1.4% in midday trading in the stock market today. Wynn and MGM were both down about 1.5%. Hong Kong-based Melco Crown (MPEL) slid more than 3%.

Telsey Advisory Group analyst Chris Jones said Monday that the mass market segment in Macau — tourists and casual middle-class visitors — is also losing steam. And Las Vegas…

Despite predictions that a recovery in Macau's casinos could begin this year, there still appears to be no end in sight for the gambling mecca's losing streak. In fact, Wells Fargo analyst Cameron McKnight on Tuesday said that June gambling revenue for Macau could fall 30% to 40% annually to about $2 billion, which would be the lowest result for…
Isle of Capri Casinos (ISLE) stock climbed more than 20% in two days of trading since the St. Louis-based riverboat casino and racetrack company reported outstanding quarterly results.
Penn National Gaming (PENN), another casino company that operates in the U.S. but doesn't own properties in the global gambling mecca Macau, climbed nearly 5%.
Domestic casinos are outpacing their larger global peers.

The world's largest casino operator Las Vegas Sands (LVS), as well as MGM Resorts International (MGM) and Wynn Resorts (WYNN) all get the bulk of their growth from Macau, which generates annual gambling revenue about six times that of Las Vegas.

Macau, on China's southern coast, has been in a recession the past year amid tighter government regulations and shrinking economic growth in China. As a result, Sands and its peers have seen revenue growth shrink.

Isle of Capri Casinos, which operates a racetrack in Pompano Beach, Fla., and 15 casinos in the Midwest, South and East Coast, said Tuesday that fiscal fourth-quarter earnings jumped 71% to 58 cents a share, beating analyst estimates by 17 cents a share.
Revenue grew 5.3% to $274.6 million, topping views for $266.7 million.
Isle of Capri Casinos President and CEO Virginia McDowell said the company continues to invest in properties by renovating hotel rooms, restaurants and casinos.

"We broke ground on our land-based development at Bettendorf (Iowa) which we expect to open in early fiscal 2017," McDowell said. "We continue to optimize our marketing programs and are introducing new productivity tools in fiscal 2016 across the enterprise."
Isle of Capri Casinos shares shot up 7.7% to 19.39 on the stock market Wednesday.

Its stock has a powerful 92 IBD Composite Rating , meaning it's outperformed 92% of all stocks on key metrics such as sales and profit growth. It cleared a 15.49 buy point of a flat base Friday and continued rising. It was on track for its sixth straight higher close Wednesday.
Penn National Gaming, which boasts an 87 Composite Rating, rose 4.9% to 17.61, breaking out of a base.

Among top global casinos, Las Vegas Sands rose 0.6% Wednesday. Wynn Resorts was up 0.9%. MGM Resorts International, which is the largest casino operator in Las Vegas and less exposed to Macau, also advanced 0.9%.

Shares of Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and other top casinos jumped Thursday on a report that Macau, the world's top gambling destination, may be bottoming or at least stabilizing. Revenue figures for the month of May show some "green shoots," Credit Suisse analysts Kenneth Fong and Isis Wong said Thursday, based on May gambling revenue figures released by Macau officials earlier this week.The report noted that revenue for the high-end VIP category rose 3% from April while it climbed 9% in the larger mass-market middle-class and tourist group.Sands, the world's largest casino company, and top-rated in the casino group, gets the bulk of its growth from the resort city on China's southern coast. Sands shares were up 4.6% to 54.90 in midafternoon trading in the stock market today, Thursday.Sands reported year-over-year earnings per share growth until last quarter, when its EPS plunged 32%. Consensus is for EPS growth to continue shrinking the rest of this year. Still, Sands stock crossed above its 50-day line Thursday and was on track for a third straight higher close.Wynn Resorts (WYNN) was up 7% and MGM Resorts International (MGM), which is less exposed to Macau, rose 3%. Hong Kong-based Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL), another big casino company in Macau, climbed 7%.Like Credit Suisse, other market-watchers see light at the end of the tunnel after a yearlong Macau recession, triggered by slowing economic growth in China, tighter regulations by Chinese officials in the special administrative district, and a smoking ban that kept some gamblers away.Market-tracker Union Gaming Research noted Wednesday that Macau's gambling revenue remained soft in May, rising 6.2% overall from April but falling 37.1% from May 2014.Still, Union Gaming analyst Chris Jones said in a report that he sees some signs of stability ahead, with tailwinds starting in June."We continue to view June as a transitional month as trends should ... improve given the easier comparisons to June 2014."Wells Fargo analyst Cameron McKnight sees improvement in Macau but expects growth to be permanently lower than its earlier, boisterous growth days."Based on current trends, we believe June gaming revenue decline could be closer to 30% year over year. Given this weakness, we see downside risk to our Q2 and 2015 estimates. We remain neutral on Macau gaming as estimates and valuations adjust to a 'new normal' " of lower growth.Follow James DeTar on Twitter: @IBD_JDeTar.

Stocks traced thin losses early Thursday as investors largely looked toward what promises to be a big news day on Friday.
The Dow Jones industrial average and the Nasdaq dropped to fractional losses. The S&P 500 shaved off 0.3%, weighted by losses among energy and chemical stocks.

Factors affecting the stock market today include the Eurozone's dilemma over Greece's debt, which faces a steep hurdle in the form of a $334 million debt payment owed to the International Monetary Fund on Friday. That uncertainty has helped trigger a volatile week in global bond markets, a situation given an additional stir by comments Wednesday from European Central Bank President Mario Draghi.
Markets are also positioning for a U.S. payroll report for May and a meeting of the Organization for Petroleum Exporting Countries, both on Friday.
That being said, not much positioning is going on in the U.S. stock market, where the Nasdaq and S&P 500 remain in a tightly rangebound posture.

In economic news, layoff data were positive early Thursday. The Challenger Job Cuts Report announced a 23% year-over-year decline in job reductions, down 33% from an oil-spurred surge of layoffs in April. Weekly jobless claims declined 2%, in line with consensus forecasts, but first-quarter productivity and unit labor cost revisions from the Labor Department were worse than expected.

In stocks, dollar store chain Five Below (FIVE) surged 10% out of the starting gate. The Philadelphia-based retailer's earnings and revenue narrowly topped Q1 consensus views. Management reported 19 new stores opened during the quarter and said store growth remained its No. 1 priority. Five Below has been in a general uptrend since March, trying to haul itself out of an eight-month consolidation.

T-Mobile (TMUS) and Dish Network (DISH) also staked out the early high ground. Dish jumped 5% to lead the Nasdaq 100. T-Mobile powered up 4%. News reports said the two companies were in discussions regarding a possible merger. The gain sent T-Mobile to a fresh high. It sent Dish further up the right side of a four-month cup base.

Casino owner Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) surged more than 5% at the start of trade. Wynn Resorts (WYNN) jumped 4% to top the S&P 500. MGM Resorts (MGM) and Las Vegas Sands (LVS) gained 2% each. The group has largely been consolidating for the past 14 months.

Cal-Maine Foods (CALM) scratched out a 2% gain to lead the IBD 50 list in early trade. A pair of reports confirming falling revenue for Macau gambling proved a losing hand for Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and other Macau-centric casinos.Wells Fargo analyst Cameron McKnight said Macau gaming revenue for July fell 3.6% to $3.5 billion. The drop came amid a crackdown on practices by local lenders who allegedly used credit cards to illegally launder money. Some of those lenders have been arrested as a result.Visitors to Macau routinely borrow money to get around restrictions on the amount of cash that can be brought into the special district across the strait from Hong Kong.The crackdown includes tighter restrictions on lenders that make it harder for visitors to borrow, causing some, especially high-roller VIP gamblers, to stay away.The revenue drop was led by a 13.9% slide in VIP gaming, mostly from baccarat play. Mass market (middle class tourist) revenue rose 17%, but that was the weakest growth since the bank started tracking Macau casinos in 2010.McKnight said Macau "revenues did not improve materially in the back half of July, which could mean mainland China's political initiatives, and potentially transit visa changes, are impacting premium mass" gambling revenue.In a separate report, Deutsche Bank lowered its third-quarter and full-year 2014 revenue forecast for Macau.Deutsche Bank analyst Carlo Santarelli expects Q3 revenue to fall 0.9% vs. the same quarter a year ago and full year revenue to grow 6.5%, well below the region's usual growth rates, and down from his earlier outlook for 3% Q3 growth and 8.6% for the full year.Deutsche Bank also lowered its August gross gaming revenue forecast to a mild 3% increase "to account for softer VIP volume and mass revenue trends against a tough comparison" vs. the same month a year ago, StreetInsider quoted Santarelli as saying in the report.Las Vegas Sands shares were down more than 4% at 68.93 in Wednesday afternoon trading on the stock market today.Other large Las Vegas casinos with operations in Macau dived. Wynn Resorts (WYNN) fell 3.5% and MGM Resorts International (MGM) slid 2%.Hong Kong-based Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) skidded 5%.Follow James DeTar on Twitter: @IBD_JDeTar.
Macau-centric casinos continue to be pounded by a mid-year slowdown, with Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) on Thursday becoming the latest to fall short of revenue and profit targets.

Additionally, Wells Fargo analyst Cameron McKnight said in a post-earnings report that the Taipei District Prosecutors Office had indicted Melco Crown's Taiwan branch office and certain employees for alleged violations of local banking and foreign exchange laws. The company was expected to provide details on its earnings call.

Melco Crown, which competes with Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and other large U.S. casinos in Macau, said Q2 earnings per share fell 26% from the same quarter a year ago to 26 cents. That was 10 cents below consensus of 21 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters.
Revenue slid 7.4% to $1.199 billion, undershooting Wall Street's $1.297 billion target.
Casino mogul and Melco CEO Lawrence Ho said the shortfall was mainly in the high-roller VIP segment, partly offset by a 38% increase in so-called mass market, or tourist, table game revenues.
Melco shares slid as much as 5% early and settled to a 2.9% drop at 29.14 in morning trading on the stock market today.

McKnight in a report said it was a "soft" quarter for Melco and noted its "City of Dreams Manila is on track to open later this year, while Studio City remains on-track for a mid-2015 opening." Wells Fargo has an outperform rating on Melco.
The company's board also approved a $500 million share repurchase program.
Las Vegas Sands last month also reported disappointing results, mainly on weakness in Macau. Sands shares lost 2.2% Thursday.

Among other Vegas casinos with Macau operations, Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and MGM Resorts International (MGM) lost more than 1% intraday. Both reported Macau weakness in their recent earnings reports, partially offset by resurging business in Las Vegas.

Sands shares lost 2.2% Thursday.Among other Vegas casinos with Macau operations, Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and MGM Resorts International (MGM) lost more than 1% intraday. Both reported Macau weakness in their recent earnings reports, partially offset by resurging business in Las Vegas.Follow James DeTar on Twitter: @IBD_JDeTar.

The stock market closed higher Thursday, although indexes pared gains.
The Nasdaq climbed 0.8% while the S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average added 0.5%.
Volume rose on the NYSE, but fell on the Nasdaq, according to early figures. Advancing stocks led decliners by 7-to-5 on the Nasdaq, but winners barely edged out losers on the NYSE.
Computer, trucking and financials ranked among the day's top performing sectors. Retail, metals and energy stocks lagged.
A weak forecast sent a chill through homebuilding stocks in the stock market today.

Meritage Homes (MTH) cut its forecast for 2015 earnings, citing rising labor costs, delays in closings and slower-than-expected business in the company's newer markets in the Southeast. The stock fell 9% in heavy trading, to the lowest level since early February.

"There are shortages of skilled labor in many markets as subcontractors struggle to catch up with the increased demand of a continued recovery in homebuilding," said Chairman and CEO Steven J. Hilton. Competition for labor is raising costs and lengthening construction times, his statement added. Bad weather in parts of Texas and Colorado further hurt the company.
The homebuilders' industry group, which has been a market leader, was one of the worst 20 groups Thursday out of 197 that IBD tracks.

One of the day's biggest losers was Lululemon Athletica (LULU), which plunged 16% after the yoga-styled apparel chain guided Q3 and full-year earnings below expectations. Shares fell to the lowest level since December.
Google (GOOGL) rose 1% and shares continued to rise from support at the 50-day moving average. But volume in Google was light.
After the close, shares of action sports retailer Zumiez (ZUMZ) slid after the company announced quarterly results. The stock closed regular trading near a 52-week low.

Wynn is set to open the Macau Palace, its second resort in the Chinese coastal city, in 2016. It sits on land in the trendy Cotai…

Top Vegas casinos such as Las Vegas Sands (LVS), MGM Resorts International (MGM) and Wynn Resorts (WYNN) are taking slot machines off casino floors to focus on lucrative table games like baccarat. Data from the University of Nevada Las Vegas Center for Gaming Research say the number of slot machines in Nevada casinos fell by 38,000 from 2000 to 2012.…
Caesars Entertainment (CZR) expects other casinos bidding for a gambling license in Massachusetts will likely face a tough time, after it withdrew its own bid for a license to build in the state.

Caesars also said in a filing Monday that its Desert Palace subsidiary, owner of the Caesars Palace resort, is being investigated by a federal grand jury for possible money laundering. Caesars said it's cooperating with federal officials.
Rivals Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and MGM Resorts International (MGM) are bidding for Massachusetts licenses too, but Caesars claimed the state's requirements are "unprecedented."
"It's going to be very difficult for sophisticated, multi-jurisdictional operators to tolerate the environment this commission has created," Caesars CEO Gary Loveman told reporters Sunday.
The company said it was pulling out after Suffolk Downs said it had severed its partnership with the casino to build a $1 billion resort casino at the racetrack.
Massachusetts' gaming commission earlier said in a report it had concerns about Caesars' debt and ties to a New York hotel with possible links to organized crime.
Caesars in March said it planned to spend $185 million to transform the aging Bill's Gamblin' Hall in Las Vegas into a boutique hotel using the Gansevoort name.

Earlier, an investor in New York-based Gansevoort Hotel Group was identified in German court filings as possibly having ties to organized crime in Russia, a 2012 report in the New York Post said. A Gansevoort spokeswoman told Bloomberg the hotel agreed to end the partnership with Caesars to avoid controversy.
Caesars stock is down about 33% since September and slid 7% in Monday afternoon trading in the stock market today.

It rose 462% from mid-November 2012 to an all-time high close on Sept. 11 before retrenching. The company is preparing to split into two companies, creating a new unit to invest in online gaming technologies.
Wynn and MGM were both up less than 1%. Las Vegas Sands (LVS), the world's largest casino company and listed on the IBD Leaderboard of highly rated companies, eased fractionally.

Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and Wynn Resorts (WYNN) could keep cashing in on the Golden Week holiday in Macau, as a recent government ban on low-cost travel packages from the Chinese mainland to the gambling hub seems to be having little effect.
Macau officials said tourist arrivals in the first five days of the holiday were about 4.7% higher than last year, and total gambling revenue is estimated at 14% to 17% higher than a year ago.
A 17% rise would translate to about $4 billion in revenue for Macau casinos for the week.

But the final results for Golden Week, which lasts Oct. 1-7, aren't yet known because the last few days of the national holiday haven't been tallied yet and are typically the biggest for Macau casinos, analysts said.

Sands' stock price has climbed 38% from a June 24 low but shares were down fractionally on the stock market today. Wynn and MGM Resorts International (MGM), which both have Macau operations, were basically flat.
Hong Kong-based Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL), controlled by gambling mogul Stanley Ho, rose 1%.

Sands, a member of the IBD Leaderboard list of top-rated stocks, is benefiting from a buildout in Macau, situated across the straits from Hong Kong and China's only legal casino gambling region. Macau's Gaming Inspection and Coordination Bureau said Tuesday that gross gaming revenue in June was $3.41 billion, down 3.7% from a year ago. That was the first annual decline…

The major indexes closed mixed Tuesday, but underlying strength could be seen in leading stocks. The Nasdaq added 0.4%, while the S&P; 500 fell less than 0.1% — a loss too small to be considered distribution. Volume rose sharply as traders started coming back from summer break. Oil and other commodity stocks suffered the most and contributed to the lagging…
Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe narrowed the time frame he'd like to see a bill legalizing casino gambling passed in that country, saying Tuesday he's looking for a vote this fall.
U.S. casino giants such as Las Vegas Sands (LVS) have been in Tokyo for months, lobbying for passage of the bill, which could add billions to their coffers.
Some observers had expected a vote on the bill in the spring session. But the Diet failed to act and postponed the vote.
"I hope in my capacity as leader of the LDP (Liberal Democratic Party) that we can aim to pass it in the next extraordinary session of the Diet" this fall, Abe told Bloomberg in an interview.
Sands CEO Sheldon Adelson has said he's ready to invest $10 billion in Japan as soon as casinos are legal there. Sands shares rose 1.3% in the stock market today.
Analysts have said if the bill passes as expected, Japan could quickly vie with China's Macau gambling district, which boasts annual gambling revenue of roughly $50 billion a year.
Abe, now 18 months in office, is pushing for quick passage as part of a package to stimulate Japan's economy and enable casinos to be built ahead of the 2020 Olympic Games in Tokyo.
Sands rival Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and Hong Kong-based Melco Crown (MPEL) are among casinos jostling to get their foot in the door in Japan.
MGM Resorts International (MGM) Chief Executive Jim Murren told IBD earlier this year his company was in talks with Japanese companies to form partnerships to build casinos.
"Ultimately we hope to be a large, active operation and participate in Japan through the operation of one or more casinos there," he said in March.
MGM shares climbed 2%. Wynn Resorts and Melco Crown were both up about 2%.

Las Vegas Sands' (LVS) had its price target cut by two analysts in as many days amid rising concerns about slowing growth in global gambling capital Macau.But shares of the world's largest casino company rose nicely early Wednesday, leading a sector mini-rally, amid general stock market gains and hopes for stronger China economic growth, which should fuel Macau gaming.Analysts have said they're still bullish long-term on Macau casinos. The new price targets may be catching up with months-old news of slowing Macau growth.Casino stocks may also be reacting to prospects in Japan, whose parliament is debating a bill to legalize casinos.Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe on Tuesday voiced support for the bill, saying he plans to push for a vote in this fall's session, part of his broader plan to improve infrastructure and tourist attractions ahead of the 2020 Olympic Games in Tokyo.FBR Capital analyst Jake Fuller lowered his price target on Sands to 80 from 85, with a market perform (neutral) rating. Fuller noted in a report that FBR downgraded Sands' rating and began shifting away from Macau casinos in January.Many high-roller VIP gamblers are avoiding Macau during a crackdown by Chinese officials on local lenders who provide cash to gamblers to get around limits on how much cash they can bring into Macau. China says some lenders use the system to illegally launder money.On Tuesday, Susquehanna lowered its target for Sands to 89 from 98, with a positive rating. The bank also cut its target for Vegas rival Wynn Resorts (WYNN), which operates large casinos in Macau, to 239 from 268.Morgan Stanley, Zacks and Telsey Advisory Group all earlier lowered price targets on Sands.Wells Fargo analyst Cameron McKnight said last week that valuations of Macau-centric casinos are bottoming, "but, based on our valuation analysis, we don't believe we're at a short-term bottom."By late afternoon, Sands was trading up 0.8% and Wynn was up 0.9% in the stock market today, Wednesday.Meanwhile, MGM Resorts International (MGM) rose 0.9%.On Tuesday, a Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court ruled that a ballot measure to repeal the state's expanded casino gambling law can go to voters this fall.The ruling overturned a decision by state Attorney General Martha Coakley, and set up what could be an expensive campaign.The 2011 law said three casino resorts and one slot machine parlor could be built in the state. MGM this month was awarded the state's first casino license. Penn National Gaming (PENN) got the slot parlor license in February.Meanwhile, Wynn and Mohegan Sun, a Connecticut casino company, have issued proposals for a license and are vying to get the nod to build a casino in Boston.Follow James DeTar on Twitter: @IBD_JDeTar.

Passport holders with transit visas can stay five days starting July 1, down from the previous maximum of seven. The government is trying to stop abuse of transit…

Shares of Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and other Macau-centric casino stocks continued to work through choppiness on Friday, but they are seen bottoming out after sliding in recent months, a new report said.
Casino stocks have fallen since March, mainly because many VIP gamblers are staying away from Chinese gambling hotspot Macau amid new, tighter regulations.

"We see recent downgrades and cuts to Street (Macau gambling revenue) market estimates as a sign that short-term valuations are bottoming out — but, based on our valuation analysis, we don't yet believe we're at a short-term bottom," Wells Fargo analyst Cameron McKnight said in a report Friday.

Macau has begun restricting the amount of cash that visitors can bring. So gamblers often borrow money from lenders carrying handheld devices to dispense funds from bank cards to get around the restriction.
Chinese officials earlier this year cracked down on the lenders, arresting 12 people in February and March, charging that they used the system to illegally launder money from criminal operations.
Macau officials also ordered jewelry stores and pawn shops at casinos to remove UnionPay card terminals by July 1, a state news agency said Thursday.
Sands and Wynn (WYNN) shares were up both up about 1% on the stock market today. Sands was down about 16% from a recent high of 88.28 on March 7 and was trading below 50-day and 200-day averages.

MGM Resorts International (MGM), which also owns casinos in Macau, rose as well. The hot debate over legalizing online gambling nationally took a turn with the defeat of House Majority Leader Eric Cantor, who was backed by Las Vegas Sands (LVS) CEO Sheldon Adelson in Virginia's Republican primary.
Tea Party challenger David Brat beat Cantor, the No. 2 Republican in the House of Representatives, to become the GOP candidate from Virginia's 7th District.
Cantor's backer Adelson is leading the opposition to the movement to legalize online gaming.
And "Cantor counted Sheldon Adelson, who publicly sank at least $10 million into Cantor-backed super-PACs through 2012, among his staunch backers," Union Gaming analyst Robert Shore said in a report.

Although it's not clear yet what the implications would be if Brat wins the Virginia House seat, with Adelson-backed Cantor out of the picture the odds could change for legalizing online gaming nationally, analysts say.
Adelson has said there are insufficient safeguards to block minors from gambling online if it's legalized nationally.
Analysts note Sands' multibillion-dollar Venetian and Palazzo casino resorts in Las Vegas and other U.S. brick-and-mortar properties could lose money to online gambling if legalized nationally.
Online gambling for money is legal in three states, Delaware, Nevada and New Jersey, but only for residents who live within those states.

It should be noted that Sen. Lindsey Graham, R-S.C., who defeated challengers to gain his party's nomination Tuesday, in March introduced legislation that would impose a federal ban on all online gambling, including shutting down operations in the three states that have legalized it.

Caesars Entertainment (CZR) and MGM Resorts International (MGM) have backed the rollout of online gambling. Steve Wynn, head of Wynn Resorts (WYNN), supported online gaming until recently, when he switched positions, joining Adelson in opposing it.
Shares of Sands, Wynn and MGM were all up about 1% in afternoon trading in the stock market today, Wednesday. Caesars fell 1%.

Steve Wynn, head of Wynn Resorts (WYNN), supported online gaming until recently, when he switched positions, joining Adelson in opposing it.Shares of Sands, Wynn and MGM were all up about 1% in afternoon trading in the stock market today, Wednesday. Caesars fell 1%.Follow James DeTar on Twitter: @IBD_JDeTar.

Victor Fleming was one of the most successful movie directors of all time yet is barely remembered. In 1939, he helmed "Gone With the Wind," the biggest box-office smash in history, once ticket prices are adjusted for inflation. It brought in the equivalent of $3.3 billion, according to the Guinness Book of Records. And it won Fleming an Oscar for…

Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and other top Vegas casinos fell sharply early Tuesday in heavy volume after officials in gambling hotspot Macau said gaming revenue rose just 9.3% in May vs. a year ago, well below consensus for 13% to 15% growth. The drop was a surprise for many, coming a day after Chinese officials reported stronger manufacturing growth for…

Stocks held solid gains near midday Thursday, but eased from session highs. The Nasdaq trimmed a 1% gain to 0.7% and the S&P 500 pared a 0.7% gain to 0.5%. The Dow Jones industrial average added 0.5%. Turnover was running higher on both major exchanges in the stock market today.

In leading stocks, WNS (WNS) gapped up and bolted nearly 7% to its best levels since February 2007. It blew past a 31.60 buy point in a cup base. Before the open, the Indian outsourcing firm posted fiscal Q2 earnings above views and raised guidance.

Inphi (IPHI) rallied 5% and hit an all-time high. The stock cleared a 27.21 buy point in a consolidation. Volume was heavy. The chip designer will report Q3 earnings Oct. 27. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters see profit doubling to 24 cents a share. That would mark an eighth straight quarter of double-digit growth.
On the downside, Netflix (NFLX) gapped below its 50-day line and dumped 10% following late Wednesday's disappointing Q3 results and news of soft U.S. subscriber growth.

Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX) was off its session low, but still down 5% on news that it received a federal subpoena over its drug-pricing policy. Shares of the Canadian drugmaker were off as much as 12% intraday.
