Shares of Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and other top casinos fell for a third straight session amid conflicting reports Monday about gambling hotspot Macau.
SSome analysts had earlier forecast a short-term decline in Macau after the government cracked down on lenders in China's gaming enclave
Gamblers often borrow money to get around restrictions on how much cash they can bring into the the special administrative district across the strait from Hong Kong.
Chinese officials say some lenders engage in illegal money laundering.

Sterne Agee analyst David Bain said in a report channel checks indicated that Macau's gross gaming revenue, or GGR, was up about 5% so far for June, year over year, to an annualized rate of $3.9 billion.

"This morning, there were initial reports that the first nine days of GGR amounted to 7.8 billion Macau pacatas ($980 million), which would have shown a slower than expected start to June (-4%). Those reports were incorrect," Bain said in his report.
"Our June year-over-year GGR outlook is between -2% and +3%. Recall that we expect some GGR head winds from the World Cup," which began June 12 in Brazil and will likely draw tourists away, he said.
Wells Fargo Cameron McKnight was also moderately downbeat.

"Based on (channel) checks through June 8, we estimate June Macau gaming revenue growth is trending between 1%-5% (higher) year over year, vs. our June estimate of 6.5%," even though that period included two weekends when more people visit Macau, McKnight said.

He remains positive about Macau's long-term prospects. However, "2014 could be choppy due to a potential slowdown in VIP driven by decelerating credit growth and a softer macroenvironment. Las Vegas Sands (LVS) remains our top pick for 2014 given its strong mass market" position. Mass market refers to middle-class tourists from inland China and other countries.

FBR Capital Markets said the crackdown, tighter restrictions on visas for people visiting the city and a recent smoking ban are likely to keep gamblers away. FBR analyst Jake Fuller expects Macau gambling revenue to grow about 10% this quarter, below consensus. He kept market perform ratings on Las Vegas Sands and Wynn and an outperform rating on MGM Resorts International (MGM), a third Vegas casino with Macau operations.

Deutsche Bank cut its 2014 full-year Macau gross gaming revenue forecast from 15% to 12%. It also downgraded Wynn Macau and SJM Holdings — a Hong Kong-based casino that operates in Macau and trades on the Hong Kong exchange — to hold from buy. The bank lowered its price targets on Wynn, Sands, MGM and Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL), a Hong Kong-based Macau casino operator that trades on the NYSE.

Morgan Stanley said in its report there may be a quarterly decline in earnings this quarter, the first since the fourth quarter 2009. The bank projected year-to-year VIP gambling revenue could fall 7% "due to fewer weekend days and potential distraction from the World Cup starting June 12."
Shares of Wynn Resorts fell nearly 3% on the stock market today.
Sands and MGM Resorts fell more than 2%, while Melco Crown skidded nearly 6%.
Caesars Entertainment (CZR), which doesn't own casinos in Macau but is the largest U.S. casino operator, climbed 2%.

International Game Technology (IGT), a maker of computerized slots and other casino gaming gear, shot up more than 14% Monday after Reuters reported that IGT is mulling a sale of the company. Casino companies and private equity firms reportedly are interested.

A second bank said Macau faces a short-term slump in gambling revenue that could affect earnings for Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and other top casinos in the hot gambling destination on China's southern coast.
Nomura Securities on Thursday cut its earlier-raised 2014 revenue growth forecast for Macau from 17% to 14%.
The Japanese bank joined Wells Fargo, which, as reported earlier, has been warning for some time that Macau casinos face headwinds in the short term.
Sands separately said Thursday that President and Chief Operating Officer Michael Leven will retire at the end of this year. And CEO Sheldon Adelson tried to quash rumors that he plans to step down.
"I am as bullish about this company as I've ever been, and I have no plans of slowing down or passing the CEO title or job to anyone," Adelson said in a statement.

Meanwhile, Nomura analyst Harry Curtis in a report noted the bank raised its estimate for Macau in March, based on stronger-than-expected demand early in the year. "Since then, growth has contracted to 12%-13%, which we expect to continue through year-end," Curtis said, "so our revised forecast for the full year is back to our original +14% estimate."
Both banks blame a credit crunch in the world's top gambling destination for the projected slowdown.

VIP gamblers rely on local loans to play in Macau because Chinese officials restrict the amount of cash visitors can bring in. But Chinese officials have accused some lenders of laundering money for illegal activities and imposed further restrictions that could keep some VIPs away.
Like Wells Fargo, Nomura remains bullish on Macau in the long run as the gambling mecca continues to expand.
Las Vegas Sands shares rose 1% in Thursday morning trading in the stock market today.

Sands threw a huge party this week, celebrating the 10th anniversary of its first casino in Macau. It now has more than 9,000 hotel rooms and suites, 1.5 million square feet of convention space, more than 100 restaurants and 600 duty-free retail shops, two theaters and a 15,000-seat arena there.

Among rivals in Macau, MGM Resorts International (MGM) was up more than 2% early Thursday. MGM shares hit a five-year high of 28.75 on March 7 and have consolidated about 14% in sync with a market correction.
Wynn Resorts (WYNN) rose 1.5%. Wynn said in a May 16 filing that it appointed Stephen Cootey treasurer and chief financial officer. Cootey had served as interim CFO since February.

Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL), a Hong Kong casino that competes in Macau with Vegas rivals, jumped 3%. Melco Crown continues to expand in Asia and, like Sands and others, is eyeing Japan, whose legislature is debating legalizing casino gambling.

Macau is the growth engine for the global casino industry, and revenue growth for casinos there seems to be slowing, Wells Fargo said in a report.

That could affect sales and earnings for world's largest casino company, Las Vegas Sands (LVS), and rivals Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and MGM Resorts International (MGM), which all have properties in Macau. It could also hurt Hong Kong-based Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL), which competes with the Vegas casinos in Macau.

Wells Fargo analyst Cameron McKnight is in Macau meeting with company executives this week. McKnight said in a Monday report that, based on those meetings and channel checks, he expects May revenue for Macau casinos will rise 10% to 14% compared with the same month a year ago. That's well below his earlier forecast for 14% to 16% growth.

"We remain positive on the longer-term Macau secular growth story; however, 2014 could be choppy due to a potential slowdown in VIP (gambling revenue) driven by decelerating credit growth and a softer microenvironment," McKnight said in the report.

High rollers, known in the industry as VIP gamblers, borrow money from junket operators who bring them to the gambling hot spot on China's southern coast. They do that to get around limitations China sets on how much outside cash gamblers can bring in.
The Chinese government has accused these junket operators of being involved in illegal money laundering, and is cracking down on them. That could lead to fewer VIP gamblers visiting Macau.
Additionally, China's hot growth has cooled in recent quarters, which could lead to fewer middle-class Chinese visiting Macau, the country's only legal casino gambling region.

McKnight said Sands remains the bank's top pick because it has higher exposure to the "mass market" segment, mainly middle-class tourists from inland China. Sands shares were down more than 2% in afternoon trading in the stock market today, Tuesday.
Sands and Wynn both have a 91 IBD Composite Rating, meaning they've outperformed 91% of all stocks in recent quarters on key metrics such as sales and profit growth.
Wynn was down about 2% too. MGM Resorts, the No. 2 casino company by annual revenue, slid 1.5%. Melco Crown dropped more than 4%.

The bill has wide support, and analysts say that it's expected to pass, opening the door to Vegas casinos such as Las Vegas Sands (LVS), MGM…
The major averages were on track to close at or near record highs as stocks extended their gains in early-afternoon trade.
The Nasdaq led with a 0.5% advance, while the S&P 500 and Dow industrials each rose 0.2%. Volume was trending slightly higher on the Nasdaq but lower on the NYSE in the stock market today.

TAL Education Group (XRS) rose 4% to 25.72 in brisk trade as it nears a 26.68 buy point. If the gain holds, shares will have advanced in seven of the past eight sessions. The Chinese educator's profit growth accelerated the past three quarters and is expected to step up to 183% in fiscal Q2, from 140% in the prior quarter.

Fellow Chinese stockYY Inc. (YY) surged 5% in twice the normal turnover. The stock, which may be shaping the right side of a deep V-shaped base, is 24% off its high. The online social network and gaming company has also enjoyed strong growth recently, with five straight quarters of triple-digit earnings and sales gains.

Casino stocks were lower as analysts said June gaming revenue growth in Macau was tracking below estimates. Wynn Resorts (WYNN) fell 3%, Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) 5% and MGM Resorts (MGM) and Las Vegas Sands (LVS) 2% each.

MGM Resorts International's (MGM) first-quarter sales and earnings rose more than expected amid expansion in Chinese gambling enclave Macau and in the U.S., pushing its shares higher and keying a sector rally.
MGM's sales grew 12% to $2.63 billion, topping estimates for $2.58 billion.

MGM China, which runs the MGM Macau casino resort and is developing a new resort on the trendy Cotai peninsula in Macau, saw revenue climbed 26%. MGM competes in Macau with Vegas rivals Las Vegas Sands (LVS), the world's largest casino company, as well as Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and others.
MGM, the No. 2 casino by revenue, reported 22-cent Q1 per-share earnings, up from a 1-cent profit the same quarter last year, and well above Wall Street's 9-cent target.
MGM China had $941 million in new revenue in the quarter, a 26% increase compared with the prior-year quarter.

CEO Jim Murren noted that the company's second Macau casino resort, MGM Cotai, is on schedule to open in early 2016, and the company is preparing to break ground on MGM National Harbor in Maryland this summer. It expects to open that property in 2016 as well.
Wells Fargo Securities analyst Cameron McKnight said in a report Tuesday a large part of the gain came from rising room occupancy in MGM's home-base Las Vegas.
"Results were driven by stronger than expected RevPAR (revenue per available room), particularly at MGM's low and midend properties," McKnight said.
In a recent interview prior to the earnings report, Murren told IBD: "Las Vegas is bustling right now. There's a lot of buzz, excitement and fun, new restaurants and things to do."

On Monday, MGM announced plans for a tree-lined park and outdoor shopping and dining district on the west side of the Las Vegas Strip. The eight-acre park will connect New York-New York and Monte Carlo resorts and a new 20,000-seat arena being built by MGM and partner AEG.
MGM shares were up 7% in Tuesday morning trading in the stock market today.

Wynn, which is on the IBD 50 list of top-rated stocks, was up more than 4%. Sands rose more than 3% and Hong Kong's Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL), which competes with the Vegas casinos in Macau, was up 4%.

Ron Weisner is used to having demanding clients.After all, he's a music manager.From the 1960s through the 1990s, he traveled the world with the likes of Michael Jackson ("obsessive perfectionist"), Paul McCartney ("zero ego") and Madonna ("never grateful")."The music business isn't normal on a good day," Weisner, author of "Listen Out Loud," told IBD. "Managing artists is like owning a chain of 7-Elevens — you're on call all the time and have to be there for one emergency after another. But I was fortunate in having clients who made timeless music."He got out of artist management 15 years ago. Now he organizes arena concerts for corporations featuring top artists such as Beyonce and the Eagles. He also produces specials for BET, MTV and VH1.Grow With The BeatWeisner, 69, grew up in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, N.Y., where during the summer everyone played music with the windows open, mixing Elvis with Jamaican calypso, Motown and the Four Tops.In his teens, he would sneak over to the Apollo Theater in Harlem to catch concerts by the likes of Aretha Franklin and Little Stevie Wonder, and was usually the only white kid in the audience."There's a whole generation of listeners who haven't experienced what it's like to see a tight, well-rehearsed band blow the roof off a theater, and it breaks my heart that today it's considered a successful show when the prerecorded vocal track to which the singer is lip-synching doesn't crap out in the middle of a song," Weisner wrote.In 1966 he got a job in the mailroom at MGM Records. He spent loads of time in the office of Harold Berkman, head of promotions, listening to how he pitched stations for new releases. Berkman decided to make Weisner his assistant.Weisner saw how singers did interviews with the press and noted that MGM's units worked closely together ("there were no divas").After a year with Berkman, Weisner shifted to marketing in the Verve label, where he learned about distribution, production quality control and the label's artist and repertoire segment, which was signing new acts like Richie Havens, Janis Ian and the Velvet Underground.In 1969, Weisner followed two colleagues from MGM to Buddah Records (later renamed Buddha)."We knew that to survive, we'd have to outhustle and outthink the major labels, but we thought we could develop a reputation for being more artist friendly," he said.One of Buddah's most important clients was Curtis Mayfield, who had composed many of the anthems of the civil rights movement."One of the great wordsmiths of our era," said Weisner.Mayfield and two other Buddah performers, Gladys Knight and Sha Na Na, became Weisner's first management clients."What I wanted to do was to nurture the best talent, helping them put on brilliant live shows and build a following over the long run," said Weisner, who moved his management business to Los Angeles in 1972."The first thing that grabbed me about Ron is how much he loved music," wrote Knight in the foreword to Weisner's memoir. "When I asked him to be my manager, he said, 'I'll do what I can.' He didn't talk a big game like some managers do. The passion and loyalty he has for his artists, his business associates and his friends are unmatched."Sha Na Na was a dozen guys who put on 250 shows a year, but each had a different idea of what the band should be doing.Weisner had to constantly intervene in their arguments while making their 1950s doo-wop style famous with their appearance in the 1978 movie "Grease."He also signed a syndication deal for a TV variety series for them, but it needed a sponsor. Weisner approached some Procter & Gamble (PG) executives, but they were skeptical about the group's appeal.Weisner came up with a flashy idea. He arranged for them to fly to New York so the P&G suits could see Sha Na Na perform, then called a billboard company. As the execs were driven up Sixth Avenue, the electronic billboards flashed pictures of the performers.P&G signed, and the show ran for four seasons.In 1977, Weisner got a call from a friend who said a group of brothers called the Jackson 5 needed help. They had left Motown for Epic Records, and their career had stalled because their light pop style had lost its appeal.The problem was that their dad and manager, Joe Jackson, didn't care what they sang, as long as he could squeeze every dollar out of the deal. They were petrified of him."I knew I was walking into a minefield and became their manager anyway," Weisner said. "Joe and I had constant fights, and my only real concern was that I could keep these away from Michael, who could make magic when he was in the studio."Feet On The GroundWeisner found Michael to be a serious student of entertainment who had studied how Fred Astaire, Charlie Chaplin and James Brown danced and moved."His energy level was off the charts, unmatched by anyone I've seen before or since," Weisner said. "He wanted to be the best, then go beyond that."Against the wishes of Epic, which thought Quincy Jones was too old to produce a record for what they thought was Michael's preteen audience, Weisner arranged for him to handle Jackson's solo record "Off the Wall."The process proved worth it.After it was released in 1979, "Off the Wall" sold 20 million copies — compared with the 1.3 million the label had expected.Jackson's next album, "Thriller," was the ultimate smash after coming out in 1982. It sold 110 million copies, the greatest number ever.Michael had been calling Weisner 20 times a day when suddenly he stopped in 1984, after Joe Jackson reasserted his control over his son's careers.Downs And UpsBy then, Weisner had brought on a partner, Freddy DeMann, but by 1985 they had different visions for the business and decided to divvy up the clients.One of those clients was Madonna, and Weisner happily let DeMann have her.The singer had topped the charts the year before, but her demeanor wasn't for Weisner."Sure I want to help my family have the good life, but I also want me to have a good life, and if Madonna were part of it, no amount of money was worth the headache," Weisner wrote.Paul McCartney sparked the opposite experience."He was, without fail, a joy to work with — professional, energized and punctual," Weisner wrote. "From him I learned that you must persevere not only when things are at their worst, but also when they're at their best. I learned that it's possible to balance your show business with your personal life and remain at the top of your game in both. I learned that entertainment is a noble profession."Larry Schweikart, director of the independent film "Rockin' the Wall," said: "In interviewing musicians for our documentary on how rock music helped bring down the Iron Curtain, I learned that almost all of them had a very difficult time finding a manager they could trust. Ron Weisner was known for having built his success on being absolutely honest and always putting the client's benefit before his own. That's a lesson that can be applied to any profession."

Las Vegas Sands' second-quarter estimates will be a high bar for the company to jump when it reports Wednesday. Like Las Vegas peers MGM Resorts International (MGM) and Wynn Resorts (WYNN), Las Vegas Sands (LVS) gets the bulk…

Former National Basketball Association player Jackie Robinson plans to build a $1.3 billion arena and hotel on the Las Vegas Strip.Robinson said this week he expects to begin construction in the spring on a privately funded project near the renovated SLS Las Vegas hotel-casino and idle Fontainebleau tower. It would open in 2016.The 22,000-seat stadium would be the second new arena on the tourist corridor. MGM Resorts International (MGM) is building a similarly sized project on the opposite side of the Strip, in partnership with sports and entertainment promoter AEG."I think it's the only place that's going to have the Chicago Bears at one end and Beyonce at the other end, and an arena in both places. It's a unique place — it's not like Kansas City. It can support more than one event," Robinson said.Developers say an 863,000-square- foot arena will have four levels, a retractable roof and a nightclub, and will host basketball, hockey, boxing, rodeos and concerts. Plans call for 75 luxury boxes and a VIP entrance.Robinson says an outdoor promenade with shops and eateries will lead to a 500-room luxury hotel.Minneapolis-based Cunningham Group Architecture is the designer.MGM's $350 million arena is expected to open in the spring of 2016 between the New York-New York and Monte Carlo hotel-casinos.Robinson played at the University of Nevada-Las Vegas, then in the NBA 1978 to 1982 with the Seattle SuperSonics, Detroit Pistons and Chicago Bulls. He later worked as a general contractor, hotel manager and airport concession owner. Robinson, who's using loan financing, got the arena idea five years ago but waited for the economy to improve.

Earnings season kicks into high gear this week, with a slew of high-profile quarterly results from some of the biggest and brightest companies. Many are the first to report for their given industry, giving investors a particular interest in analyzing the financials and outlooks.Here are six of the most important earnings reports on tap.TuesdayCharles Schwab (SCHW) was a pioneering discount brokerage, but it's still blazing new trails. Schwab shares hit a 13-year high on March 21. The stock consolidated and attempted a breakout on July 3. It fell back as the market sold off, though in light volume. Schwab rose 0.7% to 27.10 on the stock market Friday.Wall Street expects Schwab to report a 28% earnings per share gain to 23 cents. That would snap 3 quarters of accelerating growth.J.P. Morgan Chase (JPM) has had a tough time of late. Once deemed the best-run Wall Street bank, JPMorgan Chase has paid billions of dollars in various settlements. Mortgage activity has slowed — affecting many lenders — while fixed-income trading seems permanently depressed. JPMorgan said in a SEC filing that it expected Q2 market revenues down 20% vs. a year earlier. Finally, the company reported on July 1 that CEO Jamie Dimon has throat cancer, though that should be "curable."Shares have retreated since hitting a 14-year high in late March.JPMorgan earnings likely fell 19% to $1.29 a share, matching Q1's 19% year-over-year decline. JPMorgan is just one of several major bank earnings. Wells Fargo (WFC) reported earnings Friday. Citigroup (C) reports Monday, with Goldman Sachs (GS) joining JPMorgan on Tuesday. Bank of America (BAC) results are due Wednesday.Intel (INTC) has seen a rebirth in recent months, with shares recently hitting a 10-year high, in the wake of solid Q1 results in early April and then upwardly revised revenue guidance on June 12. Intel is benefitting from the recent revival in corporate PC sales after Microsoft (MSFT) stopped supporting the venerable Windows operating system.Intel earnings should show a 33% gain to 52 cents a share, following yearly changes of -5%, 6%, 0%, -28% in the prior four quarters. Investors will want to have some indication if PC sales will remain strong in the second half of the year, or if Intel will find some other way to expand.Yahoo (YHOO) earnings will rise 9% to 38 cents a share, following Q1's flat reading. Q1 revenue edged higher, as display ad sales climbed 2%, offering some hope that CEO Marissa Mayer can generate top-line growth. Still, Yahoo's most important news may be about Alibaba. Yahoo owns a minority stake in the Chinese e-commerce giant, and it gives some headline figures on Alibaba's results.Alibaba's planned U.S. IPO is widely expected to take place in August. Yahoo will sell a significant share of its existing holdings as part of the offering.Yahoo shares have been in a downtrend since hitting a decade-best in early January.WednesdayLas Vegas Sands (LVS) is the world's largest casino operator. Despite its name, Sands — like Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and MGM Resorts (MGM) — gets the bulk of its revenue and profit from Macau, China's gaming enclave and the world's largest gambling site. Macau growth has slowed in recent months amid a crackdown on moneylenders in the area. But there are some signs that the worst is over for Macau. Meanwhile, Las Vegas casino revenue has been solid.Las Vegas Sands earnings should show a 40% gain to 91 cents a share, analysts predicted. That would the second straight quarter of moderate acceleration.But Sands stock has been in a modest downtrend for the past four months, falling below its 50- and 200-day moving averages last week.ThursdayGoogle (GOOGL) is involved in many ventures, from self-driving cars to alternative-energy investments to Android mobile software. The open-source Android has become the global leader over Apple (AAPL) iOS. It's a direct money-maker, though it likely does help boost mobile ad revenue. Search-based ads remain the bulk of Google's business. But it's a good business: Earnings likely rose 31% to $6.26 a share. That would follow decelerating growth for the past two quarters to just 8% in Q1.Google shares hit a record high of 615.05 in late February. The stock consolidated and has been building a handle on its cup base. Google (GOOG) Class C shares, which started trading on April 3, are near a new highFollow Ed Carson on Twitter: @IBD_ECarson.RELATED:Wells Fargo Q2 Earnings Growth Slows As Banks Report

Stocks opened higher and held gains Tuesday as the two-day Federal Reserve meeting got underway.Investors were in a good mood, perhaps in anticipation of a dovish tone when the policy statement is released Wednesday at 2 p.m. ET.The Nasdaq rose 0.7%, while the the Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 approached all-time highs, rising 0.5% each.Preliminary data showed Nasdaq volume coming in about 20% lower than Monday. NYSE volume fell about 7%.In the stock market today, IBD's beaten-down Internet-Content industry group, filled with former leaders, was one of the day's top performers, rising about 3%. Group members Twitter (TWTR) and Trulia (TRLA) rallied ahead of their earnings reports after the close, rising 6% and 8% respectively.Elsewhere, Alliant Techsystems (ATK) soared 7% after the ammunition maker announced plans to merge with Orbital Sciences (ORB) after spinning off its sporting gun business. Orbital Sciences jumped 16%.In earnings news, Buffalo Wild Wings (BWLD) jumped 5% after reporting earnings before the open. Quarterly profit soared 71% from a year ago to $1.49 a share. Sales growth accelerated from 12% growth in the fourth quarter, rising 21% to $367.9 million.Strong earnings from MGM Resorts International (MGM) sparked a rally in casino operators. Shares rose 9%.Earnings and sales were better than expected at MGM amid expansion in Chinese gambling enclave Macau. Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and Las Vegas Sands (LVS) also had solid days with gains of 5% and 6% respectively.It's another busy day of earnings on Wednesday. Watch for reports from Iconix Brand Group (ICON), Cavium Networks (CAVM), Portfolio Recovery Associates (PRAA) and Whiting Petroleum (WLL).

In Las Vegas, the rates for hotel rooms at rival MGM Resorts International (MGM) were up more than 20% so far in the…
Caesars Entertainment (CZR) will close its money-losing Harrah's casino in Tunica, Miss., on June 2, as casinos in the U.S. struggle with anemic growth amid continuing consumer caution.
"There's just too much supply in that market," John Payne, president of the company's central markets division, told Bloomberg. "The Harrah's has not been profitable for a while."
Top U.S. casino operator Caesars will eliminate 1,300 jobs in the move, which comes amid a broad restructuring for the company. Caesars has lost money in five of the last six years.
It's also indicative of a broader malaise in the U.S. casino industry.

Atlantic City, N.J. is one of the country's hardest-hit locales. On Jan. 13, the 33-year-old Atlantic Club Casino Hotel, owned by Santa Monica, Calif.-based private equity firm Colony Capital, closed its doors.
A subsidiary of Caesars, the largest Atlantic City casino operator, bought the non-gaming assets of the Atlantic Club in a bankruptcy auction.
Like rivals Las Vegas Sands (LVS), the world's biggest casino company, MGM Resorts International (MGM) and Wynn Resorts (WYNN), Caesars is based in Las Vegas.
But Sands, Wynn and MGM mostly rely on casinos in Chinese gambling hotspot Macau for their growth.
Caesars has been U.S.-centric until now, but earlier this month said it had gotten preliminary approval from South Korean officials to build a casino there.
Meanwhile, Vegas, the hub of U.S. casino gaming, has experienced a weak recovery from the 2008-'09 recession.
After total Vegas gambling revenue dropped about 10% in 2008 and 2009, it grew just 3% a year from 2010 to 2013, the UNLV Center for Gaming Research said in a recent report.
Caesars shares were down 3% in Thursday midday trading in the stock market. Sands, which is on the IBD 50 list of top-rated stocks, fell 2%, MGM 1% and Wynn 3%.

Las Vegas Strip gambling revenue plunged 20.2% in February, worse than some analysts expected.Nevada's Gaming Control Board reported Friday that revenue for the Strip fell to $556 million from $696 million the same month a year ago.Statewide gaming revenue was down 13.7% to $926 million.Union Gaming Research said the drop came in part because of lower revenue from VIP high rollers at baccarat tables compared to a year ago."The Las Vegas Strip numbers were below our expectations," Union Gaming analyst Robert Shore said in the report. "The comp was very challenging given the combination of last year's near record baccarat volume."Las Vegas Strip baccarat revenue fell a whopping 40.9% from a year ago, to $156.2 million, the research firm said.The market tracker said there were no major issues that would explain the discrepancy.Vegas gambling is recovering, albeit slowly, but renewed growth is "likely being led by other segments including nightlife, restaurant covers and the hotel segment," not gambling, the report said.Union Gaming expects March numbers to be better. "The month of March is historically one of the strongest months for Las Vegas demand," Shore said.Casino stocks were mixed Friday.Las Vegas Sands (LVS), the world's largest casino company and on the IBD 50 list of top-rated stocks, was up 1% in Friday afternoon trading on the stock market.Sands gets the bulk of revenue from its casinos in Macau, the thriving gambling hub on China's southern coast that's the world's top casino gaming destination.Vegas rival Wynn Resorts (WYNN), another IBD 50 stock, jumped 2%. CEO Steve Wynn said Friday he will offer 1,000 shares of the company's Wynn Macau subsidiary stock to all 7,500 employees there."The only compelling way that my colleagues can fully participate in our business success is by making each and every one of them an owner of the company with me," Macau Business quoted Wynn telling employees in Macau.Caesars Entertainment (CZR), the largest U.S. casino operator, plunged 8% after it announced a secondary offering of 7 million shares of common stock.Caesars, which is controlled by private equity firms Apollo Global Management and TPG Capital, is restructuring after losing money five of the last six years.MGM Resorts International (MGM) edged down fractionally.Follow James DeTar on Twitter: @IBD_JDeTar.

MGM Resorts International's (MGM) revenue rose more than expected in the final quarter of the year as it saw more visitors at its Las Vegas and Macau casinos.MGM earned 11 cents a share excluding various items, reversing a 23-cent loss a year earlier and beating views for a 1-cent profit. Net revenue grew 10% to $2.51 billion, above estimates for $2.46 billion.Including items, MGM lost 8 cents a share vs. a loss of $2.50 a share a year earlier. That included early retirement of debt related to the buildout of its CityCenter complex on the Las Vegas Strip and other properties.CEO Jim Murren said in a statement that work on a new casino in Macau, the former Portuguese colony on China's southern coast and the world's largest casino gambling region, is progressing."In Macau, we continue to yield our existing resort and are well underway in more than doubling our footprint in the world's largest gaming market with MGM Cotai set to open early 2016."MGM shares were up and down before closing off 10 cents to 25.75 on the stock market today.Rival Las Vegas Sands (LVS), the world's largest casino company and on the IBD 50 list of top-rated stocks, fell 1.3%.Earnings for MGM China, the company's Macau joint venture, rose 35% to a record $238 million. MGM China also declared a $500 million special dividend. Parent MGM Resorts International will receive $255 million, its 51% share of the special dividend.Operating income for MGM's U.S. properties in Las Vegas, Atlantic City and other locations rose 16%, as a 2% drop in casino gaming revenue was more than offset by 3% higher hotel room revenue.Wells Fargo Securities analyst Cameron McKnight said in a client note that "MGM reported solid Q4 results."McKnight viewed the China special dividend positively and said the company is well positioned this quarter amid higher hotel room rentals."That said, we believe investors are aware of Q1 strength and are focused on commentary for all of 2014," in the company's earnings call with analysts, he said.Follow James DeTar on Twitter: @IBD_JDeTar.

The drive to legalize online gambling throughout the U.S. is gaining momentum, but the heads of the world's largest casino companies are divided on what could be an $8 billion market.MGM Resorts International (MGM) CEO Jim Murren and Caesars Entertainment (CZR) CEO Gary Loveman support it."Gamers and casinos — those two industries are converging," Murren told IBD recently."We think that's a good thing. There's a business opportunity if it's regulated pristinely, preferably at the federal level."Caesars also has spun off Caesars Acquisition (CACQ), whose goal is to acquire online gaming sites and technology. Most of the rest of the U.S. casino industry, which generates more than $37 billion in revenue a year, supports legalizing online gambling.But Las Vegas Sands  (LVS) CEO Sheldon Adelson is vehemently against it, and Wynn Resorts (WYNN) CEO Steve Wynn has withdrawn his earlier backing.Possible FrameworkDespite this opposition, Nevada and Delaware recently took what many see as a significant step toward national legal online gambling.Last month they signed a compact — similar to the ones states use to enable multistate lotteries — that lets gamblers in both states play on sites based in each other's state.The agreement is for online poker only, but market tracker Union Gaming noted in a report that it is the first of its kind and "could serve as a framework for future interstate compacts."The two states hope to build on the Justice Department's 2011 decision to allow online gambling, except for sports betting, even though it limits betting to residents within a state playing on sites based in that state.Nevada, New Jersey and Delaware were the first to offer online gaming. Struggling Atlantic City venues are betting online games will drive interest in playing at casinos rather than encourage players to just stay at home.Other states, still licking wounds from the recession and looking to boost tax revenues, are mulling legalization too.They won't get any help from Adelson, who has said online betting will open the door to minors gambling and to unscrupulous sites preying on vulnerable people.In January, he launched the Coalition to Stop Internet Gambling, which is calling on Congress to pass a federal ban on Internet gambling.An opposing group, the Coalition for Consumer and Online Protection, has formed with backing from MGM Resorts, the American Gaming Association and the Poker Players Alliance, among others.MGM's Murren says the industry must be "absolutely vigilant and tireless" in shutting down illegal gambling sites and warns they could damage the overall industry."From our perspective at MGM, the most important dimension of the debate has to be on law enforcement," he said.Adelson may have found an ally in his bid to hold back the online gambling trend.888 Holdings On HoldUntil recently, Steve Wynn was preparing his company for online gaming. In September he agreed to have U.K.-based 888 Holdings develop his resort's online poker offerings.But in a January interview with industry tracker Jon Ralston at RalstonReports.com, Wynn said he now agrees with Adelson.Wynn added later it's possible he could change his mind again."This is not a good entrepreneurial opportunity," he told Ralston. "Where's the business opportunity? The big problem I see is I don't see the government letting us keep the money."Wynn has since put its partnership with 888 Holdings on hold.Meantime, 888 is working with regulators in states considering legalizing online gambling to educate them about safety and security issues.888 CEO Brian Mattingley said in an interview with IBD that based on his conversations with analysts, the online gambling market could reach $5 billion-$8 billion when it matures."The opportunity in the U.S. is going to be enormous," he said.

The stock market today opened lower amid tension in Ukraine and soft Chinese factory data, but has already pared a large chunk of its losses.

The S&P 500 fell 0.4% while the Nasdaq was off 0.3%. They were down by as much as 0.8% and 0.9%, respectively. The Dow Jones industrial average lost 0.5%, hurt by JPMorgan (JPM) and Pfizer (PFE). Volume was tracking lower across the board, especially on the Nasdaq.

In economic news, the ISM non-manufacturing index rose to a better-than-expected 55.2 in April from 53.1 in March — the best reading in six months. Economists had expected 54.2, according to Econoday.
Ambarella (AMBA) slumped 5% to its lowest levels in nearly five months. The stock sliced its 200-day moving average. It has never closed below that level since coming public in October of 2012.

It rose nearly 1% after Raymond James upgraded shares to outperform from market perform and placed a price target at 560. Chipotle is stabilizing near its 200-day moving average after falling 24% from its March peak.

Sands' Singapore casino revenue was lower than expected, while Macau continued its blistering growth pace. A new bridge being built between Macau and Hong Kong, just…

Wells Fargo lifted its 2014 earning per share estimates for Las Vegas Sands (LVS), Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and Hong Kong-based Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL), which all operate casinos in China's special gambling quarter Macau.
The bank continues to be positive on long-term prospects for Macau, but says in a client note that the region's breakneck pace of growth could moderate this year, limiting upside potential.

Wells Fargo raised its full-year EPS estimate for Sands, which is on the IBD 50 list of top-rated stocks, to $3.88 from $3.47; for Wynn to $8.36 from $7.16; and for Melco Crown to $1.65 from $1.46. It kept outperform ratings on all three stocks, with a bias to Sands and Wynn.

Wells Fargo analyst Cameron McKnight noted in a separate, in-depth report on Macau that China is spending billions to build high-speed rail lines to Macau on its southern coast, as the casinos build new restaurants, hotels and entertainment venues to attract gamblers from around the globe.
Shares of Sands, which reports fourth-quarter earnings after the market close Wednesday, were down 2% in afternoon trading in the stock market today.
Consensus of 22 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters is for Sands EPS to climb 56% to 84 cents and revenue to grow 21% to $3.71 billion.
McKnight said tightened lending in China could curb high-roller VIP gamblers in Macau who borrow from junket operators to gamble, and that could weigh on casinos later this year.

MGM Resorts International (MGM), which also has Macau casinos, didn't get an EPS upgrade from Wells Fargo, which noted in the report that its mass market (middle class and tourist) revenue declined an estimated 4.5% in December.
Wynn, Melco Crown and MGM Resorts were all down in afternoon trading.

Stocks were tightly mixed at Tuesday's open, with earnings reports driving much of the early action.
The Nasdaq, hamstrung by Baidu's (BIDU) 14% decline, fought with a fractional loss. The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 each added 0.2%.
Volume was soft, down 12% on the Nasdaq and 17% lower on the NYSE, compared to action at the same time Monday.

The stock market today has an eye on the Federal Open Market Committee, which is meeting in Washington but not expected to generate any news until the policy announcement scheduled for 2 p.m. on Wednesday.

Other economic news began with home prices, which were effectively flat in May, according to a 4.9 reading for the Case Shiller 20-City Home Price Index. Economists had expected a reading of 5.6. April's number was revised a notch higher, to 5.

The Conference Board's Consumer Confidence Index also fell, dropping to 90.9 in July, down from June's 101.4 tally, which was revised lower to 99.8. Economist consensus projected a very slight dip, to 99.6, for July.

A more positive note from researcher Markit reported the services sector of the economy improved in July. The preliminary estimate for its PMI index rose to 55.2, up from a 54.8 reading in June. Consensus had looked for a no-change number of 54.8.
In stocks, reactions were generally positive as quarterly reports rolled out from a broad range of companies.

Ford (F) and heavy truck maker Paccar (PCAR) climbed nearly 2% each. GrubHub (GRUB) jumped 3% after its Q2 report. Norway's state-owned oil producer Statoil (STO) jumped more than 2% on its second-quarter results.

Baidu (BIDU) posted the news-leading decline, with shares diving 14% after the company reported a Q2 earnings miss late Monday. The drop put shares down 17% so far for the week, and far below critical levels of support.

Cummins (CMI) powered up almost 4% after the diesel engine maker easily beat analysts' second-quarter sales and earnings projections. Management held to its prior revenue guidance for the year, which is consistent with consensus views. The stock has been in a deepening consolidation since June last year.

United Parcel Service (UPS) swept up nearly 4% as its earnings beat consensus estimates. Revenue stopped short of expectations, but management backed its prior EPS range of $5.05 to $5.30 for the year, and said it would come in near the top of that range. The stock has been crawling along the bottom of a flat consolidation and fighting to retake 10-week support since January.
The IBD 50 list opened the session evenly split — half up, half down at the start of trade.
Horizon Pharma (HZNP) and Blackhawk Network (HAWK) led the group, up more than 2% each. United Therapeutics (UTHR) grabbed the low post, dropping almost 4% after a mixed second-quarter report.

JetBlue Airways (JBLU) slipped nearly 4% after 132% EPS growth met Q2 expectations, but an 8% revenue gain stopped short of consensus estimates. Shares of Las Vegas Sands (LVS), Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) are rallying as they develop Macau casinos with new hotel rooms, restaurants and entertainment centers.

Macau officials said gambling revenue for the world's top gaming destination climbed 18.6% in 2013 to $45.2 billion as the popular destination on China's southern coast, across the straits from Hong Kong, continues to build out.
The surge topped many estimates, including Wells Fargo's. Analyst Cameron McKnight said he was expecting 12%-15% growth for the year.

Looking ahead into 2014, the "macro environment remains generally supportive of growth" in Macau, he said in a report, adding that "Chinese high-end consumer sentiment is now at year-to-date highs, and export growth remains strong."
Union Gaming Group said Macau's 2013 tally smashed records and predicted 2014 gaming revenue growth of 14%.
"Based on numerous conversations we've had with casino operators over the past few weeks we find no reason to alter our bullish stance on Macau as we head into 2014," wrote analyst Grant Govertsen.
Wynn was up 1.5%, hitting a new all-time high, on the stock market todayhttps://www.investors.com/stock-market-today/ . Melco, up 2.5%, was also at a fresh high.
Las Vegas Sands stock rose 1% to a 5-1/2-year high, and MGM Resorts International (MGM), which competes with Sands and Wynn in Macau, rallied 0.5% to the highest in more than five years.
Macau gets the bulk of its revenue from Chinese middle-class tourists and affluent VIP high rollers, although it attracts gamblers from around the globe.

Stocks ended mixed Wednesday as investors sifted through another batch of conflicting earnings reports.The Nasdaq rose 0.4% to a fresh 13-year high, while the S&P 500 edged up 0.1%. But the Dow Jones industrial average lost 0.2%, led by IBM's (IBM) 3% drop following mixed quarterly results. Volume was lower across the stock market today, according to preliminary data.United Technologies (UTX) climbed 1% after its quarterly earnings jumped 52%, beating analyst estimates, on strength in its elevator and aerospace divisions. Revenue rose just 2%, however, trailing views.Meanwhile, Nu Skin (NUS) rose 6% in heavy volume, stemming a sharp four-session sell-off, after Deutsche Bank said a Chinese government investigation into the company's business practices will likely end in a small fine.Yet the stock remains a whopping 41% off a recent 52-week high.VMware (VMW) reversed higher and ended up 2% in heavy volume after announcing that it would buy privately held AirWatch for $1.54 billion. The top maker of virtualization software used in corporate data centers also preannounced Q4 revenue that matched Wall Street estimates.Atlanta-based AirWatch sells mobile computing management and security software to large companies.On the downside, casino operators Las Vegas Sands (LVS), MGM Resorts International (MGM) andWynn Resorts (WYNN) each fell 2% following negative comments about growth in the Chinese gambling enclave of Macau.Las Vegas Sands is 2% above a 78.23 buy point from a three-weeks-tight pattern. Wynn is far extended from a 173.48 flat-base entry. MGM is also well out of buying range.
By the late 1990s, Walt Disney shareholders could have whistled toward work — or retirement.
The company stood atop the entertainment world, growing strongly as its animation division churned out hits, its live-action films flowered, and its dusty video library turned into content gold.
Shares surged 8,943% from their 1984 low to their March 2014 peak, with the biggest run from '84 to '98.
But in the spring of 1984, all of that was far off.

A few years after the death of the visionary founder Walt in 1966, Disney (DIS) foundered under weak leadership and little sense of direction. Once the company's crown jewels, the animated movies had fallen by the wayside, and its live-action films — think of "Escape to Witch Mountain" (1965) and "Tron" (1982) — weren't much better.
In fiscal 1982, net income plunged 18% and fell 7% again the following year. The next year, corporate raider Saul Steinberg targeted Disney, which eventually paid him $32 million to go away.
The Disney board knew that it needed change. In September of 1984, Michael Eisner started as CEO and chairman, and Frank Wells as president.

"It was a fabulous management team. People were at their absolute best," said Chris Dixon, who covered Disney as a PaineWebber analyst at the time. "Eisner was terrific in terms of imagination and energy, and Frank, because of his long-term experience, added a little gray hair."

"The '80s were golden," said Hal Vogel, a long-time entertainment industry analyst and investor who wrote "Entertainment Industry Economics." "It was a very positive change and a very fruitful period."

One of the team's first smart moves, analysts say, was to recognize the cash potential of Disney's assets. By the early 1980s, the theme parks were generating 70% of company income, according to the website Funding Universe.
"They sensed correctly that they could raise ticket prices and not affect demand for the parks," Vogel said.
In fact, raising ticket prices by just $1 would yield $30 million more per year, wrote Kim Masters in "The Keys to the Kingdom: The Rise of Michael Eisner and the Fall of Everybody Else."

Disney got lucky with demographics, says Vogel, as children of baby boomers got old enough to appreciate the theme parks. But it was a stroke of genius, not luck, that led Eisner to see Disney's existing film stock as an asset to be tapped.

"Such a bounty has fallen into my lap. Every day a new asset falls out of the sky," Eisner said in Masters' book. Wells was said to have quipped, "Every time I open a door at this company, there's money behind it."

No company had thought of marketing videocassettes cheaply enough that parents could buy them for children to watch over and over, Masters wrote, and that brainstorm made video a "staggering source of revenue" for Disney. Its video library, more than those of most studios, was easily distributed overseas because the films didn't require a lot of sophisticated translation.
Eisner's recognition that old content had value changed the face of entertainment. It helped cable fill empty channels and gave rise to new business models such as Netflix (NFLX) and Roku.
Again, Disney was in the sweet spot. Consumers weren't the only ones looking for videocassette content; scores of new TV channels also needed it, and Disney had family-friendly films galore.
To create new movie and TV content, Eisner and Wells hired Jeffrey Katzenberg, who'd worked under Eisner at Paramount, as Disney Studios chairman.

Under Katzenberg's direction, Disney revitalized its animation division, turning out hits like "The Little Mermaid," which won two Oscars and grossed a record-setting $85 million; "Beauty and the Beast," the first animated film to be nominated for a best-picture Oscar; and "The Lion King," which took in a staggering $423 million in theatrical box-office revenues according to the website BoxOfficeMojo.
Katzenberg "lit a fire under people," said Bill Cotter, author of "The Wonderful World of Disney Television." Cotter worked for that Disney medium for years.

Thomas Sito, who helped animate many of the hit films of the Disney renaissance, including "Little Mermaid" and "Aladdin," believes another manager was also key to that revival: Roy Disney, Walt's nephew, who became head of the animation division in 1984.

Roy was personally invested in the revival of animation, which had been the Disney Co.'s heart and soul. Sito told IBD that when it came to making decisions about the quality of the products, Roy used to growl, "I have to care. My name's on the damn door."

The entire management team focused on bringing that sense of quality back to Disney films, Sito says. That was partly due to outside competition; former Disney animator Don Bluth had left and was producing popular animated films such as 1986's "An American Tail."
Katzenberg used to liken Disney's status as synonymous with quality family entertainment just as the Kleenex brand is to tissues.
"It was very exciting at the time, because as artists we always had faith in the art of animation and its ability to entertain," Sito said.

Disney's new successes also showed Hollywood that animation could be big business again. The Lucasfilm spinoff Pixar had enormous hits with "Toy Story," "Finding Nemo" and other films before being bought by Disney in 2006. And Katzenberg had hits like the "Shrek" films at DreamWorks Animation (DWA) after leaving Disney.

Eisner, who was president of Paramount Pictures when Disney tapped him for the CEO job, also knew that there was value in live-action, non-G-rated movie fare. Disney had established Touchstone Films in 1983, before Eisner started, and had even had a hit with the Tom Hanks comedy "Splash."
Eisner gave Touchstone lots of attention, and Touchstone hits such as "Outrageous Fortune," "Ruthless People" and "Pretty Woman" were box-office gold.
Eisner also expanded the moneymaking theme parks. He broadened Walt Disney World in Orlando, Fla., via a partnership with MGM for a studio-themed entertainment park, which opened in 1989.

But Eisner thought even bigger. Tokyo Disneyland had opened in 1983, and while it did well, it was considered a missed opportunity because Disney had leased its characters and name to a local concessionaire rather than owning everything in the park outright. Still, Vogel said, "It was quite lucrative, and Europe was the next logical decision." Eisner began working on establishing a Disneyland in Paris: Euro Disney, which opened in 1992.
Vogel lauds the decision to pursue global expansion. It spread Disney products to consumers around the world and reinforced the brand's iconic status.

More than that, Eisner's long-distance shift meant that every interaction that a consumer had with Disney sparked another. A theme-park vacation would remind children of a love for Disney films, and re-viewing an old favorite movie could send a parent to buy a toy with a character's likeness. Some 22% of Disney's revenue came from international operations by 1991.

All of those ventures were a prelude to one of Eisner's biggest steps: buying ABC/Capital Cities in 1996 for $19 billion. "Once they were successful in being able to expand and demonstrate they could take the company to the next level and scale it, the next step was buying ABC," Dixon said.
The acquisition got Disney a broadcast network along with TV and radio stations — plus ESPN, which at the time had 95 million worldwide viewers. "ESPN was the crown jewel," Vogel said.
The purchase was especially bold because it guaranteed Disney a network for its programs, Masters notes.

ABC could air new Disney programming, which could be resold as reruns to cable. Yet Disney remained focused on quality entertainment rather than on churning out lots of content to dump on the network, says Cotter.

The sense of rebirth touching the film animators reached the TV division as well, Cotter said: "The more you keep a feeling of fire and ambition under a creative crowd, the more they're going to rise to the occasion."

Disney's market cap increased from $2 billion to $53 billion from 1984 to 1996. Eisner could point to 18 new businesses into which he'd led the company since taking the reins, including professional sports teams, live Broadway shows and Disney stores.

"In the history of American business, this was a great group of people who complemented each other at the same time as expanding demand for American entertainment and rapidly developing technology delivered entertainment in new and different ways," Dixon said.By the late 1990s, Walt Disney shareholders could have whistled toward work — or retirement.The company stood atop the entertainment world, growing strongly as its animation division churned out hits, its live-action films flowered, and its dusty video library turned into content gold.Shares surged 8,943% from their 1984 low to their March 2014 peak, with the biggest run from '84 to '98.But in the spring of 1984, all of that was far off.A few years after the death of the visionary founder Walt in 1966, Disney (DIS) foundered under weak leadership and little sense of direction. Some 22% of Disney's revenue came from international operations by 1991.All of those ventures were a prelude to one of Eisner's biggest steps: buying ABC/Capital Cities in 1996 for $19 billion. "Once they were successful in being able to expand and demonstrate they could take the company to the next level and scale it, the next step was buying ABC," Dixon said.The acquisition got Disney a broadcast network along with TV and radio stations — plus ESPN, which at the time had 95 million worldwide viewers. "ESPN was the crown jewel," Vogel said.The purchase was especially bold because it guaranteed Disney a network for its programs, Masters notes.ABC could air new Disney programming, which could be resold as reruns to cable. Yet Disney remained focused on quality entertainment rather than on churning out lots of content to dump on the network, says Cotter.The sense of rebirth touching the film animators reached the TV division as well, Cotter said: "The more you keep a feeling of fire and ambition under a creative crowd, the more they're going to rise to the occasion."Disney's market cap increased from $2 billion to $53 billion from 1984 to 1996. Eisner could point to 18 new businesses into which he'd led the company since taking the reins, including professional sports teams, live Broadway shows and Disney stores."In the history of American business, this was a great group of people who complemented each other at the same time as expanding demand for American entertainment and rapidly developing technology delivered entertainment in new and different ways," Dixon said.

Las Vegas casinos were big winners in November in Macau, the world's top gaming destination.RBC Capital Markets analyst John Kempf said Friday in an analysis of gambling revenue figures released earlier by Macau officials that Las Vegas Sands (LVS), Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and MGM Resorts International (MGM) all saw big gains form the month.Meanwhile, Hong Kong-based SJM Holdings "had an atypically weak month," he said.Macau's total gambling revenue grew 21.1% in November vs. the same month a year ago, to $3.8 billion, edging RBC's forecast for a 20% increase.Sands, the world's largest casino company and on the proprietary IBD Leaderboard list of top-rated stocks, keeps drawing winning cards.It improved its Macau market share by 100 basis points, to 21.9%, and was leader in the mass market category, mainly middle-class tourists from China and elsewhere.Sands' stock earlier surged 4% Wednesday after Standard & Poor's upgraded its credit rating to BBB- from BB+ with a stable outlook.Sands rose less than 1% in Friday afternoon trading on the stock market today. MGM surged 3% and Wynn rose a bit.Meanwhile, Sands' archrival in Macau, Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL), was downgraded on Wednesday from Goldman Sachs' conviction buy list to a buy rating.Goldman said Melco Crown's Cotai, Macau casinos outperformed the market last quarter and it expects "less dramatic positive earnings revisions momentum" this quarter. Melco Crown fell.Kempf forecasts seasonally slow growth for Macau casinos this month."As we round out a record year in Macau, we are expecting December (gambling revenue) will increase 7.5% over the prior year," he said in the report, adding, "However, we believe this is a conservative estimate which may leave room for upside surprise to end the year."

Young guns such as Facebook (FB) and Las Vegas Sands (LVS) are top-rated companies that have gone public within the last 15 years. These nimble companies often show big stock price growth in the first years of public trading. Today's Screen Of The Day, Young Guns, includes a group of companies that also have massive trading volume, indicating they're traded…

After pausing to clear its throat Thursday, the market uptrend returned to yelling mode Friday. The Nasdaq popped 1.1%, while the small-cap S&P 600 roared 1.8%. The S&P 500 added 0.5%. The IBD 50 gained 1.3%. Volume rose across the board. Friday was a quadruple-witching session, a day when stock and index options, and stock and index futures expire. This…

Stocks continued to hold near session highs Monday afternoon following buyout news and comments from Fed officials. The Nasdaq and the S&P 500 jumped 1.1% each. Both regained their 50-day moving averages. Volume was running mixed in the stock market today compared with the same time Friday. Trade was tracking about 1% higher on the NYSE and nearly 13% lower on the Nasdaq.

Among leading stocks, Ritchie Bros. Auctioneers (RBA) gapped above its 50-day line and jumped 5% on a upgrade. Canaccord Genuity raised shares to buy from hold and lifted its price target to 32 from 27. Ritchie Bros. is in a consolidation with a 30.95 buy point.

CyberArk Software (CYBR) gapped up, rallied 5% and regained its 50-day moving average. The line had acted as resistance as the stock bounced back after a sell signal in late June. But CyberArk still has more work to do to form a new base.

Nvidia (NVDA) climbed 4% in fast trade after bouncing back from early weakness. The stock cleared a 23.70 buy point from a consolidation. Shares of the graphics chip maker already surged 12% Friday on its Q2 results.

On the downside, shares of Chinese online retailer JD.com (JD) gapped down and slumped 6% on news that Alibaba (BABA) will invest $4.6 billion for a near 20% stake in Suning Commerce. With the loss, the correction in JD.com's handle stands at 18%. It might still be snowing on the East Coast, but spring is officially here. Palm trees and sandy beaches are calling all Americans — not just students — to take a break from the snow and head to somewhere sunny.
But even those stuck in the latest snowstorm can still take advantage of spring. Here are six spring-break stocks on the Big Cap Leaders Screen of the Day.
Delta Air Lines (DAL) is on the list with the highest possible Composite Rating of 99. Shares soared 3.33% to 34.43 in the stock market Tuesday.
The airline offers flights to numerous warm destinations in the U.S., like Miami, San Diego and Honolulu, as well as to beach spots abroad like the Bahamas.

For those who can't unplug from the office, on Tuesday Delta announced it will have Wi-Fi service on Boeing (BA) 747 flights from Los Angeles and Atlanta to Tokyo. The company plans to add Wi-Fi services on all international flights by the end of next year.

Southwest Airlines (LUV) is also featured on the screen with a 99 rating. The airline will begin international flights to the Bahamas, Aruba and Jamaica starting in July. The airline is expanding its routes at home as well. On Monday, Southwest said it will more than double flights out of Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport in the D.C. area. New routes include nonstop flights to Akron-Canton, Ohio; Indianapolis and Dallas. In December, Southwest bought American Airlines' (AAL) takeoff and landing spots at Reagan as part of American's merger deal with U.S. Air.
With the economy on an uptick, more travelers are heading to Las Vegas to try their luck in Sin City.
Wynn Resorts (WYNN) has a 99 Composite Rating and Las Vegas Sands (LVS) enjoys a CR of 98.

Earlier this month, Sands applied to Singapore officials for permits to add 1,500 rooms to its Marina Bay Sands casino there. Sands also has operations in Macau, along with MGM Resorts International (MGM) and Wynn.
Wynn shares fell more than 2% to 219.50 on Tuesday and Sands fell nearly 2% to 78.80. Both have fallen below their 50-day moving averages
If you want to look good while hitting the beach in Miami or the tables in Vegas, Michael Kors (KORS) has affordable luxury offerings like handbags and dresses to adorn spring-break revelers.
Kors has a 98 rating. Luxury brands outperformed their mid-market peers during the holiday season as middle-class consumers looked for deep discounts.

Take lots of pictures en route to Vegas or sporting a Kors bag at the beach and put them up on Facebook (FB) or its sister site Instagram. The social media giant has a 99 rating. Late Tuesday it announced plans to buy virtual reality company Oculus VR for $1.9 billion — perhaps you can take a virtual trip to Maui one day. Casino industry sector leader Las Vegas Sands (LVS) received a credit rating upgrade from S&P, while highly rated rival Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) was removed from Goldman Sachs' conviction buy list.

Standard & Poor's Rating Services lifted Sands' corporate credit rating to BBB- from BB+, with a stable outlook. The ratings agency said it expects the world's largest casino company to maintain low debt through 2015, based on current development and shareholder return plans, which could boost future earnings.
"We believe this level of expected leverage provides ample cushion" compared to the company financial risk profile, S&P said in the report.

Sands is on the proprietary IBD Leaderboard list of top-rated stocks and has seen accelerating earnings growth this year in part on returns from its new Sands Cotai Central casino, which opened in Macau, China, last year.
Sands shares were up 3% in Wednesday afternoon trading on the stock market today.
Meanwhile, Goldman Sachs downgraded Hong Kong-based Melco Crown from its conviction buy list to a buy rating, although it increased its price target to 43 from 34.10.

Melco's Cotai casinos outperformed peers by an average 34% last quarter and "we expect to see less dramatic positive earnings revisions momentum for the stock over the next 6-12 months," Goldman analyst Simon Cheung said in a client note.
Shares still rallied 1%. Both Melco and Las Vegas Sands have properties in Macau, the world's most popular casino gaming destination.
Macau officials said Monday that November gambling revenue surged 21.3% annually to $3.8 billion, topping RBC Capital Markets' estimate for a 20% increase.
"We are now expecting 2013 gross gaming revenue (in Macau) will be up 17.5%, up from our previous estimate of 17%," RBC analyst John Kempf said in a client note.

Among other large casinos, Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and MGM Resorts International (MGM) were up about 2% each. Bally Technologies (BYI), which provides gaming equipment to casinos, eased fractionally.Casino industry sector leader Las Vegas Sands (LVS) received a credit rating upgrade from S&P, while highly rated rival Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) was removed from Goldman Sachs' conviction buy list.Standard & Poor's Rating Services lifted Sands' corporate credit rating to BBB- from BB+, with a stable outlook. Bally Technologies (BYI), which provides gaming equipment to casinos, eased fractionally.

Top casino operators Las Vegas Sands (LVS), MGM Resorts International (MGM) and Wynn Resorts (WYNN) are expected to keep growing in China, as Beijing invests billions to attract visitors to Macau, a new report said.
Gambling revenue in Macau is on track for a 15%-17% rise for the month of November vs. a year earlier, RBC Capital Markets said Monday, up from its prior estimate for a 12% increase.

RBC analyst John Kempf said the estimate is based on the city's $1.25 billion in gambling revenue for the first 10 days of this month. He recommends investors with stock in the three casino companies let it ride.
In 2012, Macau gambling revenue was $38 billion, and analysts' consensus is that it will be around $44 billion this year.

Sands, MGM and Wynn get the bulk of their revenue from Macau. But it can't keep growing quickly forever, Kempf noted, and some investors wonder whether it's time to take money off the table and sell shares in related companies.
"Our answer, particularly in light of the recent growth rates, is not now," Kempf said in a client note.

"And with no new supply (of casino resorts) until mid-2015, infrastructure projects supporting new demand, and signs that the China economy is at least stabilizing, the demand-supply imbalance could last for the foreseeable future."
He has an "outperform" rating on all three companies.
China is building what is expected to be the world's most expensive high-speed rail system to bring middle-class Chinese to the coastal tourist spot.
It's also building a bridge from Macau to Hong Kong and a new airport, which will be the second major airport to serve Macau.
But Kempf cautioned there are several issues percolating that need to be watched.

Among them are rising labor costs as the standard of living improves in China, pressure from China's government on casinos to diversify to more family-oriented entertainment, and competition from resorts on Hainan Island, where there are no travel restrictions like there are in Macau.
Nevertheless, Kempf said, "As for now, we remain bullish on the near-term prospects of Macau and buyers of Macau-related names."

Sands shares rose 1% in afternoon trading Monday on the stock market today. New Yorkers voted for as many as seven casinos Tuesday, while voters in Boston and other Massachusetts cities were split on similar proposals, intensifying the competition between MGM Resorts International (MGM),Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and Caesars Entertainment (CZR) to build new projects. In Boston, voters rejected a proposal to build a $1 billion casino resort at the Suffolk Downs race track,…

Macau continued its winning ways, a boon to Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and other casinos in the world's most popular gaming destination, according to two reports. RBC Capital Markets analyst John Kempf said in a client note he expects gambling revenue in the special gaming district on China's southern coast, across the straits from Hong Kong, to grow 15%-17% this…
Wynn Resorts (WYNN) stock was nursing a hangover Friday amid a reversal from the prior day's gain, after third-quarter results pointed to weakness in its Las Vegas properties.

The casino company late Thursday reported a 24% jump in Q3 earnings per share to $1.84, trouncing estimates of $1.66. Revenue rose 7% to $1.39 billion, above analyst views for $1.36 billion, on continued growth in Chinese gambling hub Macau.
Revenue from Macau, the world's top casino destination, climbed 9.6% to $997.6 million. But revenue at its Las Vegas casinos edged up just 1.1% to $392.5 million.
Shares were down more than 3% in Friday afternoon trading in the stock market today. The stock had risen 54% for the year by last Monday before consolidating.
Rival Las Vegas Sands (LVS), the No. 1 casino company and on the IBD Leaderboard list of top-rated stocks, was down 1%.
MGM Resorts International (MGM) and Hong Kong's Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL), which both compete with Wynn in Macau, were down as well.
Stifel Nicolaus Capital Markets reiterated a hold rating on Wynn, saying in a client note it was disappointed with weakness in Las Vegas.

RBC Capital Markets analyst John Kempf said in a note that Wynn's gains came from a steady stream of high-roller VIPs as well as middle-class, mass-market gamblers, pointing out "the 33% EBITDA (profit) margin was up 90 basis points from the prior year and better than our estimate."

RBC has an outperform rating on Wynn.Wynn Resorts (WYNN) stock was nursing a hangover Friday amid a reversal from the prior day's gain, after third-quarter results pointed to weakness in its Las Vegas properties.The casino company late Thursday reported a 24% jump in Q3 earnings per share to $1.84, trouncing estimates of $1.66. A pair of reports confirming falling revenue for Macau gambling proved a losing hand for Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and other Macau-centric casinos.Wells Fargo analyst Cameron McKnight said Macau gaming revenue for July fell 3.6% to $3.5 billion. The drop came amid a crackdown on practices by local lenders who allegedly used credit cards to illegally launder money. Some of those lenders have been arrested as a result.Visitors to Macau routinely borrow money to get around restrictions on the amount of cash that can be brought into the special district across the strait from Hong Kong.The crackdown includes tighter restrictions on lenders that make it harder for visitors to borrow, causing some, especially high-roller VIP gamblers, to stay away.The revenue drop was led by a 13.9% slide in VIP gaming, mostly from baccarat play. Mass market (middle class tourist) revenue rose 17%, but that was the weakest growth since the bank started tracking Macau casinos in 2010.McKnight said Macau "revenues did not improve materially in the back half of July, which could mean mainland China's political initiatives, and potentially transit visa changes, are impacting premium mass" gambling revenue.In a separate report, Deutsche Bank lowered its third-quarter and full-year 2014 revenue forecast for Macau.Deutsche Bank analyst Carlo Santarelli expects Q3 revenue to fall 0.9% vs. the same quarter a year ago and full year revenue to grow 6.5%, well below the region's usual growth rates, and down from his earlier outlook for 3% Q3 growth and 8.6% for the full year.Deutsche Bank also lowered its August gross gaming revenue forecast to a mild 3% increase "to account for softer VIP volume and mass revenue trends against a tough comparison" vs. the same month a year ago, StreetInsider quoted Santarelli as saying in the report.Las Vegas Sands shares were down more than 4% at 68.93 in Wednesday afternoon trading on the stock market today.Other large Las Vegas casinos with operations in Macau dived. Wynn Resorts (WYNN) fell 3.5% and MGM Resorts International (MGM) slid 2%.Hong Kong-based Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) skidded 5%.Follow James DeTar on Twitter: @IBD_JDeTar.
Macau-centric casinos continue to be pounded by a mid-year slowdown, with Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) on Thursday becoming the latest to fall short of revenue and profit targets.

Additionally, Wells Fargo analyst Cameron McKnight said in a post-earnings report that the Taipei District Prosecutors Office had indicted Melco Crown's Taiwan branch office and certain employees for alleged violations of local banking and foreign exchange laws. The company was expected to provide details on its earnings call.

Melco Crown, which competes with Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and other large U.S. casinos in Macau, said Q2 earnings per share fell 26% from the same quarter a year ago to 26 cents. That was 10 cents below consensus of 21 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters.
Revenue slid 7.4% to $1.199 billion, undershooting Wall Street's $1.297 billion target.
Casino mogul and Melco CEO Lawrence Ho said the shortfall was mainly in the high-roller VIP segment, partly offset by a 38% increase in so-called mass market, or tourist, table game revenues.
Melco shares slid as much as 5% early and settled to a 2.9% drop at 29.14 in morning trading on the stock market today.

McKnight in a report said it was a "soft" quarter for Melco and noted its "City of Dreams Manila is on track to open later this year, while Studio City remains on-track for a mid-2015 opening." Wells Fargo has an outperform rating on Melco.
The company's board also approved a $500 million share repurchase program.
Las Vegas Sands last month also reported disappointing results, mainly on weakness in Macau. Sands shares lost 2.2% Thursday.

Among other Vegas casinos with Macau operations, Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and MGM Resorts International (MGM) lost more than 1% intraday. Both reported Macau weakness in their recent earnings reports, partially offset by resurging business in Las Vegas.

Stocks traded in another tight range Thursday and showed some resilience, recovering off session lows.

Two days after Philadelphia Federal Reserve President Charles Plosser said the economy isn't in as bad a shape as some might think, St. Louis Fed President James Bullard made equally optimistic comments about the economy, saying the Fed could raise rates as early as the first quarter of 2015.

The market didn't like the comments at first. The Nasdaq lost 0.8% early but ended fractionally lower. The Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 each fell 0.1%. Preliminary data showed volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq coming in lower than Wednesday's totals.
In the stock market today, GoPro (GPRO) soared in its debut. The stock priced Wednesday night at 24 and opened at 28.65. It closed at 31.34.

In earnings news, Lennar (LEN) reportedbetter-than-expected earnings, but it didn't help the stock much. The stock erased early gains and fell 0.5%. It closed below a potential cup-with-handle buy point of 42.38.

Elsewhere, casino operator MGM Resorts (MGM) continued work on the right side of a shallow consolidation. Shares rose 1%. The stock's price strength has been impressive in light of sluggish price performance lately from the likes of Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and Las Vegas Sands (LVS), which have a strong presence in Macau, the gambling center off mainland China. Concerns about slowing growth in Macau have weighed on both stocks.

On the downside, sellers continued to have their way with Bed, Bath & Beyond (BBBY) as shares cratered 7%. The stock has been on a sharp downtrend since January. Late Wednesday, the home furnishings retailer reported another disappointing quarter and issued a soft outlook. Profit of 93 cents a share was flat from a year ago and slightly below expectations. The stock's price strength has been impressive in light of sluggish price performance lately from the likes of Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and Las Vegas Sands (LVS), which have a strong presence in Macau, the gambling center off mainland China. Concerns about slowing growth in Macau have weighed on both stocks.On the downside, sellers continued to have their way with Bed, Bath & Beyond (BBBY) as shares cratered 7%. The stock has been on a sharp downtrend since January. Late Wednesday, the home furnishings retailer reported another disappointing quarter and issued a soft outlook. Profit of 93 cents a share was flat from a year ago and slightly below expectations. Sales rose 2% to $2.66 billion.

Las Vegas hit a winning streak in May as gambling revenue surged 17% compared with the same month last year. That could lift shares of Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and other Vegas-based casinos.Nevada's Gaming Control Board said Friday that gambling revenue hit $592.9 million in May, up from $505.4 million a year earlier. Year to date, its gambling revenue is up 3.9%. For Nevada statewide, including Lake Tahoe and Reno casinos in northern Nevada, revenue grew 8.1% to $970.3 million in May compared with May '13.Union Gaming analyst Robert Shore said the 17% growth figure was the highest for Las Vegas since November 2013, when revenue surged 22.6%."The results are encouraging," Shore told IBD, adding, "Las Vegas is still an aspirational place where people want to come to see shows and gamble."Wells Fargo analyst Cameron McKnight agreed: "We view these results positively for our Las Vegas Strip exposed coverage," including Sands and smaller rivals MGM Resorts International (MGM) and Wynn Resorts (WYNN), which all have casinos both in Las Vegas and Chinese gambling hot spot Macau.Vegas casinos have been losing ground for years to Macau, the top global casino destination.But VIP gamblers have shied away from Macau this year amid a crackdown on lenders who provide money to visitors there, so Las Vegas may have picked up some of that high-rolling business for the month.Shore notes Las Vegas Strip baccarat revenue in May exploded, rising nearly 90% to $170.9 million.Asked whether this indicates Vegas may regain market share from Macau, he said the monthly gain was more of an event-driven improvement. May included an extra Saturday vs. a year ago and a major sporting event in Vegas."Baccarat play, in particular, tends to be event-driven, and in May players came to see (Floyd) Mayweather" win a title fight against challenger Marcos Maidana at the Las Vegas MGM Grand Hotel.Sands shares eased fractionally in afternoon trading in the stock market today, Friday. MGM was also down slightly while Wynn rose a bit.Caesars Entertainment (CZR), which is the largest U.S. casino company but doesn't own casinos in Macau, dipped less than 1%.Hong Kong-based Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL), which operates in Macau but has no U.S. casinos, rose 0.5%.Follow James DeTar on Twitter: @IBD_JDeTar.

The Philadelphia Fed Survey comes out at 10 a.m. ET.
